name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the Paradise papers (2017/2956(RSP)).

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, we have witnessed a series of revelations in respect of tax evasion and avoidance over the last years: Offshore Leaks, LuxLeaks, SwissLeaks, the Panama Papers, and now the Paradise Papers. The Council attaches great importance to such investigative journalism. Not only have these revelations been instrumental in providing bases for informed policy-making, but they have also helped in creating political awareness. It might be the case that many of the practices described in the Paradise Papers are formally legal; however, we cannot exclude that certain schemes exist with the sole objective of reducing the taxes that would otherwise be due. This is unfair for those citizens and enterprises who are paying their fair share of taxes. Against this background, Member States are working very hard to change the legislation so that unwanted practices leading to loss of tax revenue would become illegal. Here, we have to work in the context of 28 different systems of national law which, strictly speaking, fall into the area of national competence, but progress is being made.  The Council and the Commission have worked hand in hand. The Commission was quick to present new proposals to tackle the problems identified and the Council swiftly found necessary compromises and has adopted tax legislation. The list of EU legislation that the Council has adopted against tax evasion and tax avoidance over the last four years, under the unanimity rule, is impressive, especially compared to the previous decades. Clearly, our response is picking up speed. Just to name a few: the revision of the Savings Taxation Directive and of the parent Subsidiary Directive, the adoption of four successive revisions of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation in Tax Matters, the adoption of a new Anti-Tax Avoidance Directive and of amendments concerning hybrid mismatches, the adoption of a new Directive on Dispute Resolution Mechanisms and, lastly, the conclusion of EU agreements on automatic exchange of information with five ‘third countries’ to the European Union.  In some of the cases, for instance with regard to hybrid mismatches, the measures are just about to be implemented by Member States. Their impact on the tax avoidance practices highlighted in the Paradise Papers will therefore only be visible in a few years’ time. We have also adopted conclusions at the Ecofin meeting in November 2016 setting out the process for establishing an EU list of non-cooperative third country jurisdictions for tax purposes. This important work is led by the Council’s Code of Conduct Group for Business Taxation and has been particularly intense over the past months, including in terms of dialogues with a number of countries. At this stage the Code of Conduct Group is seeking commitments from jurisdictions to address the issues that were determined by our experts in the areas of tax transparency, fair taxation and the implementation of anti-base erosion and profit shifting standards. This work of promoting good tax governance standards is also carried out in coordination with the OECD and G20 agenda.  The Code of Conduct Group also continues to perform other important non-legislative tasks such as peer review of our Member States’ potentially harmful tax regimes, development of new guidance to enable fairer tax competition between Member States, dialogue with our immediate neighbours (recently Switzerland and Liechtenstein), and an update of the tax good governance clause to be included in EU agreements with third countries.  All in all, these legislative and non-legislative initiatives just mentioned have been politically important steps for the EU. Among the results achieved so far, we have seen bank secrecy de facto coming to an end, a shift of our policy focus from removing double taxation to tackling double non-taxation, development of new EU policy instruments to combat tax avoidance, and steps taken towards harmonisation of our national practices affecting the functioning of our single market.  However, we cannot be complacent. More work will be needed, since tax planning methods are evolving constantly. We are currently examining several proposals, inter alia the revision of the Mandatory Disclosure Rules Directive, which would require tax advisers to disclose aggressive tax planning schemes to their tax administration. In addition, work is ongoing on several VAT legislative proposals, where we hope to adopt the VAT e-commerce package at the next Ecofin meeting on 5 December.  The Presidency has also initiated a debate on the taxation of the digital economy, which should provide input into OECD discussions. We are also happy that the Commission has announced that it will put forward a legislative proposal on this matter next spring. On this front, we will need the cooperation of our global partners so that international tax rules could be revised and adjusted to the reality of digitalisation. We are, in this respect, closely monitoring international developments. The Council is taking the Paradise Papers revelations very seriously and is moving fast to deliver progress. A fairer tax system is what our citizens expect from us.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, Minister, Ladies and Gentlemen, like all of you, I am deeply outraged by the recent revelations of the "Paradise Papers" which follow other scandals of a similar nature. Every day, new information appearing in the newspapers of all our countries sheds more light on what must be called a planetary, perfectly oiled circuit of aggressive tax planning. A real system of aggressive tax planning. I am shocked, but I am not surprised. We have known for a long time that multinationals, wealthy taxpayers, consulting firms and banks work hand in hand to exempt huge sections of income from tax and that they spare neither their money nor their imagination. We are not here in the face of isolated incidents, but in the face of practices that are systemic, which are global and which are organized. These aggressive tax-optimization schemes are all the more shocking in that many of them - this remains to be verified - are apparently legal. Therefore, we must respond on the ground of law to a defect in the law, with a new regulatory framework. If it is legal, as some claim, then the law has to be changed and that is what I want to do with the help of this Parliament. This is why, since the start of my mandate at the European Commission, I have emphasized transparency, because I am convinced that transparency is our first weapon. It is this that will put an end to the culture of secrecy and the feeling of impunity of the practitioners and beneficiaries of tax evasion. These are a bit like vampires in a way: they fear nothing more than the light. It is up to us to shed this light. Today, there are three major proposals to be finalized to ensure greater transparency in our tax systems. In what Concerning the first, I proposed to you, last June, new transparency rules for tax intermediaries, that is to say the lawyers, bankers, consultants who sell these tax optimization schemes. Behind that, there is an approach, indeed, quite commercial. If the proposal I made is accepted, they will systematically have to declare these arrangements to the tax authorities of the buyer's country. If these schemes are illegal, then tax administrations can take legal action. If they are legal, tax administrations can spot the loophole and fix it. I hope, and I say this firmly here, that the Council adopts the proposal on tax intermediaries within the next six months. This is an easy proposition, which is simple, and therefore it is above all a question of political will. There's no time to lose. There is no real reason to delay this adoption. At the same time, as you know, my colleague, Vera Jourová, has proposed more transparency on beneficial owners within the framework of the directive against money laundering. This information must be public in order to fight against the opaque structures that the “Paradise Papers” have revealed. Today, I must admit that the negotiations are struggling to find a satisfactory answer and outcome. I deeply regret this and encourage the co-legislators to do their utmost to ensure that these new rules can be applied as quickly as possible. The citizens would not understand our inaction after the new warning shot constituted by the “Paradise Papers”. The second proposition that I fundamentally hold on to is targeting businesses through mandatory public disclosure, country by country. What would this publication actually change? It would give every citizen a power of control and pressure that he does not have today. If that is achieved, we would have a publication accessible to all, to citizens, to the media, to NGOs, to you parliamentarians, of accounting and fiscal data which, today, are made available - this is already progress - of tax administrations, but only them. Because it is through pressure from the press, it is through pressure from public opinion that the rules can be changed. These "Paradise Papers", like all these scandals, are good news and bad news every time. A bad one because they reveal, a good one because they are a very decisive spur. Here again, I say to those who are hesitant in the Council: I do not believe that we should oppose transparency and competitiveness. On the contrary, I think that transparency is a factor in the competitiveness of companies and that a company always has an interest in behaving as a good citizen, as a good taxpayer ex ante rather than being then denounced ex post in revelations or leaks. . Do not be afraid of this publication of information country by country, I insist on this notion of publication. That’s what I’ve been saying since the first day I’m here. Finally, this is my third proposal, we must equip ourselves with a European blacklist of tax havens that the Member States wanted to establish on their own responsibility, the Minister spoke about. I made a commitment to complete this list quickly after the Panama Papers scandal, and the Commission quickly made its proposal. I urge Member States to adopt it this time around, not in six months, but at the next Council of Finance Ministers, the Ecofin Council on 5 December. On December 5, we must have a blacklist of tax havens. The work undertaken so far in this framework has already led, at this stage, to interesting advances. 92 third countries were, as we say "screened", examined, and the vast majority have cooperated with experts from the European Union. Several of them have already committed to reforming their tax laws to bring them into line with European standards, but I am convinced that we still have enough to make a credible list. The other problematic countries still now have the opportunity to make commitments at the highest political level, in writing, by the end of this week, not later. Member States have indicated that these commitments will be taken into account when the blacklist is adopted in early December, but I call on Member States and the Code of Conduct Group to stand firm and united on the demands of the European Union and to accept only very concrete commitments. These commitments must be sufficiently precise on the substance, in particular for third countries which, today, do not apply any tax on profits. In my opinion, not applying income tax is a serious breach. The absence of taxes should not be used by these countries to artificially attract profits made elsewhere and thus encourage the establishment of "letterbox companies". What I want is a list that is credible, ambitious, with dissuasive sanctions. No mystery. Fraudsters and tax havens must be hit with the wallet to shake things up. It is a crucial fight to be won in the coming weeks. The last discussion of the Ecofin Council made me rather optimistic, even if I still heard from some ministers such and such nuance that they will be able, I hope, to erase it by 5 December. Yes, sanctions are needed and yes, having no income tax is definitely a problem. I say that to some of my colleagues who spoke at that time. A word on another notion. Along with transparency, we also need a convergence of rules fiscal. It is the absence of common rules in Europe that allows companies to practice this aggressive tax planning. This system thrives and endures thanks to loopholes in current national laws, as well as to the differences between these laws. That is why, here again, I call on the Member States to adopt the European corporate tax base as soon as possible. The CCCTB would indeed make it possible to further limit the artificial transfers of benefits between countries which are one of the major problems we are facing. Here again, the ball is in the capital's court to move forward on this major project. It is imperative to speed up the discussions and adopt a timetable for concluding this common and consolidated European corporate tax base in 2018. It is essential that this text is now the subject of an agreement. Ladies and gentlemen parliamentarians, remarkable progress has been made in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion under this mandate. I do not want and I cannot let it be said that the European Union has sinned by inaction. No, we have made progress together that had not been made before and we must not flog each other, beat each other up. We are not responsible for what goes wrong, but we are responsible for trying to make things better. Bank secrecy no longer exists across Europe, not just the European Union, since this year. Taxation of profits where they are generated limits the transfer of profits to countries with favorable taxation. It exists thanks to us. With the adoption of the measures currently on the table, which I have recalled, our anti-escape shield would be considerably strengthened. If these measures had been put in place over the past three years, if transparency was the rule, if the light was shed, so I think we could have avoided the latest scandal. Member States must assume their responsibilities by transposing the measures already adopted as quickly as possible. Some of the cases raised by the "Paradise Papers" result from legal provisions that will have to be repealed as part of the application of the anti-tax avoidance directives. Why wait until the last moment and let practices continue that should no longer apply? We must speed up the work by adopting the list of tax havens on December 5, adopting rules on tax intermediaries within six months, and adopting the European tax base for corporate tax within a year. You can see that I am setting an agenda for our common work for the coming year. I know that I can count on the European Parliament because de facto we have been allied since the start of this long-term battle with different sensitivities and positions to push the Member States down this path in which they do not always engage spontaneously. , but that they always end up following thanks to you and a little thanks to us. I want to thank you warmly here, because none of the progress we have made together over the past three years would have been possible without the support of the European representation. Now we have to take another decisive step, again we will do it together. (Applause)

name: Luděk Niedermayer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, we are talking again, unfortunately, about new tax scandals. We do not know how many millions of documents, with more than 100 000 names, constitute illegal behaviour. Maybe most of them are actually legal; but they matter, not only because in the view of many people they are immoral – they matter because they are harming our society. Extensive use of loopholes in tax systems, or intentional or unintentional creation of special tax regimes by some tax authorities, are harming our economy. They are harming competition, they are creating unfair ways of increasing inequality. They are harming fiscal policy and, as a consequence, citizens are losing their trust in our society.  How to react on actions that can in a broad sense be legal? There are two basic tools. The first one is better, simpler and clearer tax rules, and we should make them. And the second is to convince the others to do the same. As the European Union, we are in an extremely good position to pursue this agenda. First of all, we are a superpower. We can not only lead by example, but more decisively use soft and hard powers to persuade the others that are making the game unfair. And secondly, we must acknowledge that many of the problems are not outside the EU but within the EU.  This is the moment where I have to turn to the Finance Ministers, because they have the power. This is what the Treaty says. They have power but they also have responsibility, so I ask you, or rather I urge you, not to use the cheap excuses, not to insist on small benefits for you that are paid for in multiples by the others, and not to hide behind the unanimity rules and to act.  We should modernise the tax regime. We can close the loopholes. And in some cases, do not be afraid to go for harmonisation. I am not talking about tax rates, I am talking about the tax base. If we progress in that, we will benefit all. Society will benefit, the economy will benefit. It will make Europe stronger so we should not hesitate. We should act.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems that at every trumpet blast we should be amazed, in reality we discover hot water. Our economy is devoured by a cancer: tax fraud and fraud. It is shameful that, while states were being forced into austerity horse care, some multinational corporations and private citizens stole billions of euros from public coffers by not paying taxes. We have denounced this shame as Socialists and Democrats and we must acknowledge the Juncker Commission and Commissioner Moscovici in particular for having put important and courageous proposals on the table. I am thinking of reporting country by country: we want information on their financial activities to be reported country by country in the financial statements of multinationals. It is right for citizens to know where the multinationals make their profits because it is in that country that they have to pay taxes. We repeat it to the point of boredom: taxes must be paid in the country where the profits are made. Parliament approved its position on this. What is the Council doing? What are the Member States doing? Very little, almost nothing. We also want a clear and credible definition of a tax haven. The current list contains Trinidad and Tobago, that's ridiculous! Make a credible list and foresee sanctions. On this too, the Member States are holding back. Furthermore, those who are smart must pay. Competent authorities must suspend or revoke the banking licenses of financial institutions and financial advisors who help organize fraud. Behind all these scandals there are always the usual suspects, the usual consultants, the usual banks. On these commitments we challenge the Council. As often happens, Parliament is ready, but the Council must lend its hand to give a credible response to the citizens. If we don't do this, we waste that margin of confidence we still have in ours citizens.

name: Bernd Lucke
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! We are dealing with another major leak, the fourth such leak in just two years. We had the Luxembourg Leaks, we had the Panama Papers, we had the Bahamas Papers, and now the Paradise Papers are coming. Every time such a scandal arises - and slowly one desensitizes oneself to the word “scandal”, slowly one no longer perceives it to be so scandalous because one such leak comes after the other - it says: Well, it it may well be that it was all legal. We must not turn a blind eye to it. If all of this were so legal, the people who do it would hardly be allowed to do it on any Caribbean island. Then hardly anything would happen somewhere in the dark. We have to be very clear: Even if it is technically legal, then it was against the meaning of the law because this kind of secrecy was practiced. And it's not just that the things are perhaps formally legal, but it goes beyond the area of ​​aggressive tax avoidance into the area of ​​tax evasion, money laundering, corruption, terrorist financing, and it works, as we have seen have even entered the realm of targeted political murder. In Malta, for example, where whistleblowers who have disclosed something have to die for such things. Now we have to state once: We have seen the tip of the iceberg here several times - so it was said. We saw it at the Luxembourg Leaks - exposed by journalists. We saw it in the Panama Papers - exposed by journalists. We saw it in the Bahamas Papers - exposed by journalists. We have now seen it at the Paradise Papers - exposed by journalists. And then you have to ask the question: Why is something like that is constantly uncovered by journalists, and what is the tax investigation of our countries actually doing?Don't our Member States have better investigative opportunities than journalists?Why is something like this not finally discovered by the responsible authorities?Why are millions of pages of documents constantly coming to light through journalists, but not through the administrations of our Member States, which are actually responsible for them?Commissioner Moscovici,What you said is certainly all correct - transparency and information sharing and blacklists - but we need to make sure that tax criminals are caught!That is the essential goal to be achieved.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the Paradise Papers revelations show once again the urgent need for Europe to intensify its fight against tax evasion and money laundering. I would like to thank the journalists again for their work.  The names of the leaks may change, but the mechanisms revealed remain the same: anonymous companies or trusts set up and maintained by intermediaries in tax havens, low or zero transparency and low or zero taxes, and the rich and famous involved, including the Queen, whose finances are internally and externally audited. I hope this new leak has opened the eyes of those Member States who had not comprehended the magnitude of the problem. There is a good opportunity for them to prove that, as this afternoon we will conduct a crucial trilogue negotiation on the revision of the Anti—Money Laundering Directive. After more than a year’s work, a month ago the European Parliament’s Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA) adopted its report and recommendations, which will be voted on in plenary in December. The Committee calls on the European Union and its Member States to properly implement and reinforce its legal tools, to shift from secrecy to transparency, mutual cooperation and exchange of information. It urges both the Commission and the Member States to step up their efforts, commitments, cooperation and investment in financial and human resources, to improve supervision and enforcement. It counts on the leading role of the Commission in setting up criteria for a common EU list of non—cooperative tax jurisdictions, and calls on the Council not to dilute, but rather to increase, the ambition of the criteria of the said list. It calls for more efficient sanctions against banks and intermediaries that are knowingly involved in illegal tax or money laundering schemes. There are more than 200 recommendations adopted by the Committee. The way to prevent money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion is charted, and a lot has already been done, but still more needs to be done in the area of adoption, implementation and enforcement of legislation.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, once again, a new massive leak of documents on tax evasion and avoidance, this time called 'papers from paradise'. It is not a temporary issue, ladies and gentlemen. It is a structural issue and we have to treat it as such. Once again we found out about this new leak through the work of journalists and the work of the leakers. Filters or journalists like Daphne Caruana, who died precisely for doing her job. How long are we going to have to wait to truly have legislation that protects whistleblowers within the European Union? Once again the fundamental role of facilitators is confirmed. Facilitators of tax evasion and avoidance: banks. Yes, ladies and gentlemen, banks. Until when are we going to allow dissuasive sanctions such as the withdrawal of the banking or professional license not to be applied? Without these enablers, tax evasion and avoidance would not be possible. Once again, politicians involved. Those who have to legislate against tax evasion are often the first evaders. When will we take action to end the obscene revolving doors and collusion between evaders and public representatives? Once again, tax hideouts. Until when are we going to allow tax havens to continue to exist within the European Union? Even when? How can we believe in the Council when we have tax havens within the Council itself? Look, at the next plenary session in Strasbourg we have the possibility to vote on the recommendations of the inquiry commission regarding the Panama papers. We have the opportunity to send a message: either with the evaders or against the evaders. You see, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, 2008 the UBS scandal, 2013 “Offshore Leaks”, 2014 “Lux Leaks”, 2015 “Swiss Leaks”, “Football Leaks”, it's the HSBC scandal, 2016 the “Panama Papers” and the “Bahamas” Leaks ”, 2017 the“ Malta files ”and now the“ Paradise Papers ”. You counted well, ladies and gentlemen, with these ten scandals, of which the vast majority of our fellow citizens are the victims, their loyalty cards are full. What will they gain in the eleventh, can they finally hope for fair taxation? Assuming that nothing here is illegal, which we can doubt, is it legitimate? Because one thing is certain, fiscal injustice is not the product of a natural phenomenon, it is on the contrary the result of deliberate political choices. It is not without their knowledge that for 30 years, the elected political majorities in Europe have made our taxes less and less progressive and have competed in creativity to create the loopholes in which the profiteers of the system are engulfed. But why, why, even today, those who govern us, like here in France, Emmanuel Macron, continue to pass tax laws that benefit the richest? Of course, there is in some the will to lick the hand that feeds them, or perhaps will feed them one day. But above all, there is this sham that making the rich richer, and protecting mega-corporations, benefits everyone. In reality, all of this only reinforces their capacity to extract rent from our societies and the planet. This is why the tax administrations have been reduced to a dry regime, which is why the accounting transparency of multinationals and that of the beneficiaries of trusts, foundations and shell companies is still not the rule. This is why the harmonization of corporate tax is not moving forward, it is because of this that tax havens continue to flourish, including within The union.And all this because of who?Finance ministers who only agree to act under pressure and on condition that the fundamentals of the system are not called into question.I would like to warn them here, because tax evasion does not only increase inequalities and undermine our public services, it seriously undermines our democracies, because the trust on which our society is based is crumblingevery day more, because of your refusal to act.Sooner or later it will be shattered, unless of course, and I conclude, Madam President, that you find the courage, Finance Ministers, to let go of your toxic beliefs.This is what the overwhelming majority of our citizens are asking you.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, as Mr Moscovici said at the start of this, the leak of all these papers and lists of people with offshore holdings has come about because of the Society of Investigative Journalists, but what has not been said this morning, and I think is relevant, is that the funding of these investigations came from one George Soros.  (Interjection from Mr Lamberts: ‘So what?’) Now I say this at a time – I am going to come back to ‘so what?’ and it may have some personal interest for you as well – when the use of money and the influence it may have had on the Brexit result, or the Trump election, has reached a level of virtual hysteria. Just last week the Electoral Commission in the UK launched an investigation to find out whether the Leave campaign took offshore money or Russian money. This came about as a result of questions asked in the House of Commons by one Ben Bradshaw, somebody linked to an organisation called Open Society.  I just wonder when we are talking about offshore money, when we are talking about political subversion, when we are talking about collusion, I wonder whether we are looking in the wrong place. And I say that because George Soros recently gave Open Society – his organisation, which of course campaigns for free movement of peoples and supports supranational structures like the European Union – USD 18 billion. And his influence here and in Brussels is truly extraordinary. Open Society boasts that they had 42 meetings last year with the Commission. They have even published a book of reliable friends in the European Parliament and there are 226 names on that list, including yours, Sir. I thought you would find this interesting.  We even had last week Mr Verhofstadt lobbying on behalf of Mr Soros at the Conference of Presidents in a battle that is going on with Viktor Orbán, the Prime Minister of Hungary.  If we are going to have a debate and we are going to talk about full, political and financial transparency, well let’s do it. So I shall be writing today to all 226 of you asking some pretty fair questions: ‘Have you ever received funds, directly or indirectly, from Open Society?’ ‘How many of their events have you attended?’ ‘Could you please give us a list of the meetings of all the representatives, including George Soros, yourself.’ And I think this Parliament should now set up a special committee to look into all of this. I say that because I fear we could be looking at the biggest level of international political collusion in history. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- You're off topic.This is about the Paradise Papers, namely that companies should pay taxes.Are you in favor of allowing such tax avoidance constructs in the British Virgin Islands and other tax havens, yes or no?

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – If you are going to completely ban people from putting money, which in many cases could be utterly legitimate investments, be it in the British Virgin Islands or the Bahamas or anywhere else, if you are going to do that then please be consistent. Make sure that you ban the sale of duty-free cigarettes and make sure that you stop anyone using their personal allowances to avoid tax when it comes to investments.  By the way, while you are at it, what about the 25 000 people who work for the European Commission and the European Parliament and pay a maximum tax rate of 16%? It is time, perhaps, to put your own House in order.

name: Barbara Kappel
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, Minister, Commissioner! The Paradise Papers again show what tax avoidance strategies of prominent politicians and multinationals look like, and this time there are very prominent names on the list, from US Minister Wilbur Ross to the Canadian Prime Minister to Queen Elizabeth II or the U2 front man Bono, but also corporations like Apple and Nike. I would like to refer to a Scandinavian study on the subject of tax avoidance and tax inequality based on an HSBC dataset from the Swiss Leaks, which says that recipients of very large capital incomes engage in tax evasion when the risk of discovery is as low as possible, and that even applies to countries with a high level of social cohesion and high legal compliance as in Scandinavia. Corporations, on the other hand, do not evade taxes, they optimize their assessment by means of license fees, trademark rights, patent boxes or internal transfer prices - all completely legal - with the aim of minimizing the tax burden. And the EU has responded with two pillars, namely with two areas of action: increasing transparency and closing tax loopholes. Great progress has been made in both areas over the past year and a half; more than a hundred states have committed to sharing information on financial accounts. There is country-specific reporting, there is a catalog of measures against tax avoidance, and there is the OECD's BEPS action plan. But that's not all: there will also be a list of beneficial owners in foundations, a black list of non-cooperative tax areas, sanctions for intermediaries and a stronger exchange of information between the member states. In the wake of Swiss Leaks, Lux Leaks, Panama Papers and Paradise Papers, many measures have been taken to combat tax avoidance, reduce inequality and to increase tax equity.And these measures are already working in the EU, because with the exception of the British, no Europeans were found in the Paradise Papers.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Madam President, Panama papers, LuxLeaks, Paradise Papers and who knows how many more leaks will occur in the future? What does it matter? After each time we have an extraordinary debate in plenary, we will condemn in general and vaguely and in the end nothing will be done at all. And how can this be done, since many companies and politicians across Europe are taking advantage of the various loopholes in the law to transfer their money to an overseas company, in the most unlikely parts of the world, and to avoid taxation legally? Unlike the ordinary citizen, who groans under taxes that in some cases, such as in Greece, exceed 50%. In Greece, where -by the way- the wife of the official opposition leader appears in these leaks, but he evangelizes the cleansing. Of course, here in Europe this role is taken over by Mr Juncker, whose works are well known when he was Prime Minister of Luxembourg. Eventually the legislation will not change and these ghost companies will continue to operate, because that is how it suits most politicians, who legislate themselves, and the large capital that helps them in their work.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: - Madam President! The latest publications show that tax avoidance, tax evasion, tax fraud and money laundering are still on the agenda. I don't want to talk about the personal responsibility of tax evaders who are free riders in a solidary society. I would like to put the business models of those countries to the test that pose as tax havens and consciously seek to undermine international tax sharing. There are enough examples in the European Union: Whether the Netherlands, Malta, Luxembourg - they all belong in the test and not just third countries! That is why we are calling for a paradigm shift. So far, double taxation agreements have always been concluded. We demand minimum taxation agreements! Even if progress has been made, Commissioner, progress has been very, very modest. So we need to discuss the basics. I always hear that: tax competition is healthy. The question of fair tax sharing and the acceptance of minimum tax rules is not a departure from healthy tax competition, but the necessary basis in times of globalization and new powerful corporations in the digital age. That is why the responsibility of the Member States is not only to improve cooperation between the authorities, to introduce reporting requirements and to draw up a black list of non-cooperative third countries, but we have to ensure order within the European Union ourselves. That is why the European Parliament decided on its measures. It is not enough to say: it is the others who do it, we have to start. In the long run we cannot accept that international corporations and wealthy people evade their solidarity tax obligations and that the states have no choice but to tax labor and consumption more heavily. That is the shared responsibility that we face and I ask everyone for their support.

name: Udo Bullmann (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! No, we shouldn't be surprised anymore. After all the scandals, we should at best still be amazed at those who do. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you are a diplomat. They say, much of what we are now learning about Paradise Papers may have been legal. But they cannot rule out that one or the other would also have contributed to tax avoidance. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, that is too diplomatic. This diplomatic language is not part of the solution, it is part of the problem. We must clearly recognize that these constructs were created to avoid taxes. That is the only reason why they exist there that we can track down, who in fact - as the House agrees - cheat on the people who pay decent taxes. That's why we have to get down to business a little harder. It is not enough to just mention that tax fraud and tax avoidance may be on the table. No, we have to smash this silent cartel. It is a silent cartel of the companies that are benefiting from it. It is a silent cartel of the super-rich who evade taxes. But it is also a silent cartel of the financial bureaucracies that we have to put an end to for good. Mr Moscovici, you have the support of the whole House. There is an urgent need to ensure that the fight against tax avoidance becomes a Europe-wide, global one. Only that creates justice.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - The system of tax havens could not reach such a size if it were not at least tacitly approved by politicians, including European politicians. After all, you do not earn money in paradises only in paradise. Someone had to organize all these structures, supervise the flow of money, and someone had to make sure that the whole thing was "legal". Such people do not sit on Bermuda's beaches, but rather in European capitals. Also in Brussels. Let us recall LuxLeaks and the case of the famous Steelie Neelie - European Union Commissioner. The problem of tax havens can only be solved at the global level, so an agreement is needed on this at this level and not just within Europe. For paying taxes cannot be an obligation from which there is immunity for the richest and global corporations. I would also like to point out that my country, Poland, has been the European leader in reducing the VAT gap for two years, and also one of the first countries to regularly raise the problem of tax havens at meetings of EU finance ministers.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Mr. Moscovici defines it well: systematic global practices and organized in an organized circuit. And he says that citizens would not understand our passivity. We are too lenient; is that they no longer understand it. With each new scandal we meet new names. The ideology does not matter. We have from the left, from the right, from one country, from another ... Now a president of the Barcelona Football Club has joined us; a Catalan secessionist, the former mayor of Barcelona ... It doesn't matter: all the world's elites, criminal networks are in this business. And we only have a small part of the puzzle, and the problem, the uncomfortable question is that Member States, obsessed with their powers, cannot cope with a globalized evasion in a globalized world from a financial and economic point of view. Therefore, Mr Moscovici, we are pouring water into the sea. If we don't change the paradigm, it won't work. And we cannot be lenient. And, furthermore, you in the Commission do not have the resources to see if the rules are implemented well or not. The problem is that crime is globalized and states cannot act alone. And this is the terrible and miserable reality.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, I fully support this Parliament forming a new committee to examine revelations in the Paradise Papers. Issues of corporate tax avoidance and evasion are now so prevalent that we need a permanent committee for investigations. It is also time for the UN to convene a global summit in response to this latest leak in order to deal decisively and at a global level with financial secrecy.  The Paradise Papers revealed that the world’s richest corporation, Apple, went shopping for a new offshore jurisdiction after the role its Irish subsidiaries were playing in tax avoidance was exposed. The Apple leak shows that Apple settled on Jersey, but it also highlights the role that the Irish Government played in helping Apple set up its new tax avoidance structure. In 2014, the Irish Government claimed it was abolishing the notorious ‘double Irish’ but not only did they provide an absurdly long phase-out period, they also created a grace period that allowed new companies to be established which could then use the double Irish until 2020. The Paradise Papers show Apple took full advantage of this move to set up the ‘double Irish’ structure in Jersey. How many more billions in profit will this scheme allow Apple to avoid paying in tax over this period? Apple has repeatedly shown its contempt for ordinary taxpayers by using every trick in the book to avoid paying its fair share of tax, and yet this is the company that the Irish Government is desperately trying to avoid collecting unpaid taxes from. If we in Ireland are to garner any credibility on these matters, then our government needs to stop wasting millions of our money on its appeal and act now to collect the taxes that the Irish people are owed.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! While we are discussing here, we are discussing on the day on which we actually wanted to adopt the reform of the money laundering directive in the final trialogue. This was initiated by the Commission a year ago with the Panama Papers. Parliament is in a strong position to draw conclusions from the Panama Papers. What is happening today The Council, the Council Presidency, has not even been given a mandate to reach a bad compromise with Parliament today, let alone to draw serious conclusions. Today's trialogue will fail - just like many other proposals by Mr Moscovici are currently on hold - because the Council and key Member States are unwilling to take serious steps against tax avoidance and money laundering. The question is therefore: when will you change this line in the Council? When do the Member States change this line? And for us here in Parliament the question is: when do we stop complaining about it, but are ready to use our resources to force the Council and the Member States to finally end this blockade against tax justice? This is how we can measure whether we are serious here in Parliament. Dear Colleagues! We Greens are ready, together with you, to take serious action against the Council and the Member States here - in the interests of Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Giegold, in the UK jurisdiction, company directors have a duty to minimise taxation for the benefit of their shareholders. It is their duty. No one in their right mind wants to pay more tax than is correctly demanded, especially since governments, especially the European Union, squander taxpayers’ hard-earned money. The question is: do you agree with me, Mr Giegold, that governments squander money? (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – The key question here, Mr Coburn, is the following: the UK and its related offshore territories are offering their sovereignty to the dirty money of the world with zero tax rates. Now, in the proceedings of Brexit, we have the chance to tell the UK very clearly: if you want to get good business with us, you must change this stealing of taxpayers’ money, which has been going on so far and which your Government was able to protect inside the EU. In the future this deep dirty business will be over, Mr Coburn.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, once again an incredible tax scandal, where it turns out that, in a totally legal way, more than 100 multinationals, 120 politicians, managers and celebrities have not paid their taxes, while we are in situations , in our European Union countries, where ordinary citizens and businesses are continually crushed by an incredible tax burden. This is a sense of injustice that citizens feel and what they perceive is that politics fails to react precisely because it is colluding, precisely because the most influential people in the world are involved. I wonder, as much as I respect Commissioner Moscovici and the work he is doing, where the hell is President Juncker, the person who led the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg for twenty years and who made tax avoidance a way to enrich his own country. Where the hell is he? Because today he represents the institution of the European Commission and he should put his face on these issues. I have been to Luxembourg: they have a lot of beautiful companies with lots of intercoms, lots of PO boxes and very few people who work in them. What does this mean? Which is a system within the European Union, in a founding country, which very often gives moral to us countries of the South on the reforms to be applied, which does not apply the most important reform it should do, which is to eliminate this system disgusting of tax avoidance, because it deals with interests of trillions and all are involved, I repeat, politicians, big companies, managers and celebrities. Let us bring justice back from the founding countries of the European Union.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, since the end of national borders and in the absence of serious regulations, the federalist and ultraliberal European Union has been directly responsible for the tax evasion of multinationals. Whether it is VAT evasion or aggressive tax optimization of corporate taxes, the fiscal damage to states is immense. The cost for France has been over 80 billion euros per year for two decades. Due to the active complicity of certain Member States, large American digital companies, such as Apple, legally manage to pay an effective tax on their European profits which is close to zero. Profits made throughout the European Union are in fact reallocated to parent companies, notably in Ireland and Luxembourg, where they are subject to insignificant taxation before their final departure for tax havens. These practices of fiscal vagrancy must be made impossible and illegal. Unfortunately, the envisaged anti-tax avoidance reforms are blocked by these same Member States which are draining the public finances of their partners. The effective political solution is therefore for France and the other states victims of tax evasion to urgently conclude an intergovernmental agreement. It will be about forcing the uncooperative member states to accept that the tax base of multinationals is reallocated, country by country, to where business and profits are really created. Let’s stop this fiscal drain, Mr. Moscovici. Our citizens demand it.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – Madam President, can I say that European Union hypocrisy is alive and kicking? Mr Moscovici, you made a comment, which is that you can count on the Parliament. Can I remind you that when this Parliament had before it a vote to effectively sanction Mr Juncker and ask him to stand aside due to his alleged links with LuxLeaks, that was declined and voted against. So this Parliament cannot be counted on and you should not even state that.  A far bigger scandal that nobody has yet addressed is the issue of the big German and French corporates who own, for instance, UK water, energy, waste collection companies, and they make full use all of the so-called tax avoidance and tax evasion mechanisms which this Chamber and this Parliament finds so unacceptable. Can I suggest that your investigation widens and includes the big German and French corporates?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: –Madam President, we have not yet completely finished our work in the Committee of Inquiry into Money laundering, tax avoidance and tax evasion (PANA) and yet we have another scandal surfacing. This gives an idea of the scope and extent of tax evasion and tax avoidance by big multinational companies and wealthy individuals. One could say  "déjà vu, déjà entendu" Most of the cases uncovered in the Paradise Papers seem to be legal from a purely legalistic point of view, although they are not in accordance with the spirit of law. But what does ‘legal’ mean? Is it legal for Apple, a company, simply not to pay a single euro of taxes on 120-something billion US dollars when small and medium-sized companies in Europe have to pay 20% or 30% in corporate tax every year? How come it is possible that this is legal? If this is legal then the law is imperfect and the laws have to be changed. Apart from that, we have to remember that these practices are unfair and deeply immoral. They undermine the trust and confidence of our citizens in state institutions. This has to stop. Commissioner Moscovici, I very much welcome your promises and your proposals that by the end of the year you will come up with a blacklist of countries that are not cooperative jurisdictions. This is very important and this list also has to include the British dependent territories that provide a nice place for money to be hidden from taxation. Moreover, not only is the list necessary, but so are the sanctions on all those territories that do not cooperate with us and will still continue these practices. I thank the journalists for uncovering this scandal, but the main task is for tax authorities, and we have called on the Member States to increase efforts to finish and stop these unlawful practices.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue—card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: Question "blue card".- Madam President, I have listened carefully to our colleague Rosati, and I mean that in terms of legality I fully agree with what he said.I'm just wondering why, in the framework of the "Panama Papers" committee, he and his group did not support a whole series of amendments that would have made all these things illegal?Why, in the context of our colleague Rozière's dossier on the protection of whistleblowers, he and his group, the EPP, have tabled a whole series of amendments which do not protect journalists?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr Bayet, we have supported all the amendments and all the provisions that, in our opinion, will lead to an improvement in the whole situation. We are against tax evasion, we are against money laundering, and we are in favour of solutions that will make the whole system more efficient and more effective. However, not all the amendments submitted by you go in the same direction. That is why we have not agreed on everything but, on balance, we are in favour of a much stronger fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering.

name: Peter Simon (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The discussion this morning - like the work in the TAXE-1 and TAXE-2 special investigation committees, as in the Panama Papers committee of inquiry - has shown that tax havens do not only exist outside the borders of the European Union, but also within. And individual states in this union have made it their business model to steal taxes from other states. That leads to precisely the problem that was described this morning, namely that the Member States are not making the right progress themselves, and that there is no will to take decisive action against tax avoidance and money laundering. That is why it is our task as Parliament to set the opposite pole here, to take up the fight against tax avoidance and money laundering together with the European Commission. We have shown that our pressure here in this House can make a difference, get Member States to act. That is why the consequence of the Paradise Papers for our work must be: now all the more! If we really want to drive tax evaders out of the tax haven, then we must now, together with the European Commission, drive the Member States before us - across party lines - and show that this Parliament is serious about the fight against tax avoidance and money laundering.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR).
text: - (FI) Mr President, in the work of the PANA committee of inquiry, we have often pointed out how Mossack Fonseca is, after all, only one player in the market for tax havens, and not even the largest.The papers of Paradise and the leaked information from Appleby Law Office are an excellent reminder of this.At the same time, the information leak underscores the importance of now continuing the work begun at PANA to close the loopholes.The difficulties encountered by PANA in obtaining information further underline that this cannot be left to the Commission, the Council and the Member States alone.It is now of the utmost importance to further promote open owner registers, the clearing of loopholes in the automatic exchange of tax information and open country-by-country tax reporting.In addition, by loading the papers of paradise, you will surely find new loopholes waiting to be tickled.

name: Morten Løkkegaard (ALDE).
text: - Madam President! Yes, it is a depressing picture that emerges in these times, not only of greedy wealthy people with tax addresses on exotic island states, but also of multinational giants evading their responsibility in terms of tax payment, and even European countries competing with each other in a destructive circle. Of course it's not okay! We must not accept that. I would like to appeal to the fact that one thinks that there are no easy solutions to this problem, even though one could get that impression from the debate, because it is largely governed by indignation and anger. The solution is therefore not that we set the tax rates here in the EU system. It is up to the individual Member States to achieve this: how to safeguard the interests of its own citizens and how much tax collection it requires. But something must of course be done, and here it is good to have these tax havens blacklisted, to have a naming and shaming principle that exposes countries with morally failed tax conditions. This list must of course be used actively! It must be crucial for whether a country, for example. must have EU funding. It must have the consequence of undermining the EU member states, also for the member states themselves. This morass needs to be cleaned up, and for that we support the plans that are.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Much has been said about yet another fiscal scandal: many data, many regrets, many promises, in a speech that is repeated, scandal after scandal. For us, this episode of “Paradise Papers” confirms the systemic nature of tax evasion, as we have always denounced, and it also confirms the total ineffectiveness of the European Union institutions in fighting this tragedy. I hear many of you speak out against governments, omitting that these governments represent the parties that are represented here and that, of course, they criticize what is rightly criticized. And I ask, but after all, what are the interests that are protected by these governments and these parties that also represent the majority here? How then can we explain that tax havens, which are political economic dwarves, can impose their law on the strongest countries? Because this is the fundamental contradiction, a contradiction that arises from the neoliberal policy imposed on us by the European Union and that leads public authorities to be mere representatives of the financial interests of the European Union and the world.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, "Panama Papers" yesterday, "Paradise Papers" today. How many millions of documents will it take for governments to take stock of the issue? How many billions of euros will we allow to be diverted from our public finances, our schools and our hospitals? Repeated scandals demand a political reaction. The responsibility of the Member States is to adopt a credible European list of tax havens. It would be unbearable to see only a few countries appearing there when the "Paradise Papers" shed light on a system of tax evasion involving too many countries, including within our Union. Above all, this list must be accompanied by effective sanctions denouncing the tax agreements concluded with each country appearing on this list. The effect would be formidable. We could finally tax the profits that go on tax holidays. We are not doomed to have our public finances stolen forever. We know the solutions to fight tax evasion. Only courage is lacking.

name: Patrick O'Flynn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, hard-pressed citizens across Europe are rightly enraged that a wealthy global elite pays so little tax, when they pay so much. Today we are debating the Paradise Papers, three years ago it was the LuxLeaks. I am afraid the EU’s record on this issue is shameful.  Remember, it was an EU directive in the 1980s that let multinational companies pay tax in any European headquarters country rather than where their revenues and profits were really made. Remember, tougher action has been taken against the LuxLeaks whistle-blowers, than against the accountants, corporate executives or politicians involved. Remember that the Commission’s own President, Mr Juncker, was Prime Minister of Luxembourg when his country was conniving with big accountancy firms to erode the tax bases of larger EU economies. In the EU, larger member countries will always be vulnerable to smaller ones acting as tax havens. British voters will surely think, yet again: thank goodness we are leaving.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF).
text: - (IT) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, scandals over tax evasion and illegal activities are exploding continuously, which, as regards Italy, have even emerged that also involve elements linked to the mafia. And you would like us to believe that this European Commission, chaired by Mr Junker, would like to fight against the tax havens of which, at least for Luxembourg, Mr Juncker is, I would say, an established protector. You are not credible because his proposals, dear Mr. Moscovici, are crap. You don't propose anything incisive in the fight against tax havens. For example, it does not propose to prohibit, in the territory of the European Union, the activity of those companies that by now these scandals have made well known all over the world, whose company name is exclusively to advise tax evaders on where to go to deposit the their current accounts in tax havens. This measure is simple, it doesn't take science to take it. If you do not want to protect tax evasion and the activity of tax havens, start with measures such as imposing bilateral agreements requiring Member States to answer to tax and judicial authorities who ask for news. This is not the case in many countries of the European Union, and you, Mr Moscovici, know it very well.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Madam President, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, now Paradise Papers, offshore tax havens, shaky business names, and many more revelations in the future, depending on the competing interests of both the revealer and the revealer. Why do you pretend to be upset? You are pretending. Are you here, the European Union and governments, not legislating by offering them everything for investment and profits, pensions and starvation wages, labor scams? Illegal transactions are crumbs in front of the legal capital exemptions, which are derived from the savage taxation of the people. Don't the funds you sell loans to nest in tax havens? After allegedly denouncing them, do you not invite them to return as investors with new tax exemptions? The hypocrisy of the parties about who is involved and who reveals does not hide that the billions were born from the social exploitation that everyone serves. The tears of the extreme right, conservatives, social democrats and supposedly neo-left, SYRIZA style, are hypocrisy. There is no fair development in an unjust system and moral capitalism. It is and will be a paradise for the few and a scam for the many.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Actually, everything that we can read in the Paradise Papers now seems like a déjà vu: tricky tax-saving models, letterbox companies, dodgy law firms that specialize in legal, semi-legal and also illegal tax practices. We have known all of this for a long time. We have had two special committees, one committee of inquiry and the practices are well known. We'll have more leaks because other law firms will be hacked at one point or another. Of course, it's not particularly surprising that Appleby is particularly affected by the UK overseas territories. That results from the clientele that is also represented by this law firm. The point now is not to wait for the next data leak, but to finally act. We know the mechanisms, and therefore, Commissioner, I do hope that we will get the blacklist for tax havens and money laundering strongholds so that we can finally work on this. But I would also like to encourage us to deal with the issue of tax loopholes within the European Union. It cannot be that unfair tax competition takes place between member states within the European Union. I can only encourage the Member States to take up and implement a large number of proposals that we have now also drawn up in the Panama Committee of Inquiry. It cannot be the case that tax breaks are granted here that are at the expense of other Member States. I am saying very clearly: if you want to point your finger at other countries, you have to have your own house tidy. Otherwise he is unbelievable. That is why, Commissioner, I also expect appropriate proposals to be made here so that we can finally solve our internal problems in the European Union and don't always point the finger at other jurisdictions outside the European Union.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, you told us that this is a new scandal but, indeed, is it really a surprise? There are a number of us here who think that it is pointless to cry out loud. There is a complicity of the Member States and, Mr President of the Council, the responsibility on your shoulders is immense. The citizens are tired of discovering new lists, new papers day after day. The paper they want to see is the one you will have to adopt on December 5, namely the list of tax havens, as the European Union must consider them. Let's face it: Are everyone here aware that the list that is currently in force is that of the OECD? On this list, among the 19 countries and territories covered by the "Paradise Papers", only one is considered a tax haven, five are "largely compliant" and one "partially compliant"? There are obviously holes… When I observe that 22 countries have already been considered “probably without risk” and that among these countries is the United States, while the State of Delaware is clearly a tax haven, I think that we must be brave. This is what citizens expect from us. Mr President of the Council, the responsibility of the Member States to stop shooting themselves in the foot is immense.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Madam President! When I think about the fact that I've already paid more taxes on this cup of tea than an international sports company on its entire turnover, then I cook. And this is not an isolated case: From the Queen to Facebook, from George Soros to Uber, from Shakira to eBay - they are all mentioned in the Paradise Papers. The EU escapes over EUR 60 billion annually, around a fifth of all corporate taxes. That can not be true! Unlike the Panama Papers, almost everything is completely legal with the Paradise Papers. Legal tax tricks? That's enough! How long do governments want to wait and tolerate such nasty cross-border tricks by corporations and super-rich at the expense of medium-sized businesses and good taxpayers? My appeal: let's not talk about paradise, the tunnel of tax evasion is already beginning in Malta, Holland, Ireland and the small Isle of Man. It is up to politics to dry up tax swamps and create real tax justice. Now, not just for the next teatime.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: - Minister, Commissioner, tax evasion is a crime, whatever the means used to achieve this result. So criminal are the conduct of those who, in order to gain illegal advantages, use the ways that the law has prohibited, as well as those of those who, in order to achieve the same result, use different paths than the law had foreseen and prohibited. Tax evasion is also morally repugnant, not only because States are deprived of relevant means to carry out their social functions, but above all because such practice is carried out by very profitable companies and by very wealthy people, some of whom are even presented as models of public virtues, as the “Paradise Papers” now reveal. Let us be clear, Minister, Commissioner: so that these debates do not become mere routine and meaningless theatricalizations, the EU must quickly establish a system of sanctions to be applied to countries whose financial systems are complicit in evading taxes. Anyone who helps someone to eat a crime should not go unpunished.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, we have a provocative tax evasion of the global elite at the expense of 99.99% of the society of consistent taxpayers, the revenues of the Member States and the welfare state. And I ask the question: why do some journalists, whom we have to protect by strengthening the protection of complainants, find more information from the Council, Mr Maasikas, from the Commission, Mr Moscovici, from the Member States? How long will we stay in words and wishes? Mr Moscovici, after the Panama Papers you put forward some - in my opinion insufficient - proposals, which were blocked in the Council and nothing was done, because the governments of Germany and the Netherlands, along with others, blocked them as well. So we have to go into action. A fair tax system, Mr Moscovici, means that profits are taxed where they are generated, and not at zero rates in tax havens. Black list for tax havens; tomorrow, in early December, tax harmonization and international cooperation and severe sanctions. Finally, we are tired of the words, we want a result.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, another day, another leak of embarrassing documents about the role of the City of London as the global centre for tax avoidance. Successive British Governments have postured about leading on transparency but it is easy to play the good guy when you have so many post-colonial territories to do the dirty work at your bidding. The Paradise Papers also reveal the link between leading Brexiteers, including Tory donor Lord Ashcroft and Jacob Rees-Mogg, and these palm-fringed islands with their thousands of secret trusts and letterbox companies.  Avoiding civilized rules on tax was always part of the Brexit agenda but any attempt to turn Britain into the Bermuda of the North is likely to flounder since the EU will surely make cleaning up the overseas territories a condition for any future trade deal. So, I am hopeful that UK citizens may continue to benefit from green changes to EU laws on tax, including the abolition of the sort of blind trust that was Appleby’s speciality, as well as country-by-country reporting by corporations.

name: Marco Zanni (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Paradise Papers show once again what the very essence of the European Union is. This is the home of dumping, of wage dumping done through the single currency, of fiscal dumping done through these policies of some Member States which also express high level representatives within the European Union. It is the home of all against all, mors tua vita mea and "beggar-thy-neighbor" policies. The solution cannot be the European Union, because the European Union is the problem. There is no courage in addressing these issues, Member States continue to live and gain weight by doing harm to others and there is no solidarity. I would like to see if the European Union will be able to include countries like Juncker's Luxembourg, Dijsselbloem's Holland, like Ireland and like other countries, like the United States, which are in fact of tax havens. It takes more courage. The solution cannot be the EU.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: - Madam President, from the "LuxLeaks" to the "Paradise Papers", the scandals which have moved public opinion have shown that we now have two duties within the European family. First, a moral duty: put an end once and for all to the practices by which certain family members have stolen the tax potential of their neighbors. Attracting talent or investors with low, publicly displayed and charged rates is normal tax competition. On the other hand, to authorize, encourage, facilitate and ultimately organize arrangements which de facto eliminate all taxes is an outrage, an outrage against equality between taxpayers within the same country and an outrage against European solidarity. It is our common founding values ​​that are being flouted. Next, we have an economic duty, we offer our businesses a unique commercial, regulatory and monetary space. We are finishing building, Commissioner, the single banking and financial area, we also owe them a European fiscal area. It is time to break down the barriers that fragment the large market into 28 different tax areas. SMEs are the first victims. The AXIS project, presented by the Commission, is the common response to these two duties. Parliament proposes to enrich it, by laying the foundations for taxing digital platforms. For once, the Union is ahead of the OECD and the US Congress. We have the rare opportunity to be the pioneers and therefore the first world reference for the implementation of a major policy adapted to the needs of the 21st century.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the Paradise Papers, the Panama Papers, LuxLeaks and so on are not just scandals: they are the melting ice cap of our economic system. They are the financial climate change that threatens to drown Europe’s welfare states and fundamental fairness in our societies, and we must not and cannot allow this to go on in secret. The Paradise Papers have exposed a corrupt global elite of companies and individuals who, through tax havens, write their own tax laws, their own tax rates, as a result of a sick and greedy form of capitalism that has been allowed to run amok. It forces countries into a never-ending race to the bottom on tax rates and, sadly, we know that some Member State governments contribute to this by stalling and diluting new anti—tax evasion initiatives. They do so because the Council and the Code of Conduct Group operates on the principle of unanimity and also confidentiality. This secrecy allows the global elite to deposit their fortunes in tax havens and leaves ordinary citizens to pay the bill.  This must change. We urgently need reform of the Council and its secretive way of working on this issue. The people of Europe need to see transparency, and we in the S&D Group also call for a full public investigation into this new scandal. We urge all other groups to join us in a special committee to look into the Paradise Papers and put the spotlight on what is going on.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Offshore Leaks, Lux Leaks, Swiss Leaks, Panama Papers and now Paradise Papers: this is just a tip of the iceberg.From scandal to scandal, it is now the turn of around 120 politicians and world leaders.Those who demand more austerity and more sacrifices for the poor are the same ones who are draining the coffers of the State with their fiscal escapes.How long will we continue to argue that these agreements, which benefit 0.1% of the wealthiest, are legal when they call into question one of the most basic structures of democracy, which is tax justice?Everything is documented.The European Union has the data and conclusions on tax evasion, but we remain from a special commission to a special commission and even today the only convicts were those who provided a public service and denounced the scandalous situations.In fact, what we really lack is a special commission on “shameless papers”.

name: Judith Sargentini (Verts/ALE).
text: - As rapporteur for the anti-money laundering law, I have bad news.The eighth round of negotiations with the Member States is taking place this afternoon and it should have been the last round, but it is not.The Paradise Papers again show that corporations, criminals and extremely wealthy people use all kinds of constructs to remain unseen for our tax authorities.We can do something about this by letting sunlight shine in all dark corners.We want the owners of companies and trusts to be found in public records, but the Member States do not want to negotiate with us.They have no mandate for this afternoon.I can only conclude that there are several capitals that are happy with those dark corners and like to keep things as is, and that's a shame.For LuxLeaks, PanamaLeaks, Paradise Papers and we do nothing.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: - Madam President, the European Union must repudiate all tax havens that exist to launder money, hide illicit profits, assist in the proceeds of crimes. You must repudiate them inside and out, without any doubt or state of mind. A black list, a real black list, is essential. It means a black list that is exhaustive and not a black list that is minimalist. To condemn in speeches what is allowed in practice is simply hypocrisy. Even so, it should be stressed that tax havens are something different from more favorable tax regimes, which exist, well, to help the most disadvantaged regions, from the outset, which do not have the same instruments capable of generating revenue, wealth and jobs that many countries, fortunately for those countries, have. In the European Union tax havens are not allowed, tax havens are not acceptable. The problem is not with the European Union, certainly with the law. It will eventually and casuistically be in the inspection. If in the European Union the law is, in any case or at any time, breached, then inspect and act, do not change, it is what in many cases happens in the European Union, in the shame that exists in many other sides of the world. Finally, a word about this committee of inquiry that was helpful, but was insufficient. It has shown that it falls short, that it has far fewer instruments than many of the national commissions of inquiry. There were many people, many entities who refused to deliver documents, who denied testimonies, when they could help discover the truth, many who were rulers, underline and point out. (The speaker agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: Question according to the "blue card" procedure.- Is Mr Nuno Melo referring, when he talks about the outermost regions with special regimes, to Madeira?Do you want to accept that the kind of reasoning that you invoke is what justifies countries such as Malta, Luxembourg and others, in the European Union itself, to remain effectively tax havens?

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: Answer according to the "blue card" procedure.- Dr. Ana Gomes, I did not speak in Madeira.Mrs. Dra. Is obsessed with Madeira.And what I want to tell you is this: comparing Madeira to Panama is obscenity, it is a shame, and it is not for reasons of patriotism.Mrs. Dra. Does it and does very badly.As she knows, even in her own party, they do not accompany her.For some reason it will be.Fortunately, Madeira is not Panama.Madeira is an outermost region and Madeira can continue to benefit from the solidarity of the European Union, which is how it is supposed to be.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - Human rights, social justice, democratic contract trampled by governments, politicians and professionals captured by the evasion, fraud, so-called tax planning industry. That is what the “Paradise Papers” are once again exposing. Legislative work in this Parliament to make so-called legal practices illegal is blocked by Member States such as those I mentioned earlier in the Council, which serve the interests of tax invaders and money launderers. We need tax harmonization and transparency in the European Union, the list of non-cooperating countries with dissuasive sanctions, we need to sanction offenders who refuse to reveal the schemes to the tax authorities. For example, in my country, Portugal, lawyers are now shamelessly mobilizing, refusing to comply with this obligation under the fourth anti-money laundering directive. We fundamentally need public access to the registers of beneficial owners of companies and trusts established in the European Union or operating economically in the European Union! But a proposal to this effect, approved by this Parliament, after seven months of negotiations on the fifth anti-money laundering directive, remains shamefully blocked in the Council.

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, another major leak, another impressive work of journalistic research, more light on the turbulent world of tax evasion and avoidance and more outrage among ordinary people, who see how the richest move their money wherever it best suits their greed. Everything that big fortunes and large multinationals save in taxes must be offset by higher fiscal pressure on lower-income households. If the choice is for less taxes, then public spending has to fall, so that a privileged minority wins and an immense minority loses. According to recent studies, the income EU countries lose to tax havens amounts to the equivalent of about half of public spending on higher education. How many more papers and leaks: Panama, Paradise, Lux, football – you name it – do we need in order to take action? I call on the Members of this Parliament to vote for the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA) report and its recommendations during the final vote in December and to set up an inquiry committee in this House.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: - Tax evasion is a criminal offense, tax avoidance is not. In principle, everyone has the right to pay as little tax as possible, as long as they stay within the boundaries of the legislation. And perhaps that is why we should indeed amend the legislation as you propose, Commissioner.
