But the bottom line is that while every individual and every company has the same rights, they don't have the same capabilities. An SME at my place in West Flanders cannot afford the services of Appleby. That's what I call class taxation. Some argue that the super rich and the multinationals should retain the right to keep slipping through the net because that profit "trickles" to the common man anyway, because that money ends up anyway. But that is outdated, the facts prove it. We have to make the political choice for tax justice and if we make such a choice, then we must all do it together. But for that everyone has to join the bath, all European member states. I was really astonished when I heard Dutch Prime Minister Rutte announce this weekend that the dividend tax would be abolished. In the same breath he added that the Netherlands did not want to end up like Belgium, I quote: "an economic desert that only has one multinational left." The fallacy is that this is a sovereign decision of one member state. That is of course not the case. It's short-term thinking. It is blindly following the logic of multinationals and the latter are the only real winners. How great must the outrage be before everyone realizes that this class taxation is eating at the foundations of our society?

name: Paul Tang (S&D).
text: - Even Bono, the hero of my childhood, appears in Paradise Papers.Even Bono.So we don't have to count on a moral turning point from the rich and the big companies on this earth.We will have to do it ourselves, tackling tax avoidance.That starts with recognizing that there are modern pirates entering countries, plundering treasure chests outside of Europe, but also within Europe.The Netherlands, Malta, Luxembourg, Ireland, we know, but what do we do about it?It is impossible that we work together in Europe and still try to approach each other.That is why a European approach is very much needed, such as a single European consolidated profit tax.An agreement must be reached on this in 2018, I fully endorse the words of Pierre Moscovici."Sometimes you can't make it on your own," Bono sings.Combating tax piracy can only be done together.Europe and the Netherlands must take this to heart.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I have the impression that the root of the whole problem is that each of our Member States is in a futile, but all the more frantic race to attract the headquarters of large multinational companies. Every member state does them favors - every member state. It's not as if the number of McDonald's subsidiaries in Luxembourg generates such profits that the company then needs to resort to tax havens to launder money. The number of its subsidiaries in Germany or France or in other large countries is much larger and strangely, as a colleague said previously, the tax authorities of the states concerned do not seem to have caught these companies in the past, before they move their funds to other countries or territories. Obviously, this race to the bottom in which we are all participating, practically without exception, at the present time, is at the root of the problem we are facing, alongside the greed and greed of some greats, who do not 'have nothing to do with the reality of life, not even in the small European countries which are regularly pinpointed as being so-called tax havens when they are not. True paradises, as Ms. Scott Cato has said, are often truly paradises. They depend on great states, which have the might and the power to use them at will. Three quarters of the funds that pass through the City of London each day are generated in the British Crown Dependencies, either in the Caribbean or in the English Channel. This is all part of this debate that we are only scratching the surface of, when it comes to getting to the bottom of it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, it is clear that the tax practices of the richest and of multinationals inspire real disgust. By defying all fiscal and social justice, they only feed all the populisms. Indeed, these ultra-privileged deprive the vast majority of our fellow citizens who pay taxes, better schools, better health care or even the creation of hundreds of thousands of jobs. It is perfectly unbearable and you have to keep hammering it. I think austerity, like tax evasion, is not inevitable. It’s all a matter of political will. As you said, the absolute need for a public country-by-country report for companies is a prime example. It will bring the imperative transparency to their profits and tax the profits where they are made. The ACCIS is obviously its direct and necessary corollary. The Council's responsibility for bringing about this progress quickly is therefore immense today. But I ask myself a question: how long will the governments of the Member States, and starting with my Belgian government, still swim in full hypocrisy vis-à-vis this shameful behavior, whether illegal or immoral? Commissioner, we need you to make a difference.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE).
text: - Madam President, after the “Panama Papers”, we have the “Paradise Papers”. Once again, this data from thousands of companies and individuals shows us the urgency for concerted and coordinated action at a global level. The European Union must be a pioneer and, therefore, the Member States, above all, who have this competence, have a duty to act urgently, and they too, in a coordinated and concerted manner. In this matter, the sharing of sovereignty ends up reinforcing fiscal justice, equity and transparency. An important step is the publication at European level of a black list of offshores, which is, in fact, scheduled for before the end of the year. Without this common list, we will always have triangulations. Tax harmonization is also essential, as well as increased cooperation between tax authorities, automatic exchange of information, for example. But tax harmonization does not mean harmonization of rates. It is essential that more favorable tax regimes are not confused with offshores. Article 349 of the Lisbon Treaty allows the outermost regions to have a beneficial tax regime to attract investment, create jobs, promote development, since these regions are affected by remoteness and insularity. This regime, although it needs to be improved, has already proved that it has positive effects on the development of the regions.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: - Madam President! Dear Commissioner Moscovici, I share your view. Tax optimizers are like vampires, they shy away from daylight, they shy away from transparency. So we shed light on the darkness and advocate more transparency. That is why I am calling on the finance ministers here to finally end the blockade on public, country-by-country reporting. Country by country, companies have to pay taxes where they have the profits. This call applies in particular to the finance ministers of the United Kingdom, Malta, Luxembourg and also Austria. Let's take the side of the taxpayers! Also important: the Commission is in the process of presenting a package on company law at the end of November. We need clear rules, clear rules, in order to stop mailbox companies, this unsystem of mailbox companies. Hence my request, in this context, at Paradise Papers, not to allow the system of letterbox companies to continue to be made possible through cross-border divisions and subsequent mergers.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the problem is that if until a few years ago we did not have laws to fight against big companies that hide their profits or against the rich who do not want to pay taxes and use all sorts of financial schemes, now we have these laws. Of course they can be improved, of course more can be done, but the 2015 Directive was to be implemented in all Member States by 2017, in June. There are still Member States of the European Union where we have, for example, companies with bearer shares, with hidden shareholders, which in ten years have taken five hundred million euros of public money contracts, which have taken over one hundred and forty million euros contracts without tender and are in the European Union, moreover access European funds, and the 2015 Anti-Money Laundering Directive is not yet implemented and we are in the European Union and say we are fighting tax havens. We are not fighting, Madam President.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is an estimated $ 21 trillion in tax havens, of which 80% in the hands of the 0.1% of the richest in the world. But the wall of silence around the offshore is falling, the Paradise Papers confirm what we have been saying for some time: tax evasion and avoidance have devastating scope and must be fought globally. It is not enough to obtain transparency at the European level. We need, as Parliament already requested in 2015, a real intergovernmental body at the UN that rewrites global tax rules, involving developing countries that pay the highest price. We need transparent public records on the final beneficiaries of companies and trusts, automatic exchange of information, a black list with harsh penalties for those who work with havens, but based on objective and not political criteria. The role of intermediaries must be regulated and tax transparency must be incorporated into trade treaties, starting with the Brexit negotiations. And it is essential to approve as soon as possible the state-by-state public reporting obligation for multinationals, so that they tell us how much profits they make and how much taxes they pay in all states inside and outside the EU, as this House has already asked and voted on. .

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: - Ms. President! It is my belief that the operation of offshore paradises does not cause the greatest damage to the budgets of states or to the careers and credibility of political leaders and famous people. This phenomenon, which cannot be hidden from the public today, poses the greatest threat to democracy and the free market economy. If it becomes apparent to the masses that it is the elites who lead societies that do not follow the rules of the game - even if they are not supposed to break the law - it will lead to a fatal loss of confidence. If it becomes clear that the principle of public burden-bearing is just a good-sounding phrase, but wealthy people and companies find loopholes to avoid paying taxes while asking people for more sacrifices, then one should not be surprised at the reactions. Politics in representative democracies must keep the interests of the people in mind, so it is not enough to refer to the laws, but to eradicate this practice and forget hypocrisy.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam president. Commissioner Moscovici, many of us in this European Parliament appreciate your position against evasion, fraud and money laundering, but we ask for much more. We ask that the Commission be fully employed after LuxLeaks, Panama and the Paradise Papers, which are hell for taxpayers who pay their taxes and want to have confidence in their institutions, and a great sacrifice for whistleblowers who can cost life, as has happened in Malta. That it be used thoroughly with the Member States to obtain a prohibition on the opening of accounts and the opening of companies in tax havens, that it withdraws the license from banks that facilitate this type of manifestly illegal operations, that prohibits that it can take place in the European Union that companies that carry out operations in tax havens can bid in public tenders and that there is a harmonization of tax programs that fight against evasion and fraud with objective evaluation. Because otherwise, we will not be able to win this battle against the intolerable and immoral of tax avoidance and fraud.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, tax evasion and avoidance are on the agenda, both in the European Union and worldwide. The multinationals, the oligarchs and the various bigwigs, taking advantage of the current legislation and the legislative gaps, transfer their profits every year to tax havens and avoid billions of taxes. Tax dumping and aggressive tax planning are a daily occurrence in the European Union. Dijsselbloem's Netherlands, Juncker's Luxembourg and Malta are countries that provide tax avoidance incentives to the various multinationals. The revelations of the LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers simply prove publicly what is widely known: that the rich evade taxes and the well-known scapegoats, that is, employees and retirees, pay taxes. Mr Moscovici, the Greek people are outraged by the revelations that at least 130 Greek bigwigs are in the Paradise Papers, while the troika and the creditors are robbing the Greek people. Multinationals must finally be taxed where they make their profits.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, and many others that I do not quote. How many more tax scandals do we need for the European Union to act? How many more for Mr. Juncker and the others involved in these murky tax schemes to resign? We must sanction and prohibit capital movements to those countries and territories where taxes are not paid, where property records are not public and financial assets are opaque. For this reason, the European Union must be involved in multilateral forums and in the application of European legislation, including the Fourth Directive against money laundering or the proposal for a new basis for corporate tax. But we must also put an end to tax competition within the European Union itself, with demanding tax harmonization and the restriction of money and asset movements that do not respond to real flows. Otherwise, corruption and inequality will continue to destroy Europe's more than fragile democracy.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Madam President, the Paradise Papers is a tax evasion scandal which adds to the long list of scandals with an economic, but primarily moral, dimension and in which politicians from most countries are involved. Unfortunately, it is now the norm for offshore tax havens to launder dirty money, attract drug dealers, criminals, tycoons and politicians. Despite the proclamations and commitments of governments, parliaments and politicians in general, scandals capture a socio-political pathogenesis, characterize political life and fuel the crisis between society and politicians. The solution is not in the communication management of the scandals so as not to damage the public image of those responsible. The only way to combat the phenomenon is legal regulation, the severity of penalties and sanctions. Let us consider on a case-by-case basis the imposition of severe prison sentences, the abolition of parliamentary immunity, the confiscation of property and the deprivation of civil rights. Such a legislative initiative will bring all of us face to face with the responsibilities of our actions and deprive professional politicians of entanglement of their freedom of impunity.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: - We are all outraged when we find out about a new affair, but it doesn't end there.And we cannot say that we have done nothing at European level to prevent tax evasion, but we obviously still have a great deal of room for maneuver.Although we can do a lot with legislation, control and sanctions are just as important, and this is where the rule of law works.If this is not the case, it is all in vain.I support greater transparency, the restriction of unconditional tax secrecy and blacklists, but these lists must not be an end in themselves.In my opinion, however, we should also deal a little more with the causes of tax avoidance in this issue.Of course, it is clear that we do not even support tax evasion.If the law allows a company not to pay tax at all, then that is not fair.However, countries should be careful in designing their tax systems and not use their systems to drive businesses elsewhere.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, we have been debating an extremely important subject for two hours, I have debated it before. If I were to analyze the Commission's position and the Council's position, I would obviously agree with all the Commissioner's proposals. You are right: we must go to the pockets of those who steal money from citizens because they impoverish national budgets and people suffer, but, Minister, we did not understand the Council's position: you informed us that we have a conduct group. Do not help. You have to be firm in the Council and get the finance ministers and the governments to take action, to be transparent on the one hand, on the other hand, we have to cooperate with international bodies because yes, the money is transferred before the European Union and we cannot talk here about combating tax evasion if we do not have that blacklist that the Commissioner was talking about, if we do not have harmonized legislation and if we do not fight together, not each country alone, but together.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, tax evasion through offshore accounts is nothing new, so the Paradise documents only confirmed that the richest and most powerful always find a way to protect their wealth.National budgets suffer enormous damage due to this practice and are left without money that could be used to raise the quality of life of all residents.As much as those who evade paying taxes are guilty, so are those who allow them to do so, and that is politics and tax institutions.Today, it is quite difficult to hide the trace of money and therefore raises even more suspicions that it is a combination of politics and tax evaders.If we really want to show that this is not the case, let’s finally move on and stop pulling out and hiding money in tax havens, and if we’re not ready then let’s wait for another financial leak and we’ll just talk about it again.

name: Pierre Moscovici
text: member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you for this political debate, which I believe has been of great quality. What I'm seeing, I'm not surprised either, is a very strong convergence of views between us on political will, but also on the measures to be adopted. This alliance between the Commission and the European Parliament is fundamental if we want to continue our fight against tax evasion, fraud and aggressive tax optimization. Basically, now the stake is on the table, and it is to win the battle against tax evasion. To those who say the opposite, I still answer that we have made, yes, a lot of progress over the past three years and I am impressed by this real revolution in transparency, which is underway, with all the same a historic advance. that we must promote is the end of banking secrecy in Europe. But, you are all right, this is not enough, in the face of a phenomenon that is systemic and global. We must therefore continue to act with determination and quickly, with even more determination, even more speed. In 18 months, our citizens will vote to elect a new European Parliament and if we do not show change on this fundamental subject, we will lose all these elections to the benefit of the populists, the cynics who, in truth, are the allies of the fraudsters. We must therefore all take our responsibilities. All? Who is he? It is first of all the Member States, which have already started their evolution, but which sometimes still have hesitations, which must go further, which must speed up their work, which must quickly conclude on the proposals that are on the table. I am thinking of the announcement, on December 5, of the European list of tax havens and dissuasive sanctions. I am thinking of rules like the fight against tax intermediaries within six months. I think about a European tax base for companies within a year and I am also thinking, of course, of the ongoing trilogue on money laundering. It is then the European Commission which must assume its responsibilities. Believe it, this Commission, and myself as Commissioner responsible for taxation, will continue this battle relentlessly until the last day of our mandate. There will be no final year, shy on this ground. Other proposals will come which will all push for more transparency, more cooperation between tax administrations and, until then, I will continue to urge Member States to adopt this list of tax havens. To make it credible and ambitious, we cooperate well with the OECD, I mean, but we have higher ambition, simply because we have a higher degree of integration and criteria that are more powerful. The Commission will be the guardian of this list, but be careful, do not overlook this list, it is not us who propose it, it is not us who draw up it, it is the Member States. I would add, finally, that it will then be necessary to prosecute offenses against States that do not respect the rules, but here I make a commitment: if the blacklist is not up to the task, if it is not enough credible, if it is not substantial enough, if the sanctions are not dissuasive enough, then I will say so, because I believe that we must not be hypocrisy, things must be extremely clear. The European Parliament must also take its responsibilities, that is to say maintain the pressure, continue to exert its influence through the legislative proposals that are on the table. I will come in December to discuss the PANA report here, I congratulate its members, it is an excellent report, I have to say it. I invite your assembly to continue this work, whatever institutional form you will choose. Finally, collectively, we must, I believe, open two avenues for the future. The first one may not bring us all together, but I formulate it all the same, with my personal convictions. We must help European states and others, those who have made tax evasion a bit of a state business, to develop another economic and social model, and I say this for those for whom it is a business, but also for those for whom it is still tolerated practices. This revolution will not happen alone, this is the very meaning of political action. Finally, we must, I believe, decide on the passage of tax issues to qualified majority before the next European elections. Our fellow citizens - you meet them, I meet them - keep asking us for more social Europe or real tax harmonization, but let's not tell them stories, there will be progress in social Europe, there will be progress in fiscal transparency and convergence, but there will be no decisive progress for social Europe and for fiscal harmonization as long as we remain in a system where the will of one can paralyze, block , what everyone wants. The Commission, as you know, its President said, here in front of you, ladies and gentlemen of the European Parliament, will make proposals in 2018 in this direction. I know how difficult this fight will be, I know that it requires political courage and I know that for that it will be necessary that your assembly, by our side, put all the necessary energy, but I know, I believe I can count almost by definition on your majority support and I want to tell you that on all of these topics, well, I'm going to need it.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you to the Commissioner and all the Members who have spoken in this in—depth and highly thorough discussion, which I have listened to with great attention.  First, there was this concrete question from Mr Giegold, who seems no longer to be in the room. I do not want to prejudge today the result of the trilogue on the Anti-Money Laundering Directive but I can reconfirm the rock-solid commitment of the Estonian Presidency to have an agreement by the end of this year on this piece of legislation.  All things need to be seen in perspective and in context. I know people do not want to hear how hard other people’s work is. Therefore I will not list again all the constraints that we have to face in the Council while working on tax matters; which include unanimity, and this, Mr Bullmann, explains my diplomatic language. You only achieve results in the EU with diplomacy. I listed the initiatives and the new regimes that have been agreed on and that have been implemented during the last couple of years and it beats all the records if you compare it in the perspective of the last couple of decades. And this work is ongoing.  At the Ecofin Ministers meeting in December, the Estonian Presidency will strive for the endorsement of a blacklist of non-cooperative third countries, as proposed by the Conduct Group. We strive for the adoption of a VAT e—commerce package and we strive for the adoption of Council conclusions on the taxation of the digital economy. I will conclude, perhaps, with one observation of a more general kind. Some speakers here may have the impression that it is only the European Parliament that takes the moral high ground here, that it is only the European Parliament that stands for fair taxation, that stands for our citizens, and that governments indulge in hypocrisy, as if the Member States and their governments were not interested in having fair tax systems, and as if the Member States and their governments were not interested in tax revenues for their state coffers. All of us here are in the same boat and we are working towards reaching the same goals.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing.- As has been demonstrated once again with this issue of “Paradise Papers”, tax evasion is one of the main obstacles to the smooth and regular functioning of our economies.There is an urgent need to take a decisive stand against this problem in Europe.It is shameful that many of our fellow citizens are going through economic difficulties and facing the rigors of an economy in crisis when, at the same time, many corporations and private citizens hide their money in tax havens to avoid paying taxes that would serve to balance the accounts of severalMember states.Socialists have always been at the forefront of combating this and other types of tax evasion.Parliament and the Commission have already taken positions that help to combat this scourge.What is the Council waiting for?

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: written. - The leaks known as "Papers of Paradise" have once again highlighted the scandalous phenomenon of tax evasion and avoidance, by hiding the wealth of the wealthiest in shell companies with no real economic activity, located in jurisdictions where they do not comply in practice with the standards of automatic exchange of information between tax administrations or in which non-residents are exempt from taxation. These revelations, in addition to those of the "Panama Papers", oblige the Commission to publish the European list of tax havens as soon as possible, given that the OECD list does not conform to the actual practices of many States , which manage not to be nominally classified as such. Likewise, we demand that the Member States prohibit the opening of bank accounts by non-residents who do not carry out commercial activities in the States included in the future list of the European Union, since the purpose thereof cannot be other than tax avoidance. . We Spanish socialists reiterate that the fight without quarter against the great social injustice that tax fraud entails is an absolute priority of our political action.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. - The disclosure of new documents which prove, for the umpteenth time, how easy it is for a wealthy world elite to hide their immense fortunes from the taxman is no longer a novelty. Ordinary citizens, increasingly tightened by the grip of taxation, perceive that those who govern them do not have the political will to adequately oppose systems and places that allow the escape of wealth, the absence of controls and the evasion of taxes. How could it be otherwise if powerful statesmen, prime ministers and ministers also use or take advantage of tax havens? It is evident the co-responsibility of a certain policy and governments in allowing multinational companies and a circle of super-rich to steal resources from the public coffers by forcing ordinary citizens, small companies and the less well-off to suffer, in addition to austerity policies, also the negative consequences of a reduced possibility for the State to finance public services and to intervene with social or investment policies.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - Another scandal involving tax havens. The succession of scandals is in danger of trivializing them, even before any fundamental measures are taken to solve the problem. This new scandal confirms the systemic nature of tax evasion. Furthermore, it comes to expose the EU's inoperability and complicity in the situation. The same ones that impose impoverishment on workers and peoples extend the red carpet to big capital that allows them to save the accumulated income at the expense of labor exploitation and speculation (a prolongation). Here is the demonstration of the false dilemma: either the workers are choked with taxes or the social functions of the states are dismantled. No. What is needed is to put an end to these economic crime centers that are tax havens and to increase the revenues of States through a fair taxation of capital. Greater tax justice and an effective fight against tax fraud and evasion are not compatible with the reigning neoliberalism imposed by the European Union and governments that demonstrate that they are no more than representatives of the interests of large multinational companies and large financial institutions.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: written. - The leaks known as "Papers of Paradise" have once again highlighted the scandalous phenomenon of tax evasion and avoidance, by hiding the wealth of the wealthiest in shell companies with no real economic activity, located in jurisdictions where they do not comply in practice with the standards of automatic exchange of information between tax administrations or in which non-residents are exempt from taxation. These revelations, in addition to those of the "Panama Papers", oblige the Commission to publish the European list of tax havens as soon as possible, given that the OECD list does not conform to the actual practices of many States , which manage not to be nominally classified as such. Likewise, we demand that the Member States prohibit the opening of bank accounts by non-residents who do not carry out commercial activities in the States included in the future list of the European Union, since the purpose thereof cannot be other than tax avoidance. . We Spanish socialists reiterate that the fight without quarter against the great social injustice that tax fraud entails is an absolute priority of our political action.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: written. - We are facing one more example, and there are already too many, that tax avoidance and evasion throughout the world is a generalized practice of rich people and companies to hide assets, profits and wealth in general. There is a gigantic machinery doing this work and the operational base of these practices is the opacity of tax havens. Therefore, transparency in economic activities, in assets, the fight against tax havens and non-cooperative tax administrations is urgent. Tax evasion is a torpedo on the waterline of the credibility of our democratic institutions and, together with inequality and the devaluation of the social and labor world, is putting the social and European state of law at risk. It is urgent: - Before the end of the year the EU approves the list of tax havens outside and inside the EU. - That it establish a framework of sanctions against the countries on that list and the intermediaries that operate in them. - That a summit be convened at the United Nations to coordinate international efforts to put an end to these practices.

name: Sergei Stanishev (S&D)
text: in writing. – The Paradise Papers have shed light yet again on the magnitude of offshore empires. We must applaud those who uncovered these schemes, but also understand that the ball is in our court, and that the EU and its Member States must take action. Contrary to what many believe, tax havens are not a question of legality, but fairness. Tax avoidance contributes to existing divisions in our societies, making the rich richer, whilst depriving those in need from the social safety net they deserve. It is unfair that while many economies in Europe are still dominated by budget cuts, we are witnessing even more creative schemes for avoiding financial responsibility. There shouldn’t be one rule for the super—rich and another for loyal taxpayers. Commissioner Moscovici played a key role in stepping up the fight against corporate tax avoidance and progress has been made. Parliament should now take the initiative by setting up a committee to address these new leaks. Fair taxation is one of the fundamentals for the progressive functioning of our societies and if we are to have the ability to take on major challenges – unemployment, inequality and lack of cohesion – everyone should be paying their fair share.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: signed up.- The new evidence on the extent of tax avoidance, revealed by Paradise Papers, confirms, once again, the existing gap between banks, consulting firms, law firms and tax havens with a single purpose: the rich not to pay taxes therewhere they live and are tax residents.Why can't this harmful phenomenon be stopped for any country?The answer is simple: the beneficiaries are part of governments, of great industrial, financial concerns and have the power to block any serious approach that puts an end to financial transfers and transactions through companies "mailboxes" registered in tax havens.It is a challenge to all citizens who pay taxes correctly in their countries and who must be stopped.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. - Cyclically, the European Union has been involved in scandals associated with tax avoidance procedures, with more or less legal contours, but strongly damaging tax justice and the proper taxation of the wealth generated in its territory. These practices have a strong impact on the credibility of the institutions and on the capacity of the Member States to develop their sovereignty policies and to implement the democratically legitimate social policy and economic dynamism options. The European Parliament, through the creation of Commissions of Inquiry that have been mapping the contours of harmful behavior, has made a valid contribution to making the European Commission and the Member States more effective in combating leakages and tax sprains, which penalize taxpayers and weaken the Union as a global economic power. As a result, the European Commission has taken positive steps, but it is necessary to go further in the fight against corruption and in active cooperation between administrations to avoid tax avoidance and promote tax harmonization within the Union. These fiscal cooperation practices must be extended to countries that constitute the perimeter of economic interactions that can lead to fraudulent or ethically condemnable practices.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, for more than a decade, there has been a system of cross-border cooperation between consumer supervisory authorities in the European Union, which has improved the supervision, investigation and prosecution of cross-border infringements. However, the revision of its operation pointed to a number of limits that prevent more effective enforcement of the set rules. Supervisors in the EU's internal market must work together on a literal basis on a daily basis and have sufficient powers and tools to deal with cross-border cases. This need has been exacerbated by the development of e-commerce. I recall that the proposal is one of the priorities of the Digital Single Market Strategy. The presented update of the existing rules on cross-border supervisory cooperation is intended to ensure faster, more active and more consistent enforcement. We need effective mechanisms that also prevent divergent approaches to law enforcement for the same infringement. Let me outline a few concrete measures that this regulation is intended to help increase consumer protection and create fair conditions for all businesses in the internal market. The proposed legislation will significantly strengthen the powers of supervisory authorities in the areas of investigation, law enforcement and corrective action. To facilitate investigations, it now has the possibility for supervisory authorities in all EU countries to control purchases of goods under a hidden identity. The supervisory authorities will have the power to impose sanctions and require the trader to undertake to offer appropriate redress to consumers who have suffered damage. The new rules will also improve the enforcement of consumer rights in the online environment. In the event of an imminent risk of serious and irreparable harm to the interests of consumers, supervisory authorities will be able to request the suspension of a website if its operator does not respond and refuses to seek redress. Supervisors should also have the power to request information from domain registrars and banks to identify the responsible trader. Fraudulent internet sites are a growing phenomenon that is currently difficult for the responsible authorities to combat effectively. An important part of the regulation are the rules for exercising these powers. Here, we have been very consistent in ensuring that enforcement is proportionate in accordance with Union law, national law and the principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. As before, Member States will continue to be able to choose whether the competent authority will exercise its powers directly or through legal proceedings. This is already happening under the current regulation and, in my opinion, there is no need to change anything in this regard. One of the innovations brought by the revision is the institute of the so-called extensive violation of consumer protection legislation with an EU dimension. It is a new instrument that involves complex investigations and coordinated enforcement in a large number of Member States. The coordinating role will always be entrusted to the Commission in this case, but each of the actors involved will know clearly what is expected of him and how to proceed. The functioning of the database and the information exchange system will also be improved, and the European Parliament will make the whole system of cooperation even more transparent. The revision of the rules will also improve the position of consumer organizations, which will be able to formally provide information to supervisors on suspected infringements. With so-called first-hand information from consumers, supervisors have often not been able or willing to work, which will change. Trade associations, which are also well acquainted with the market and have information that supervisors often do not have to access, will not be left out either. Supervisors will also be able to more easily coordinate consumer market investigations. At a time when market trends, consumer complaints or other indications indicate that large-scale infringements of consumer protection law could or are already taking place, a Europe-wide survey may be convened and binding measures may be taken in all Member States. So far, this has been done to a limited extent and only in an online environment.I believe that the regulation will be an effective tool for prosecuting all well-known illegal practices, but it will also serve, for example, in combating dual product quality and wherever consumers are discriminated against or treated unfairly.Facilitating the exchange of knowledge between supervisory authorities from individual states and the possibility of intervening together is the main currency of this legislation.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the revision of the Consumer Protection Cooperation Regulation, which you will vote on today, is a key deliverable of the Commission’s consumer strategy. I would like to thank the rapporteur on this file, Ms Olga Sehnalová, and all the shadow rapporteurs who have spared no effort to get a good deal for EU consumers.  Europe has the best consumer legislation in the world. However, it needs more effective enforcement, as was shown in the recently performed fitness check of EU consumer and marketing laws. This has confirmed the outline of our consumer strategy, which means focusing on public and private enforcement of consumer protection rules and laws. In the coming months the Commission will continue to ensure that consumer law is fully complied with and that no consumer is left without the chance for better individual redress, especially in mass harm situations. This will also be one of the main objectives of the measures that we are going to propose as our new deal for consumers in the spring of next year. The Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) review has responded to the trend of the opening and digitalisation of the consumer markets, which has also increased possibilities for illegal and unfair practices. Unfortunately public enforcement systems in most Member States date back to the pre—digital era, and in all Member States the reach of public authorities is limited by national jurisdictional rules. It was therefore high time that we modernised the public enforcement of consumer laws in the EU. We have proposed to reform the way public authorities work together and, with the Commission, to tackle illegal practices harming consumers’ interests and fair competition, as well as trust in the European single market. I would like to thank Parliament for its support throughout the negotiations, which were swift, focused and very purposeful. Once the new regulation is implemented, our citizens will be able to benefit from better working institutions securing fairer markets. Public authorities throughout Europe will have modern enforcement tools to tackle online offences, such as the power to find out who is behind an illegal commercial online practice, trace back financial flows, block online content or issue appropriate online warnings.  A real breakthrough is that consumer protection authorities will get more leverage in their joint negotiations with multinational players. Equipped with the power to accept traders’ commitments on remedies to consumers, as foreseen in the respective national laws, the authorities will be in a position to correct traders’ practices swiftly in all the Member States concerned with large—scale breaches of consumer rights. This will also avoid many lengthy civil court actions in situations where harm has been caused to many consumers across borders. Last but not least, the Commission will have a key market surveillance role. It will be in a position to request Member States investigate in a coordinated manner practices that do not look right when such practices concern a large part of the Union. The Regulation on Consumer Protection Cooperation review that you will approve today is a key part of the mosaic of the consumer strategy of this Commission. Thank you in advance for your support.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. - Mr President, the report on cooperation between national authorities for consumer protection is part of the debate on the new relevant European regulation. The rapid growth of international trade in the digital environment offers great opportunities, but also creates significant risks for consumers, with negative economic consequences at the individual, state and EU levels. This leads to undermining consumer confidence in cross-border trade. It is estimated that 1/3 of e-commerce sites violate European consumer protection legislation. Therefore, it is not enough to theoretically upgrade the capabilities of the national authorities provided for in the new regulation. In practice, we must strengthen the capacity of the authorities, especially the most economically vulnerable Member States of the Union, to combat unfair practices that threaten citizens and the economy.

name: Carlos Coelho
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, consistency in the coercive application of the essential acquis of the Union in the field of Consumer Law contributes, must contribute, to reinforce consumer confidence in the European digital single market. Regulation 2006/2004 created a network of national law enforcement authorities to ensure that the main Union consumer laws are applied consistently across borders. The evaluation of that regulation showed, however, that the existing rules had to be revised to respond to the challenges of the digital economy and the development of cross-border trade in the European Union. Effective coordination is needed between the different competent authorities that make up this network, as well as effective coordination between other public authorities at Member State level. The agreed text is the result of months of compromises between the Commission's initial proposal and the positions of Parliament and the Council, and provides for modern, effective and efficient mechanisms. As a shadow rapporteur for the European People's Party, I want to applaud 5 fundamental aspects of the text that we are going to vote on. First, it strengthens the enforcement of consumer laws across the Union, without affecting Member States' competences in this area. Second, it provides an extended common set of minimum powers for the competent authorities of the Member States. Third, it increases the level of harmonization which translates into effective and efficient cooperation between the competent public authorities, covering the entire dimension of the single market. Fourth, it establishes the involvement of consumer and merchant organizations in the mechanism. And fifth, it creates a common procedure at Union level for generalized infringements at Union level, guaranteeing the Commission a strong coordination role. Contrary to what some claim, the exercise of the powers of this regulation must be proportionate and appropriate to the nature of the infringement and respect the provisions of national and Union law, including judicial guarantees and fundamental rights.In conclusion, Mr President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur Olga Sehnalová, the fellow shadow rapporteurs and the European Commission on the result achieved which clearly benefits consumer rights in the Union.

name: Nicola Danti
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, with the text that we will approve today, European consumers will be better protected in their rights when they decide to buy, including online, in another EU country. A further step towards the creation of a single market, also in its digital dimension, closer and more attentive to citizens and consumers, who increasingly buy online, we are talking about about 290 million Europeans. The revision of this regulation has two main objectives: on the one hand, to adapt the current consumer protection rules to the new challenges posed by digital and the rapid spread of electronic commerce, which was worth around 530 billion euros in 2016, and on the other hand, making the cooperation between the different national authorities, which are already responsible for their implementation, more efficient. The latter will see their executive powers strengthened and increased, such as that of imposing sanctions and that of obliging the inflation manager to compensate harmed consumers. These are necessary tools to prevent significant abuses that are not identified or addressed adequately today, also and above all due to their cross-border dimension. In addition, an ad hoc mechanism will be set up to combat abusive practices that occur in more than two thirds of countries and which therefore risk threatening the common interest of European citizens. With the approval of this regulation, consumers and authorities will have more effective tools to combat widespread cases of fraud against European citizens, as has unfortunately happened in the past, starting with the Volkswagen case. Finally, I would like to thank my colleague Olga Sehnalová for the excellent result achieved in the trialogue, where she has successfully defended most of the claims put forward by the European Parliament.

name: Richard Sulík
text: for the ECR Group. - Mr President, for more than a decade the Commission has been proposing and the Union is adopting consumer protection legislation. It often happens that some legislation is not complied with, the Commission proposes a new one instead of enforcing compliance with the existing legislation. The result is 2,700 open infrared proceedings, ie infringement proceedings, of which 320 are in the area of ​​the internal market. The result is that, by exaggerating consumer protection, we make him an unruly sheep. This may apply to the Member States and their legislation more than to the Union. Another problem is priorities. The Commission has too many, and some of them are contradictory. Consumer protection legislation often unnecessarily complicates the lives of businesses, and improving the business environment is also one of the Union's declared priorities. Entrepreneurs then often do not know the law, they cannot recognize it and legal certainty is low. However, consumers themselves also suffer as a result. At the same time, I understand that in the area of ​​e-commerce, if it is cross-border, legislation is needed at European Union level. I appreciate the rapporteur's efforts to seek and find a real and fair compromise. In my opinion, the resulting proposal has the potential to improve the enforcement of existing rules, especially in cross-border trade. I want to believe that other changes, such as the minimum powers of national trade inspections, will also help to enforce existing laws. However, it is an illusion to think that by law we can protect the consumer perfectly. First and foremost, he must protect himself, and it would therefore be very good if the Union did not act for several years in the field of consumer protection legislation and focused on improving the business environment.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, let me first start by thanking the rapporteur, the Commission and my fellow colleagues who were working on this file. I am sure that they agree with me that this important file will better protect consumers and prevent fraud. My personal experience of fraud online was actually buying, booking and paying for a hotel room only to find out that in reality there were no rooms... nor even a hotel! Only a voice at the other end of the telephone line saying: ‘but I can see your room on my website.’ I am completely sure that all of us have had such an experience when buying online: fraudulent websites selling incredibly cheap products that are actually never delivered; websites offering products that turn out to be counterfeit; the ‘free-trial’ scams that promise consumers that they can try a product for free, only to find out later on that they have to pay something for the services... The list can be long and this piece of legislation today is directed at those consumers who have been deceived on the internet while buying products. It will make sure that consumer protection authorities collaborate better and prevent these infringements going on in the EU. We need to protect consumers because we have to buy things on the internet. There is a greater choice, there is a possibility of better value, but shopping on the internet has to be safe. I did want to see stronger wording on the need for a court decision before closing a website but nevertheless I do support the outcome of the negotiations and I do hope that the Member States will implement this legislation as soon as possible.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, there have been many changes in the European Union's internal market recently. We need to respond to the challenges of the digital economy and the development of cross-border trade in the EU. I believe that the regulation we are debating today will help to detect unfair practices, such as dual food quality, in good time. It appears that seemingly similar products are sold on the EU market, but in some Member States they have, for example, a lower meat content, a higher fat content or a different type of sweetener. (The President cut off the speaker because of a problem with interpretation.) Especially in the countries of Central Europe, which is unacceptable to our citizens. Strengthening the role of consumer organizations and early detection of unfair practices will help address the spread of infringements across the EU. The natural person - consumer must not be harmed by the development of the internal market, he must not be his hostage or a bastard. I call on all colleagues to support the agreement reached in the trialogue, as I consider it to be a balanced compromise. Thank you, rapporteur, for your excellent work.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the reform of the Consumer Protection Cooperation was an opportunity to update an important and already well-established system of cooperation of national consumer protection authorities. Parliament went into trilogue with a strong position on much-needed aspects. Consumers who have been harmed need compensation. Dieselgate has shown that we cannot leave this up to the discretion of the companies. Illicit profits would need to be restituted. The trilogue outcome we are debating today unfortunately falls short on these key points of the original Commission proposal. On top of that, it establishes overreaching internet blocking measures that are neither proportionate nor suitable for the goal of protecting consumers and come without mandatory judicial oversight. I am asking you not to just sign off on the trilogue outcome today but rather to please support the plenary amendments that reinstate the Parliament position on these critical issues, in order to really provide an added value for citizens.

name: Marco Zullo
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the online world there are no borders and transnational fraud is more difficult to tackle, not least because the action of national authorities is limited by the different procedures that exist between countries. The result is that fraud affecting consumers in multiple countries is not resolved in a coordinated and coherent way, to the detriment of all citizens, as in the Volkswagen scandal involving eight million vehicles in Europe. It is therefore necessary that the European national authorities have minimum powers in common, in order to guarantee a basic level of consumer protection, below which it is not possible to go down. This regulation on cooperation between national consumer protection authorities is a step forward in this direction. Authorities are given the opportunity, for example, to find sensitive information across borders, such as financial flows. Consumer associations are involved and can report suspected fraud directly to the States and the Commission. But we ask that we be more ambitious towards citizens in terms of compensation. We have therefore tabled amendments to grant national authorities the power to order fraudulent companies to compensate damaged citizens even by returning profits. This is a duty towards consumers. I therefore ask this House to support these amendments.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I allow myself, once is not customary, to appreciate the spirit of the text which will be put to the vote today. The prerogatives of the national authorities responsible for consumer protection are preserved and strengthened and new legal tools are made available to them to adapt to the digital age. Cooperation between these national authorities featured in this text with a real concern for efficiency and competence is satisfactory. The role of coordinator or facilitator given to the Commission, in large-scale infringement cases with a European dimension, also seems pragmatic and in line with the current commercial context. We have finally succeeded in avoiding the pitfall of the centralizing temptations of the Commission, which are generally disconnected from commercial realities and therefore generally counterproductive. This sprawling will has not prevailed today and I applaud it. Consequently, my group will support the provisional agreement and see this text as an interesting working basis for the future. The level of optimal protection for citizens and consumers of course remains the "Nation" and I am delighted to see that we are all in agreement here.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Go raibh maith agat a Uachtaráin. Molaim an Rapóirtéir agus an Coimisinéir as ucht na moltaí seo a chabhróidh go mór le saoránaigh na hEorpa. Mr President, the agreement reached at trilogue will ensure the development of modern, efficient and effective consumer protection cooperation measures which will reduce consumer detriment caused by cross—border infringements. It is vital that all Member States reach similar outcomes on the same malpractices across the board in relation to consumer and marketing law. I think that this text will help to ensure this. There are a number of positive points in this text. I particularly welcome that the Commission will be empowered to assist Member States in coordinating common actions – for example those of national enforcement – to get commitments from traders to change their malpractices. Additionally, I welcome the new surveillance mechanism to replace the current CPC system of alerts, widening the exchange of information. This agreement will enable enforcement authorities to cooperate more efficiently and act faster in the single market, especially the digital single market. It is vital that this cooperation is facilitated, as consumers must be protected to the same degree throughout the EU—28. I look forward to the implementation of the regulation.  Job maith, comhghairdeachas.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Sir. Chairman! Digitization offers consumers many new opportunities. E-commerce is booming and we have only seen the beginning. But along with increasing trade, we are also seeing increasing problems for consumers shopping digitally. Some are deliberately cheated and others just do not get the protection they are actually entitled to. We have to deal with that, and that is exactly what we are doing, with the law we are going to vote on today. We are strengthening cooperation between the authorities in the EU Member States, and this is absolutely central to ensuring that consumers' rights are enforced - enforced strongly and well and quickly. With the law, we strengthen the authorities' tools to go after those who do not comply with our consumer protection, with i.a. better rules for sanctioning and imposing fines and the like. That's really, really important! The more secure our consumers are, the more they will act, and they are only safe if we have some proper consumer protection rules enforced. So I support the result today.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: - In the digital age, consumers are increasingly faced with the challenge of enjoying good protection.A safe internet environment is nevertheless crucial to strengthen their confidence in online shopping.Figures have been released today that only 38% of consumers consider it safe to shop across borders online.We must therefore react quickly to tackle the fight against the criminal web traders.The strengthening of the capacities of the national competent authorities, in combination of course with cross-border cooperation, will make it easier for Member States to fight this battle.And it is necessary because those criminal web traders can all too easily move their activities from country to country.That is why we must involve all actors in the process: a European warning system where consumer organizations can sound the alarm and also the right to better information and compensation systems.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, within the European Union businesses and consumers should know no borders. This is the key to the digital single market and to the Union as a whole. Sadly, however, just as companies and individuals know no borders, so too do bad operators and bad products, people who do not respect consumer protection law and think they can get away with it because they are in one Member State and the victim is in another. Consumers will only go cross-border if they have trust: trust that all national authorities are working together to keep out and sanction those bad apples.  Up to 37% of European e-commerce websites are in breach of EU consumer protection law. It is in the collective interest of each Member State to ensure the better enforcement of consumer protection law, both at home and cross-border. While we do have some doubts as to the website takedowns, it is thanks to the good work of Commissioner Jourová, the rapporteur, and others that the overall package is a fine outcome.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I think I should first of all thank the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs involved on this difficult dossier. Because I believe that at the beginning it was the case that the Commission naturally came into the process with a very ambitious proposal. I believe that there was general agreement in the European Parliament that we urgently need to ensure that the enforcement of European consumer regulations and European consumer laws in the European Union must improve, and as has just been pointed out - that we are better off too cross-border succeeds. In the end, of course, in many Member States the closure of a website has to be a decision of a judge and cannot simply be carried out administratively. In this respect, I believe that the compromise that we have reached here is a really good basis on the one hand to ensure that the European Commission can better enforce consumer rights in the Member States - in Europe - but on the other hand we can enforce it Page has also succeeded in maintaining the existing structures in the Member States - however different they may be in detail. Therefore, many thanks to everyone who contributed to this. I assume that today we will find a very large majority in favor of this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the online digital world, there are no borders. This makes it very difficult for consumers and national authorities to tackle any problems emanating from the digital single market. Consumers are often confused and powerless and find themselves in a catch-22 situation. They do not know which authority to contact, who is responsible or who can help them. Even if they contact the right authority, the authority itself is limited by the procedures of its own national regulations. Not only are consumers powerless but so is the national authority. This is unacceptable in a modern digital single market. Challenges must be addressed by creating a digital environment, by adopting digitally proved consumer laws that can ensure strong and enforceable consumer rights for everyone in the EU. I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Olga Sehnalová, for finalising this proposal during the Maltese Presidency. This legislation will empower public authorities by giving them improved tools to protect consumers from rogue traders, particularly in online cross-border negotiations.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the system of consumer protection in the single market is extremely important for European economies because it builds trust that always results in higher consumption and multiple positive effects on the economy. Better cooperation between national authorities on this issue is key to the proper functioning of the single market, whose heterogeneity is welcome in many respects, but should not be a mitigating factor for consumer fraud. The Regulation leaves sufficient room for Member States to choose the implementation system they deem appropriate and to decide on the allocation of powers among national authorities. They are also free to determine whether the competent authorities will exercise their powers directly or with the assistance of other public bodies, ie under the supervision of the judiciary, which is only required to ensure the efficiency and proportionality of the costs of the proceedings. This is a good way. Consumer protection standards must be common to us, and Member States must be able to choose how they implement them. Of course, while respecting this Regulation.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you from the outset on your proposal for a revision of the rules. Here, after ten years, I want to congratulate Olga, our fellow rapporteur, who has worked hard to reach compromises and amendments to help, because a colleague said here: “we have a lot of regulations, the important thing is to we make them efficient ”. I do not want to repeat what my colleagues have said, but I want to emphasize three things: firstly, in this report, I think it is good that the limitation period for exercising certain powers in the event of a breach has been specified; it is a reasonable term of five years and I think it is welcome; secondly, I believe that we need to support, and this report provides for, the participation of consumer organizations, for example in the alert mechanism, as provided for in Article 34 because entities representing a legitimate interest in consumer protection are often aware of infringements. faster than the authorities; and thirdly, I think that the presentation of biannual enforcement plans by each Member State is very welcome.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I will start by giving you a figure: 37. This is the percentage of sites which do not comply with European laws on consumer protection. Thanks to the revision of this legislation in terms of cooperation between national authorities responsible for ensuring the application of consumer protection legislation, real progress is to be welcomed, as national authorities will now benefit from powers that are broadened and adapted to the evolution of the digital society, adapted to their times in order to put an end to the too many online violations of these rights. I would also like to congratulate Olga Sehnalová, as has already been done, for her excellent work as rapporteur in this area and I particularly welcome the following advances: the real power of investigation for national authorities, the creation of sanctions and consumer compensation, the establishment of an alert mechanism and the strengthening of the role of consumer protection associations in this process.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, when it comes to more effective supervision of investigations and prosecution in terms of violations exploited by dishonest traffickers in the intra-country or common European space, it is clear that every day needs to be more effectively monitored and better solutions sought to end dishonesty. The biggest problems are still visible in online business where consumers are not sufficiently protected, primarily by buying products or services outside their home country. But here I want to warn you that as much as a third of the food products we find on store shelves in the newer members of the European Union are of poorer quality than in the West. Research has confirmed that the eastern market has been deceived by the same packaging in which low-quality products are found. From fruit drinks and toothpastes to detergents, eastern versions of brands sold across Europe have shown that they are of lower quality than those sold in the west and this needs to be stopped. There must be no country with second-class consumers in the European Union.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the primary objective of the regulation on consumer protection cooperation is to ensure legal certainty in the single market. However, the current rate of non-compliance with the Union acquis on consumer protection shows that the situation is not exactly optimal. Coordinated checks of e-commerce websites show a non-compliance rate of core standards between 32% and 69% in the audited markets. The approach set by the new regulation will serve to develop modern, efficient and effective mechanisms to reduce situations where cross-border infringements are not sufficiently addressed and to ensure that consumer protection authorities reach similar conclusions on identical abusive practices. A harmonized framework to coordinate enforcement activities carried out by authorities will allow for effective cross-border cooperation between public authorities to prevent defaulting operators from exploiting shortcomings, territorial limitations and other limitations that affect the ability to enforce the rules of each Member State .

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the unregulated development of the single market and the development of e-commerce make it necessary to take measures in the form of a regulation to protect consumers themselves. Because what emerges from the debate is that at least 37% of the websites that exist for the provision of services, in practice violate the rights of consumers. Therefore, action needs to be taken. Firstly, to strengthen the powers of the national authorities, because only then can there be effective protection. Secondly, to strengthen consumer organizations, which will be able to take direct action on their own in order to protect consumers. Of course, extending the rights of consumers themselves by legal means is also very important. Therefore, I believe that these measures are in the right direction and we will be able to say more during the vote.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the great development of the Internet enables a large number of consumers to trade remotely through it. This possibility, however, exposes them to the risk of falling victim to small or large fraud, such as e.g. deposit money to buy non-existent items, or buy items of questionable quality. Cooperation between national authorities is therefore necessary to protect consumers from this fraud and to keep them informed of what is happening to these companies via the Internet. There must be the possibility of enforcing strict legislation so that those companies that are illegal can return the money to consumers, as well as cancel some websites that belong to companies that are illegal. This will increase consumer confidence and also increase distance trade.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, in my concluding remarks I would like to explain the two basic pillars of our consumer policy.  Consumer policy in the EU is based on the protection of the weaker side of the commercial relationship. As we can see, we are facing a totally new situation because the position of the consumer in the online world is very different from the position in his or her shop in his or her street. This asymmetry of power is something we have to address. The second pillar is that we need to have our consumers in the EU legally well-equipped, with the possibility of defending their rights themselves. That is why we are focusing, on the one hand, on better public enforcement: we are doing this through the CPC Regulation review and I am sure we are doing the proper thing for EU consumers. On the other hand, there are dishonest traders who cause much harm to consumers.  The second thing, which we plan for Spring next year, is to improve the situation in private enforcement for consumers. You know that we are considering some possibility of European Union collective redress. Of course, as Justice Commissioner, I also have in mind to come with measures which will not increase the workload for the European courts, so I welcome alternative ways to settle disputes and this is where the CPC review can help.  Ladies and gentlemen, thank you very much for your support and I hope for your positive vote later today.  Commission Statement (in writing) The European Commission declares the following. Article 21 requires competent authorities to take the necessary enforcement measures to cease widespread infringements. The Article sets out (in a non-exhaustive manner) in what situations enforcement measures are particularly appropriate. Amongst these situations, Article 21 lists: in paragraph (1) (d) commitments which are insufficient to ensure the cessation of the infringement or, where appropriate, to remedy consumers harmed by the infringement; and in paragraph (1) (e) the failure by the trader to implement those commitments. Article 21 (1) (d) and (e) must be read in consistency with the objectives of the Regulation, which are to set up an effective and efficient enforcement cooperation among competent public enforcement authorities to detect, investigate and order the cessation of intra-Union infringements and widespread infringement, and with the main provisions on remedial measures contained in the Regulation, in particular Article 9 (4) (c). In coordinated actions, where a competent authority has sought to obtain commitments from the trader to offer adequate remedies to the consumers concerned by an infringement, it may be particularly appropriate to take enforcement measures when those commitments are insufficient to remedy consumers harmed by the infringement or when those commitments are not implemented."

name: Olga Sehnalová zpravodajka.
text: - Mr President, I would like to take this opportunity to thank all the shadow rapporteurs, namely Carlos Coelho, Richard Sulík, Jasenka Selimovič and Julia Red, as well as the European Parliament's administration for constructive cooperation and support throughout the work. My thanks also go to the representatives of the Slovak and Maltese Presidencies for their enormous commitment to reaching an agreement. Of course, I also thank the proposers, Commissioner Jourová and the Directorate-General for Justice and Consumers, but first and foremost my assistant, Michal Vaňáček, for the enormous amount of work he has done on this text. Like any legislation, this revision is a compromise between the European Parliament and the Member States. The negotiated text has not deviated from its intended goal and can bring tangible benefits to European citizens. I would therefore like to call on all colleagues who support the establishment and enforcement of fair conditions in the internal market to support this negotiated agreement today.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. - Commissioner, the revision of the regulation we are debating today was now necessary to overcome the new challenges posed by the advent of the digital age and the exponential growth of electronic commerce. In fact, already in 2014, two thirds of individual complaints concerned cross-border purchases made online, compared to an estimated damage of around 770 million euros per year for consumers. In order to fully exploit the growth potential of the digital single market, the EU needs to firmly tackle illegal and unfair practices that directly harm consumers and the trust they place in e-commerce. Consumer protection must therefore be pursued by strengthening the powers of the competent national authorities in order to ensure the commitment of economic operators to compensate consumers in the event of illegal practices, with fair conditions for all and with efficient and transparent procedures, with a coordinating role of the European Commission in the event of infringements that threaten the collective interest of consumers. I congratulate my colleague rapporteur for the excellent work she has done and for having obtained greater participation from consumer associations who will be able to report cases of suspected infringement to the competent authorities.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – I strongly support the outcome of this highly important report, which builds on the proposal of reforming a pivotal piece of legislation, the so-called Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) Regulation that governs the powers of enforcement authorities and the way in which they can cooperate in order to ensure effective surveillance, investigation and prosecution of cross-border breaches of consumer law. Indeed, the increased momentum of e—commerce as well as widespread consumer law infringements across the internal market call for an overhaul of the Regulation, so that the latter does not fall short of what would be needed in order to ensure strong and enforceable consumer rights for everyone in the European Union.  Therefore, welcoming the reform proposal, I share the opinion that the Commission has rightly put the spotlight on the powers needed by the enforcement authorities in all Member States, which will certainly underpin proper cross-border cooperation. Finally, I consider that a structured dialogue between public enforcers and consumer associations is paramount as these entities very often become aware of infringements much earlier than the competent authorities.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: in writing. - The amendment to the regulation aims to strengthen the consumer protection rights of EU citizens in order to prevent cross-border infringements and enforce the penalties imposed. It is common practice for fraudulent traders to relocate to a Member State where consumer protection is less developed, thus avoiding legal consequences. In order to prevent such cases, it is necessary for Member States to strengthen their cooperation in the field of consumer protection. Member State authorities will be given additional powers, such as hacking, house searches or trial purchases, and new sanctions will include the suspension or termination of a website / domain name. In order to promote cross-border legal aid, a common database will be set up to facilitate the exchange of information between Member States. Enforcement authorities work in two-year cycles, which are also monitored by the Commission every two years.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D)
text: in writing. - Congratulations to the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs on the report aimed at cooperating with the Member States on consumer protection. Illegal and unfair practices used by companies harm consumers and distort healthy and fair competition. Improving legislation by adapting to changing conditions is essential. However, there is already significant consumer legal protection, which is not effectively enforced across the EU. I particularly emphasize the introduction of the concepts of 'extended infringement' and 'extended infringement with a Union dimension'. The systematic and massive use of illegal and abusive clauses-practices by the banking system in various Member States, especially in Cyprus, which is an example to be avoided, has been a widespread infringement with a European dimension.
