The abusive behavior of banks and, at the same time, the ineffective implementation of European legislation to eliminate abusive clauses and practices contributed significantly to the economic catastrophe that culminated in 2013, the terrible consequences of which a large part of the population in Cyprus is still experiencing, and demands justice. Effective enforcement would have prevented the problem.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: in writing. – I support the work of the rapporteur Olga Sehnalová. Parliament should adopt this report as it will strengthen national authorities to enforce consumer rights. The Consumer Protection Cooperation (CPC) Regulation from 2004 set up effective methods of cooperation between public authorities responsible for enforcing consumers’ rights, but the latest development in e-commerce and trade is asking for a reform of the rules. We need efficient tools for cooperation between the enforcers of consumer law that are effective enough in the digital age to ensure consumers a safe online shopping experience. The reform of the CPC Regulation empowers consumers by giving the national authorities powers to impose fines and penalties payments, or to seek to obtain commitment to compensate the consumers for the harm done. Consumer rights are becoming progressively more important as the trade develops new ways of business and so the legislation needs to adapt to this evolution as well.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: in writing. - There is no doubt that consumer protection in the EU market is an important element in the development of Community law. Already in 2003 For the first time, the Commission has proposed a framework for cross-border cooperation between national authorities to facilitate more effective monitoring, investigation and prosecution of cross-border criminal activities, thus closing the loopholes exploited by rogue traders. In order to ensure legal certainty and the effectiveness of enforcement actions in relation to cross-border infringements and to avoid differences in treatment between consumers and businesses in the single market, it is necessary to introduce a limitation period. This means a specific period of time during which the competent authorities may impose sanctions, compensate consumers or recover the proceeds of the infringement in compliance with the rules governing cross-border infringements. However, let us not forget that it is up to the Member States to decide whether the competent authorities will exercise these powers directly within their competences or by making statements to the competent courts. If Member States find that the competent authorities are exercising their powers, they should ensure that the rights can be exercised in a timely and effective manner.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I declare a resumption of the meeting following the award of the LUX Prize.Before proceeding to the vote, I will give the floor to Mr Amjad Bashir.

name: Amjad Bashir (ECR).
text: – Mr President, yesterday Sky News vividly showed the entire world what the suffering of the Rohingya has been. I saw that first—hand when I visited the survivors of this genocide in Bangladesh. In Myanmar babies are being born on the beach. The lucky ones will be put on a boat to Bangladesh. The rest will be left to die.  The UK Prime Minister has vowed to tackle the inhuman destruction of the Rohingya people. I plead only for the President’s authorisation for an extraordinary debate to consider the situation of the Rohingya, in accordance with Rule 153(4), because, after lengthy discussions with the UN, Bangladesh, Myanmar and the UK, I believe the EU should now convene an intergovernmental summit to put an end to this genocide. For the sake of humanity, let this House lead the way forward.  (Applause)

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Mr Bashir, I have listened carefully to your proposal and the reasons behind it.I undertake to forward your proposal to the President of the European Parliament immediately.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is Voting Time.(For the results and other information on the vote: See Minutes)

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, may I have a technician, please, as my voting machine is not working.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to propose that the Chamber votes on the amendments to the draft legislative act first, in order to give the Members the opportunity to reinstate Parliament’s position on fundamental rights, safeguards against website blocking and a stronger position on consumer rights.

name: Olga Sehnalová
text: rapporteur.- Mr President, I am against this proposal as rapporteur, and I recommend voting on the outcome of the negotiations, on the final agreement.

name: Iratxe García Pérez
text: Speaker. - Mr President, Europe is getting old. 80% of the population is in 20% of the territory. Our rural environment is dying and urgent measures are taken from the European Union to fight against depopulation. But today I would like to pay particular attention in this House to the statements made by Mr Korwin-Mikke yesterday regarding this debate, in which he said that it is women who are responsible for depopulation. That he has given us to go out to work and not to stay in our homes with children. This is an insult to women. (Loud applause) An insult to women who have decided to be free to work inside or outside our homes. We have decided to be free to decide if we want to be mothers or not. That is why I ask the Bureau of Parliament to study these statements to see if any sanction is possible in this regard, because it is totally unacceptable. (Applause and boos) And I want to say to your honorable Members that those who really should stay at home are the misogynists who do not respect the women who have decided to be free. (Applause)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: - Mr President, my point of order is based on the article which provides for sanctions for Members. I would like to say that I do not always share, far from it, the opinions or words of Mr Korwin-Mikke but, being a former Member of this Parliament, I do not hide from you, my dear colleagues, that I am quite worried about the repressive drift which is manifesting itself more and more. In the past, the President and the Bureau of Parliament could only sanction members of Parliament seriously disrupting the work of the assembly. But more and more it seems that those who say incorrect words - but who will decide whether to correct or incorrectly say something? - may be sanctioned, may have their allowances punctured, stigmatized by the Bureau of Parliament. I believe that this is a drift as dangerous as the one we have seen, with respect to the European arrest warrant used today against a person, Mr Puigdemont, whom I do not I do not share the convictions at all, I am not in favor of the independence of Catalonia, but I consider it abnormal that this European arrest warrant is used against an indisputably political refugee.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman!Here, Mrs García Pérez did an outrageous thing, namely, she spoke out against freedom of speech, which is the foundation of the European Union.I am asking the Bureau to take a position on such scandalous statements.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: Voting time is over.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to support the Saving Lives: Boosting Car Safety in the EU report, including its section on newly qualified drivers. Despite years of hard-hitting campaigns, one in eight deaths on British roads still involves a driver over the drink—drive limit, and it is newly qualified drivers in their 20s who have the highest rates of drink—driving crashes. Not a single drop of alcohol before driving for newly qualified drivers is a simple and easy message. Yes, it is a controversial recommendation, but I believe it would save lives. As we have heard, alcohol bans for young and newly qualified drivers are already in place in other European countries, including Germany, Switzerland and Croatia. So I urge the British Government to take heed of this report and back the British Medical Association and the road safety charity, Brake, who have also called for the law to be tightened. We can stop needless, tragic deaths – so let us do it.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - We are talking about a very important topic, namely road safety in the European Union.It is important because it affects virtually all citizens of the Member States, and the consequences of this safety are terrifying: more than 25,000 deaths per year, more than 140,000 seriously injured, 43% of whom are pedestrians and cyclists.Therefore, we should take very important and effective measures, and on three levels: the first is the one that concerns people, the second is the one that concerns infrastructure, and the third, of course, concerns the vehicles themselves, especially since three-quarters of vehicles traveling on the European Union's roadsthere are no driver assistance systems.This is a great challenge for the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I want to congratulate the rapporteur for this good report on an issue that is of the utmost importance, and that is that road safety in the European Union causes some 25,500 deaths a year and more than 135,000 serious injuries, which are about absolutely dramatic figures. Half of the victims are found in urban environments and statistics show that, while the number and severity of those injured inside vehicles is reduced, the percentage of victims among non-motorized users, pedestrians and cyclists, continues to increase. increase. Better vehicle design, automatic alert systems, lower blood alcohol levels, we have made much progress on these issues and we will continue to advance, but today, now, we must encourage our cities to prioritize this issue in their urban agendas and adopt measures that, with minimal and perfectly affordable costs, have enormous effects on the safety of its inhabitants, such as limiting the speed of urban traffic, limiting the number of private vehicles in the urban area and opting for quality public collective transport that guarantees a accessible, inclusive and safe mobility for all.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, this report is not really about car safety. It is about where the proper boundary should be drawn between regional, national and European authorities. I am required, as a matter of EU law, to carry my children around in car seats until they reach a certain age or a minimum height. I had been looking forward to discarding the wretched yogurt-encrusted blobs at a much earlier stage – I speak obviously of the car seats, not of the children. You might think that makes me a terrible father, or you might think that it is a question of freedom, but that isn’t really the point. The point is, how on earth did we reach this point where this cannot be decided by our national democratic mechanisms and procedures? Where is the cross-border element? How is this a matter for proper international jurisdiction? If the European Union restricted itself to those parts of jurisdiction that are genuinely in their nature international, no one would have had a problem with it. There would not have been a British referendum. The problem is, it doesn’t know when to stop.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an important report, and I believe that people's lives cannot be put in front of anything else, and I believe that road safety is in our and the Commission's attention because it is important. I also said in the debate: I think we need to take into account who influences transport security. -On the one hand, the quality of the infrastructure. If we do not correlate the programs, as the European funds, the structural funds, the strategic investment fund will be directed towards improving the infrastructure, there will continue to be accidents and families losing their lives on the roads of the European Union. We must also take into account an improvement in the qualification of drivers and this professional training must be uniform because otherwise we cannot talk about mobility in the single market. I support the report and I congratulate the rapporteur and I hope that we will actually improve road safety.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: - 25 000 deaths in a year in the European Union and 135 000 seriously injured represent tragedies and terrible numbers that affect everyone, really all of us, telling the story of everyday life on the streets of the very modern Europe.Improving road safety in the European Union is a primary element, if not to eliminate these numbers altogether, certainly to significantly reduce the statistics.Safety technologies to be included in the next revision of the legislation, such as driver assistance, automatic emergency braking and intelligent speed control assistance are priorities and must become standard features as soon as possible, but truly across Europe.However, this alone is not enough.We must demand that, if non-conformities are found, European consumers must be able to rely on rapid, adequate and coordinated corrective measures.Only in this way will we be able to contribute to a process that will avoid a massacre on the roads.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Europe’s roads are becoming safer each year. However, the number of fatalities still exceeds 25 000 a year. Hence I strongly support this proposal to take extra measures aimed at reducing the number of incidents on the roads. We need to ensure that there is the necessary infrastructure, especially in urban areas, so that pedestrians and cyclists are not at risk. In addition, we should not neglect the vehicle factor, which is fundamental for road safety, as the majority of incidents are caused by human error. If we installed mandatory safety-related driver assistance systems as singled out in these proposals, it could prevent some of those incidents by assisting and correcting drivers’ behaviour. We should live under the principle that even one saved life on the roads matters.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, 730 killed on Belgian roads, 4,200 seriously injured. Behind the figures, which are terrible, so many tragedies experienced each year by parents and families. In Europe, more than 25,000 people lose their lives at the wheel or because of it. This trend is on the decline - as has been said - but one question remains nagging: how to improve safety on the roads? The Lebrecht Koch report on strengthening vehicle safety, which we have just adopted this afternoon, contains some interesting proposals, for example: the obligation to install intelligent driving safety systems in every new vehicle. This is obviously insufficient, we must go further, this is what the organizers of the conference which took place last Friday in Brussels around the LISA Car project (Light and save car, light and safe) are asking for. . It is essential that Europe works alongside car manufacturers in making cars that are lighter and less powerful and puts in place a regulatory framework that truly protects the environment and the physical integrity of all road users .

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: -  Sir. Chairman! It is not just a mistake when the House here and the EU as an institution believe that any problem that may be on the continent is a problem that the EU must solve. In fact, it is a fundamental expression of a mistrust relationship between the EU and the Member States. For precisely an issue such as road safety is not a matter for the EU. It is clearly something that must be handled regionally or nationally, where we, with all due respect for the House here, have politicians who are typically elected with a much larger number of votes and thus a much larger democratic mandate than most in this House. This is where democracy rests, and if the EU wanted something to do with itself, would take itself seriously, then it did so first and foremost by taking the principle of subsidiarity / subsidiarity seriously. But that means, of course, that the house here gets far less to do. If you only have to deal with the things that are really cross-border, then there will be fewer things to mess with. On the other hand, national parliaments will have more influence, and this will fundamentally give the EU a greater flourishing of the population as well. Is not it worth taking?

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman! I voted against the report because the authors of the report seem to think that drivers are idiots who want to kill people and die themselves, which is not true. However, there is one disturbing thing, the death penalty is a very effective means of punishing people, and that is why drivers break various regulations, but never or almost never enforce priority, because it carries the death penalty on the spot. Well, there is not a single word in this report about a single threat, which is the introduction of autonomous vehicles. If autonomous vehicles appear, the driver of that vehicle will not be afraid to die. The guarantee of safety is that other drivers are afraid of dying, and therefore do not force you to take precedence. If autonomous vehicles appear, there will be no more road safety. I will be afraid to drive along such a road and there is not a word about it in the report, and this is the basic threat. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, unfortunately, about 92% of all accidents are due to the human factor or to the interaction of the wrong human factor with vehicles or even infrastructure. However, in addition to the development and implementation of driver and vehicle safety-oriented safety systems, considerable emphasis must also be placed on improving the condition of road infrastructure, in particular through regular and efficient maintenance of road and road marking systems and through appropriate upgrades to deal with traffic congestion. I am voting in favor of this report because it is moving in the right direction in terms of formulating existing legislation to ensure road safety at pan-European level, with effective and regular roadside checks, funding for new road infrastructure and strengthening research. and technology in cars.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, I am voting in favor of this report because it sets out basic definitions and statistical criteria for the various territorial typologies, so that there is a common point of reference for drawing conclusions and shaping the Union's regional policy. Although there is currently no choice of different territorial levels and data by Member States, in a way that the variation in the size of the territorial units is as small as possible, the report is moving in the right direction. Statistical tools need to be further improved, be technology-neutral, up-to-date and always tailored to ensure the best quality of reality capture.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! On several occasions, we have noted the sensitivity of a language. I remember how people laughed and shook their heads when Commission President Juncker once suggested that Brexit would mean that we would no longer be allowed to speak English in the room here or in the EU institutions. In this way, the language touches us wherever we are, and I voted in favor of the strategy that future reports and statistics, etc., should also be available in regional languages ​​and dialects. But precisely because it is such a sensitive area, it is essential that it kind of goes through the national responsible democratic authorities. Handling regional languages ​​can have major political and emotional implications, and I honestly fear that the European Union may very well act like an elephant in a glass shop if you just roll over. So it is extremely important that we have the national authorities with us if we want to promote the local and regional languages. I think that is important in this report.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Inland navigation is an essential element of the transport system in the European Union. As much as 6% of goods are transported in this way. However, more importantly, in recent years, the European Commission has put a significant emphasis on the development of the inland navigation sector, among others due to the relatively low environmental impact. However, the Commission's plans may be frustrated by the problem of the shortage of skilled workers. The average age of inland seafarers is 55 years, additionally, the existing regulations hinder their mobility between the Member States, because there is no consistent system of recognition of qualifications, and the existing one concerns only skippers and does not cover all rivers. Therefore, I welcome the Commission's legislative proposal. The new directive has the potential to improve the situation in the sector, in particular to facilitate the shift to inland navigation of seafarers and fishermen. However, its most important element is the establishment of a harmonized examination system with qualifications recognized in all Member States. Inland shipping is a very important topic from the point of view of the region I come from. I hope that this directive will be properly implemented by the Member States and will significantly improve the supply of skilled workers on the labor market.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – I voted against this proposal. Via its energy policies the European Union has taken control over the industrial base. Via its climate policies it has taken control over the power and air transport sector, and via this directive and the amendment it is taking full control over the major rivers and canals in the European Union. The directive insists upon training requirements and certification, safety standards, environmental controls, workers’ and women’s rights, and so on. Crucially, and I emphasise ‘crucially’, it then demands that all the data related to waterway traffic is passed to and held by the Commission. This is yet another of the European Union’s salami tactics decided on and driven towards ever closer union. Fine if you are an EU arch-federalist, not fine if you are a Euro-sceptic like myself.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: - Sir. Chairman! In the field of labor market, it is extremely sensitive how and when the EU legislates. In my country, Denmark, we have experienced how the EU has tumbled over old traditions and well-functioning institutions, such as our collective agreements and other things that have done more harm than good to the labor market. In this area, which is about mobility, which is about goods and thus also workers having to be able to move by sea between countries, it may of course make sense to have common rules, provided that these common rules respect national rules, which exists as a starting point. As far as I read this report, it is for once fulfilled, contrary to what we have seen, among other things. with the Posting of Workers Directive and the Temporary Workers Directive. I have therefore voted in favor of this report. I would like to emphasize that it is a yes that is conditional and that I will constantly monitor whether the Commission goes further and exceeds its powers. If it does, it will at the same time lose our support.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!Consumer protection is one of the greatest challenges in the single market that is being built in the European Union, if only because the market consisting of twenty-eight countries today (we will see what this number will be in the future) is a market that certainly creates many pathologies.One of the biggest problems is the digital market.As many as 68% of consumers who report to the European Consumer Center complain about electronic commerce.Therefore, in the European Union, we need to increase cooperation and cooperation on the European market of all consumer protection authorities from the Member States.This is a great task, which is why I support today's report.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this proposal. It aims to make the existing rules for cooperation among Member States on consumer protection laws be enforced more effectively. Taking into account an increase in international retail traffic and challenges related to the digital single market, adapting the rules is crucial in order to protect our citizens’ rights and their economic interests when doing e-commerce online or using other services of the internal market. For this we need to fight secrecy, have adequate consumer protection legislation and its enforcement plans in place, and of course ensure a functioning database among Member States and swift information exchange.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I supported Mrs Sehnal's draft report because I really see cross-border cooperation between national authorities, which can directly support more effective supervision, investigation or prosecution of cross-border infringements, as one of the basic pillars of compliance with the law to protect consumers' interests. Given that traders are constantly expanding their scope in the single market, possible infringements of consumer rights must also be treated in the same way. The revised regulations must therefore define the enforcement mechanisms used by national authorities to eliminate illegal practices and are applicable in all Member States. I thus see the Commission's proposal, which introduces new concepts, such as large-scale infringements of consumer protection legislation with a Union dimension or a new alert mechanism, as a real step forward, and I supported them.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! Mr. Polčák is in the first place, that's why I thought he would be the first to perform. Demographic change is one of the greatest challenges for the European Union and its Member States. The shrinking working age population weakens the potential of our economy, and in the near future may contribute to the collapse of pension systems. Most specialists believe that an appropriate solution to the problem can be prepared primarily at the regional level, mainly due to the diverse sources of demographic changes. That is why I am delighted that the European Parliament's Committee on Regional Development has prepared a report with recommendations for action at the level of the European Union and in the Member States, which I was pleased to vote in favor of. On this occasion, I would like to draw your attention to the program carried out in the region I come from, in the Opolskie Voivodeship. The demographic situation in my region is one of the most difficult in the entire Union. In order to approach the problem comprehensively, a special demographic zone program was created. The adopted program consists of four packages concerning work, education, nursery and kindergarten care and the elderly. The program is a good example of the use of cohesion policy instruments by regional authorities to counteract negative demographic changes. I am convinced that the experiences of my home region may be helpful in future attempts to use EU funds to counteract depopulation of other areas in Europe.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman!Europe is aging, the productive population is expected to drop from 66% to 56% in 2080, and the population over 65 is expected to increase from 19% to 29%.Therefore, the attitude of economically active people to those who will no longer work will change very dangerously.From today's four to one ratio, it will drop to two to one.Despite the frightening prospects, it seems that the European Union does not have a cross-cutting European strategy for solving demographic problems.This seems to be one of the greatest challenges of this century and we should face it now, today, including by using the financial instruments of the European Union with a range of funds, including the Cohesion Fund.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: - Indeed, low birth rates, a shortage of young people, an aging society, emigration are many concerns, and rightly so. We all understand that a Europe without Europeans as a project has no future. We all need to understand that the demographic dimension that we are talking about in this report is and must be an important part of regional policy. The question is how to implement this regional policy and how to better mobilize those funds or those policies that must lead to a better demographic situation. I might question the proposals we are adopting today, although I agree with the joint decision. I believe that economic policy, job creation and viability in certain regions must be our response, rather than the very generous development of social policy in those regions. Families need to be supported throughout Europe, including in my country, Lithuania. Exclusive support for families somewhere in individual regions will create a sense of inequality, not the other way around. Therefore, I hope that with this decision, we will have the opportunity to improve it.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: - Mr President, migration, low birth rates and population aging are not new phenomena. What is new in this case is that the intensity is much higher. According to the National Statistical Institute in Bulgaria, every second person who has left the country is under 39 years old. Young and educated people choose a one-way ticket for better realization and a better future in general. In addition, our country is about to fall into the ranking of hyper-aging societies worldwide. I wonder when these statistics will finally startle the government in Bulgaria to start working purposefully to deal with this problem. A targeted approach is also needed at European level. I believe that cohesion policy must play a key role in this process. In the Multiannual Financial Framework after 2020, I believe that a special resource must be provided for those European regions that are most severely affected by demographic change.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we are talking about various crises here, but with the real crisis in Europe, we are dying out. I am therefore pleased that Mrs García Pérez has found that helping regions in the European Union means improving the living conditions of young, old and children, and then adults will not have to leave their families to work in other regions or countries. and thus jeopardize the development of their families. It is important to build society in such a way as to rebuild intergenerational family relationships. The European Union can help to do this by resolving that democratic crisis, precisely by building regional infrastructure, a culture of life and by embracing family traditions. After all, the future of Europe is our children who grow up in healthy and natural families. Where is there, please, the appreciation of mothers and fathers and natural families? Why do we donate millions to support various LGBTI projects and do not support prolife projects or large families in equal parts. Yes, family policy is a matter for the Member States and should remain so, but if we want Europe to have hope, it is necessary to protect the lives of our children, including those conceived and unborn. That is why I encourage you, let us take this path and we will grow and I will not have a demographic problem and we will not die.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt about it, but demographic change is a significant strategic challenge for all of Europe. The Eurostat projection figures have revealed the decreasing labour force, which is expected to decline by 1.9 million people by 2020. Throughout the period 2008-2030, population decline is anticipated in one-third of European regions. Furthermore, it is predicted that the proportion of persons over the age of 65 will increase from 18.9 % in 2015 to 28.7 % in 2080. Thankfully in my own country, while we will have an aging population, we do have a very young population as well. The highest proportion of young people in the total population is 21.9 %. This of course offers its own challenges, especially in creating employment. The demographic change will affect education systems, health and community services. I am pleased that this was addressed by our new leader Leo Varadkar at our national convention at the weekend and he will be speaking before Parliament here in the new year.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to emphasize that I see a number of positive moments in this report. It is a fact that demographic change is the most significant challenge for the Member States of the European Union and for Europe in general in this century. However, as positive as I am that this report addresses these moments, it is important to say that this report also says, in principle, that the GDP criterion for providing support under the cohesion funds should be weakened. And the rapporteur looked a little at the door she opened, but did not say what the involvement of the other criteria should be in the distribution of cohesion policy. I believe that it is important that this criterion of GDP remains as the primary one, and precisely for those economies that do not have such a strong performance, this criterion remains as the main one, possibly supplemented by demographic indicators. Those economies that are efficient and those demographic indicators must be able to manage within their own economic parameters.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the financial and banks services in the EU is the area where the internal market has not progressed as far as we might have wished. The numbers are astonishing. For example, 92% of the respondents in the Eurobarometer Survey said that they have never purchased any financial products or services in countries other than their own. Less than 20 of these respondents have any bank account, any credit account, anything in states other than their own and, most gravely, if you have one, you will probably be considered a criminal. We have to change this. One way of changing it is with this file, with its clear proposals ending territorial restrictions, enhancing transparency of cross-border fees, and making it easier for consumers to change financial services and providers. These are crucial steps we need to take, and that is why I voted for this file.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, I am voting against the report on the Retail Financial Services Action Plan, although it has a number of positive points and the right points. However, the Union's policy on the retail financial services market has helped to raise product prices, reduce competitiveness, increase consumer suspicion and the slow death of the retail financial services sector. Organized interests, entanglement and unfair competition fuel fraud, ruthless taxation, insolvency of consumer appeal services, while at the same time putting obstacles in the way of most retail financial services, such as online banking, financial services, foreign exchange transactions, sales of insurance products, etc. Finally, I would like to point out that any legislative initiative to improve existing rules should be accompanied by a procedural system of penalties and sanctions for offenders at EU level, otherwise it is doomed to obscurity and disrepute.

name: Lucy Anderson (S&D).
text: – Mr President, this report underlines that the retail financial services market requires innovation in order genuinely to help consumers and businesses. I welcome that fact. It also shows that there needs to be a focus on ensuring prevention of predatory lending and payday loans, which have resulted in the exploitation of small businesses and individual consumers, particularly the vulnerable, across the EU. It is therefore vital that, in order to do so, the relevant European financial supervisors are given the appropriate resources to fulfil their full range of duties. A strong regulatory system will increase consumer confidence and the internal market cannot function properly without strong consumer protection mechanisms. Additionally, developing retail financial services should not be to the detriment of more traditional methods of banking and should bear in mind the needs of those who prefer face-to-face interaction. The report acknowledges that branch closures destroy community cohesion and are detrimental to the development of good financial services at a local level. This was reflected in the final text and that is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for the debate on Council and Commission statements on the rule of law in Malta (2017/2935 (RSP)).

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, common values such as human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and human rights are the cornerstone of the European Union. Each Member State must therefore respect, protect and promote them. Three weeks ago I intervened in this Chamber after the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia. We all condemned this barbaric crime and expressed the expectation that the perpetrators would be brought to justice.  We were all in agreement that media freedom is an indispensable pillar of our democratic societies. For this reason, freedom of expression, media freedom and pluralism are guaranteed in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. They are among the core basic democratic values on which the European Union is founded. In October, the Council held its annual rule of law dialogue, which was an important opportunity to take a critical look at the rule of law situation in the Member States and the Union. This year the dialogue was about media pluralism in the digital age and about the challenges that the digital age brings to the rule of law. In the context of that debate, all Member States agreed that free, reliable and pluralistic media underpins effective democracy.  The continued debate on these issues shows again that the protection and promotion of the rule of law and human rights are a constant challenge. This challenge requires unwavering attention and efforts across different policy areas. Our core values are put to the test every day. Our societies are still facing multiple inter—related crises, be it in the area of migration or internal security. Discussions such as the one today are important. Our citizens must be able to have trust in the functioning of our democratic institutions.  We commend the Maltese Government for having acted immediately as news broke of the assassination to ensure that justice is done. The Maltese authorities also opened up their investigations and sought international assistance. The police force asked for assistance and teamed up with the American FBI, Dutch and Italian forensic forces, as well as Europol, to make sure that no stone is left unturned in the investigation. I would like to recall the readiness of the Member States to help in all matters as needed.  Malta has shown that its institutions are well—functioning in responding to this challenge. Ensuring the rule of law is an absolute priority and has to be our joint commitment – of the Member States and of EU institutions together. Equally, fundamental rights need to be upheld and defended as our best guarantee for sustaining stable, open and free societies. We trust that the Maltese authorities will ensure that justice will be delivered in the case of the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. I will listen to the debate with great interest.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it has been ten days since the world witnessed Daphne Caruana Galizia’s funeral in Malta. A nation in mourning. We all saw it.  The Commission condemned this brutal assassination in the strongest words possible. The rights of a journalist and blogger to investigate, to ask uncomfortable questions and to report effectively is at the heart of our values and needs to be guaranteed at all times. There can be no free and democratic societies without free media. The Commission takes the view that ensuring an independent and thorough investigation of the facts and bringing those responsible to justice must be the top priority for the Maltese Government. The Maltese authorities and institutions must deliver on their clear commitment to do everything in their power to ensure that the perpetrators will be brought to justice. More generally, Malta needs to show to Europe – and indeed the world – that its rules and regulations are healthy and robust. This is why it is important that the Maltese Government has indicated that the investigation and prosecution should be allowed to run their full course regardless of the consequences. I want to add that, on every occasion that I have to talk to members of the Maltese Government, I make this point and it is acknowledged by them that they will do so and that they will commit to that.  But this also includes making sure that the rules that we agreed at European level are implemented on the ground. The fight against money laundering, for instance, is a key priority for the Commission in this respect. With regard to the issue of money laundering in Malta, the Commission has conducted a fact-finding exercise and an analysis. The guiding principle was to identify quality and reliable data. The facts as they resulted from our analysis – and let me stress this – raise no general concerns on Malta’s overall compliance. However, improvements could be made on various levels. In this context, the Commission recently sent a letter to the Maltese authorities regarding follow-up investigations to recommendations after the Maltese Financial Intelligence and Analysis Unit published its report, and we are now carefully studying their comprehensive reply. As part of our efforts in the fight against money laundering, moreover, we are making sure that all Member States, including Malta, adopt the necessary provisions to transpose the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive. The Commission decision on infringement proceedings against those Member States which have not yet notified their national transposition laws is imminent. We encourage those Member States to adopt the necessary rules now, without further delay. The Commission regularly collects data on the functioning of the judicial systems of all Member States in the EU Justice Scoreboard, and we are monitoring corruption in Member States as part of the European Semester. The Commission agrees with Parliament that we need to improve the protection of whistle—blowers throughout the EU. The revision of the Fourth Anti—Money Laundering Directive, currently under negotiation between Parliament and the Council, will enhance the powers of the competent authorities to prevent and fight money laundering. I hope that this legislation will be adopted soon. Finally, the Commission encourages Malta to swiftly join the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. This would send a strong positive signal of Malta’s commitment to working actively together in the area of freedom, security and justice. In conclusion, let me say that every time I have the occasion to meet with the Maltese authorities – I met with the Minister for European Affairs and Equality, Ms Dalli, and the Minister for Justice, Culture and Local Government, Mr Bonnici, last week – they have clearly expressed their determination to do whatever is necessary to make sure that these things are implemented to the full, and also to make sure that those responsible for this atrocious crime are brought to justice. The commitment of the Maltese Government on this was made very clear to all its partners in Europe.

name: Esteban González Pons
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, this Thursday it will be one month since the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia and we do not yet know who killed her, who ordered the killing and who supported the killers.  I am ashamed, and we all should be ashamed because without this killing we would never have known here what happens in Malta: journalists being harassed, denounced and even killed, media houses being blackmailed by banks suspected of money laundering and tax evasion, high government officials suspected of being implicated also in the same operations, and police authorities refusing to investigate those allegations because they have been appointed by and have economic and personal ties with the government.  We cannot remain silent, so today we ask for three concrete actions. First, we want the Commission to immediately launch a rule of law dialogue with Malta. Second, we want the Maltese authorities to investigate and to prosecute money laundering, no matter the names or the organisations implicated. Thirdly, we want an independent and international investigation into the killing of Daphne Caruana Galizia.  We have to say, loud and clear, that Europe’s values and principles are much more important than money. Daphne’s moral legacy belongs to Europe now. Europe is about justice, about separation of powers and about the rule of law. Everybody knows that. But Europe is also about freedom, transparency and truth. Every time Europe has faced the abyss, the ballpoint pen of a journalist has been the last defensive line for our democracy. This is the Europe Daphne Caruana Galizia dreamed of and wanted, and so do we.

name: Tanja Fajon
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - The brutal assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia has raised many questions about media freedom. Freedom of expression and the media is the key to the existence of democracy, so these issues are of particular concern to me. My Maltese colleagues assure me that the Government is making every effort to investigate the murder, which has involved independent international experts and organizations. I very much welcome that. I also welcome the modernization and radical substantive changes in the field of media and other laws, especially with regard to defamation, protection of applicants or whistleblowers, the abolition of censorship for works of art, and the financing of political parties. The assassination has also exacerbated issues of corruption, particularly in political elites, money laundering, the involvement of politicians in scandals, the role of banks, reports of the sale of citizenship, and the politicization of some public institutions. And we expect answers to all these questions. Nevertheless, I cannot welcome the greatly exaggerated reactions of colleagues, especially from the EPP, who after the murder of the journalist announce that there has been a collapse of the rule of law and the system in Malta. I do not agree with that, colleagues. The fact is that many countries in the European Union are facing a narrowing of the space for media freedom, corruption, involvement in financial scandals and reducing the independence of the judiciary, the activities of civil society. Only in the case of Hungary or Poland, which have quite a few serious systemic problems in guaranteeing fundamental rights, is it clear that together we can have legitimate concerns about the functioning of the rule of law. At the moment, it is important, firstly, for the Maltese Government to conduct and present a murder investigation in a transparent manner and to work with Member States and EU institutions to address all these concerns, and secondly, to be united in the fight for the rule of law and citizens. same wattle. (The speaker rejected the question by raising a blue card by Paulo Rangel)

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam president; Malta: 436,000 inhabitants and a handful of heroes. Since October 16, one less person of integrity. Daphne Caruana was forced to have a heroic behavior because some inhabitants did not want or want to know, others consent, others remain silent, while some are corrupting banks and spaces of power. International money laundering leaks have put Malta in the mirror and in the spotlight. The rule of law has failed and Daphne suffered civil and economic death, lawsuits, accounts blocked before her murder. Every European citizen must know about Daphne's murder, because her inducers cannot control everything. Commissioner Moscovici, this morning, indicated that there are systematic global and organized practices of tax avoidance and evasion. One leak after another, one journalistic investigation after another ... We know that supervisory bodies fail, Member States fail, lists of tax havens fail. But, in some places, corruption reaches the heart of the state, and when it does, freedom of expression formally exists, but it carries risks. Daphne collaborated with this Parliament through the commission of inquiry into the Panama Papers headed by Mr. Langen, who is here. Thanks to the leaks, we have been able to have a systematic overview of how national legislation and the standards of national and international control and supervision bodies are circumvented; how organized crime and certain oligarchs act globally. For more than a year, in the commission of inquiry on the Panama papers we have indicated that there is a structural problem in Malta that weakens democracy, due to this global scourge. In Malta, but not only in Malta - and I say this sadly - also in my country, with enough money you buy from citizens, and that should be prohibited. Daphne worked the Maltese slopes.She told everything she knew, and now our obligation is not to forget, to avoid impunity, but not only about her murder, but also about what she denounced and what she was killed for.We must do it in self-defense, because these forms of crime that she denounced can rot each of our democracies.Crocodile tears are not worth the impunity, neither of the Commission nor of the Council.Mr Timmermans, Mr Juncker must quarantine his friendship with Mr Muscat until the murder and the state of democracy in Malta are clarified.In the 21st century, democracy is being played against populists, but also against international crime.Our Resolution must therefore be translated into action.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the cowardly assassination of our colleague journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia only raises the lid on the failure of the government of Malta to respect the so-called rule of law. This is because she denounced multiple practices contrary to what we call "our values", including the sale of nationality to the highest bidder, the change of the chief of police five times in four years, tax evasion. and money laundering, and the camouflage of Azerbaijani corruption that she was murdered. If the European Union is truly a community of law, it cannot tolerate such obvious breaches of its principles and must urgently modify its instruments to enforce precisely this rule of law, just as it can no longer tolerate fiscal practices. States which undermine one of the bases of our democracies, and undoubtedly of civilization, equality before taxes.

name: Sven Giegold
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to say clearly why we are here today, and why we are here today again after such short notice. The last discussion focused, also in the response by the Council and the Commission, very much on the precise death and murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia, but we did not discuss seriously the wider issues. Today again, the Council has not answered the questions concerning the rule of law we have raised in our resolution, and therefore I was very disappointed by your response. While the Commission today has given much clearer answers than last time, I would like to stress that several issues are still open and, Mr Timmermans, I hope your notebook is open for these issues. How is it possible that the Head of the Financial Services Authority, Mr Bannister, is, at the same time, the vice-president of the Financial Development Agency of Malta? This is basically saying that the boss of the supervisors is at the same time the boss of those who should develop the sector. Therefore, the Commission should take action to clarify what the status of a financial supervisor is, and what conflicts of interest in that area mean. Malta has recently had big financial and economic success with online gambling and I would like to say on behalf of our Group that there is nothing wrong with online gambling as such, but there is a problem if the cross-border provision of these services is based on hyper-low taxation, and secondly, on the illegal provision across borders through the internet, which allows financial companies to make at least EUR 1 billion just for the transfers to the respective societies. So the question is: isn’t there a hole in the application of national and European law in the area of online gambling? There were also important questions about the buying of voters in the last Maltese elections, and there is the question why do Nexia BT and Pilatus Bank still have licences in Malta? So there are serious issues which were not on your list, Mr Timmermans. Will you commit today to look into these subjects and take seriously the questions that Parliament is raising?

name: Monica Macovei
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, thousands of people took to the streets demanding justice for Daphne Caruana Galicia, killed, I recall, in the anti-corruption crusade in Malta. They protested against the corruption that kills. Her colleagues said, "The killers didn't kill his spirit, they won't be able to silence us all!" and the people shouted, "Don't take democracy to the desert!" What happened after Dahpne's death? Paradise Papers have appeared and we have over thirteen million new documents that show us the enormous scale of corruption and money laundering. Everything happens here, before our eyes and in Europe and with our complicity, if we do nothing. Daphne was right, and that's why she died. We are complicit because we do not fight to the end, if we do not fight to the end, for the abolition of tax havens, for the elimination of bearer shares, for public access, total, to the real beneficiaries of shares in all private or state companies and many others. things that could eliminate this war against people, honest people, this war of those who get rich and make billions through corruption, fraud, money laundering and manage to escape the law. We have not been silenced and we will go further and further with the spirit of Daphne in us.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, obviously our heartfelt condolences go out to the family of Daphne Caruana Galizia. The murderers and those who instructed them to carry out this awful deed must be found and brought to justice, whoever they may be. This situation, though, must not be used as an oyster knife to open the judicial system of Malta and the other nation states to interference by the European Union. Rather, it is an opportunity for Malta itself, as a sovereign nation, to expunge the taints of gangsterism. Malta has proven itself in the past to be a proud and brave nation, and this is an opportunity to show that it is still that nation, and to honour the life and the memory of Daphne Caruana Galizia.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the island of Malta is one of the cradles of European civilization. It is a strategic island in the Mediterranean, at a time when the Mediterranean was completely transformed. Unfortunately, however, the island of Malta is not having its best days today. The island of Malta today has two problems. On the one hand, tax evasion and, on the other hand, corruption. Tax evasion, because we talked about it with the "Paradise Papers", but also for VAT fraud. As for corruption, unfortunately, it is a widespread problem in a number of states that make up the European Union. Can we add that a criminal gang now runs this small state? At a time when Madrid and Warsaw are being violently attacked, where Spain and Poland are the victims of the European Union, I believe that it is time today to point out the real culprits and that it is time that the Union send a mission of European parliamentarians to examine what is happening on the island of Malta.

name: Frank Engel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Ms Fajon has said that the European People’s Party (the PPE) is insinuating that the rule of law in Malta has collapsed after the assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia. The truth is, we insinuate that the rule of law collapsed a long time before that murder and that this murder is one of the consequences of the total collapse of the rule of law in Malta, that it is one of the consequences of the privatisation of state institutions, the subjugation of institutions of state to the private interests of the highest actors of the state, and of one particular party that created the atmosphere, created the circumstances in which such a heinous crime could take place in the 21st century in the middle of the European Union.  The contempt in which the Maltese Government holds this House, by the way, has never been more visible than by the fact that Mr Maasikas has to defend Malta in this debate. Have we ever seen the Hungarian Prime Minister – and everyone knows that I am not carrying him in my heart – refusing or cowing out from defending his country or a potential attack on his country in this House. We have never seen anything like that. We now see Mr Maasikas, who has nothing to do with the corrupt practices of the Maltese Government, having to stand up for something which is indefensible and unjustifiable.  Some of Daphne’s last written words were: ‘there are crooks everywhere you look, the situation is desperate’. Well, depending on where you looked, you always saw the same thing and that is prominent people from Azerbaijan – very prominent people from Azerbaijan – in the company of very prominent people from Malta – virtually half the leadership of the Labour Party, be that the Prime Minister, be that the Prime Minister and his small party who travelled there unaccompanied and brought back I don’t know what, or be that Mr Farrugia, who is still the speaker of the Parliament of Malta and who has nothing better to do than regularly travel there and applaud them for the brilliant elections that they hold.  This is what has rotted Malta through – the fact that a country like Azerbaijan could insinuate itself in the form of a bank called Pilatus, in the heart of a European democracy, and from there reach out its tentacles to stifle democratic expression. This is what we are confronted with. This is why this murder needs to be investigated. And this is why no angle needs to be left untouched in this investigation.  (Applause)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Madam President, this House prides itself on being strong in the defence of human rights and the rule of law according to our common human European values, but to remain strong the action it takes must be based on due process that collects facts as evidence, puts them in context and assesses them as a whole. Otherwise this Parliament risks losing credibility. Worse, it risks devaluing the values that we all claim to believe in. A brutal assassination has taken place in Malta. It has shocked us all. Justice needs to be done. In the investigation the Maltese Government has called upon the Dutch and US police authorities, as well as Europol, for help, but the outcome of one murder investigation, whatever and whenever it is, cannot be held to reflect on the rule of law here or wherever. Malta is being assailed for perceived deficiencies in the rule of law on the basis of jumbled facts and semi—facts, unproven allegations taken at face value, innuendos and issues irrelevant to the rule of law. Is this being done as a tit—for—tat related to processes about the rule of law that other Member States are being subjected to? Yet the Maltese Government has repeatedly agreed to receive delegations of this Parliament to investigate issues that are raised and it is still doing so. It has accepted – indeed invited – Commission scrutiny over a variety of areas, as Mr Timmermans has told us. Partisanship over the rule of law will undermine the moral basis of this House, when it has to raise issues related to it. This is being done because, in the wash of interests and allegiances that define this House, it is easiest for EU Member States to overlook Malta’s realities and to cast doubts on the motives of the Maltese Government. Yet that Government has just been re—elected with an absolute majority, possessed by no other party that is represented in this House. It has guided the Maltese economy towards growth rates that are among the highest – if not the highest – in Europe. Attitudes in a debate like this should be objective. They are being tendentious. We need well—informed assessments. Instead we have prejudice and polemical opinions brewed like instant coffee. Subjected to such a methodology, all Member States can be made to smell foul. If the joint motion before us passes as written, the credentials of this Parliament to really show how to defend European values transparently and honestly could well be put at risk.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR).
text: - Madam President! There was a terrible murder in Malta. But the subject of this debate is not this murder, the condemnation of which we all agree, but the subject of this debate is the issue of the rule of law in Malta. Mr Engel has put it very well, Mr Sant has just given a different opinion on it. In these two speeches - and I hope in many that will now follow - the crucial questions will be asked: What about the rule of law in Malta? What about the rule of law in a state that simply sells its citizenships? Just as the Catholic Church used to sell its offices, so citizenships are sold! And then you even hear in the debate that things are also going on in Spain, which I didn't know before. We have to ask: what about the defamation laws in Malta, which are alleged to restrict the freedom of the press? We have to ask: What is this Pilatus Bank doing in Malta and is it set the appropriate limits? Those are the questions that need to be asked here. Does Malta still have the power to enforce its laws and are the laws designed to meet our needs in the European Union? That is the subject of the debate and not the condemnation of murder.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I must tell you that I am a little disturbed, even worried, by the intervention of our colleague S & amp; D who seems to minimize the disturbance which the situation inspires in Malta. The cowardly and abject assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia demands that the European Union and beyond the international community act in a determined and urgent manner to end illicit financial flows and tax havens. The work of whistleblowers and the media is essential in revealing the scale of tax fraud and tax evasion. Their protection must be legally guaranteed and reinforced throughout the territory of the Union. I am obviously very happy that we voted in favor of a general protection mechanism at European Union level, but we must go further and put in place a legal status for whistleblowers, which could if necessary, give rise to compensation. One thing particularly troubles me, Mr Ferrand, is that - and I regret it - Malta has chosen not to participate in the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which brings real added value in the protection of the Union's financial interests. Once in place, it would allow us to strengthen investigations into financial fraud and would be accountable for independent investigations. While the protection of the Union's financial interests is the shared responsibility of the Union and all its Member States, I find it shocking and unacceptable that Member States can evade their obligations to fight fraud, knowing that 'they benefit from European aid. I say it clearly, I think that the benefit of this aid should be made conditional on the participation of these countries in the European Public Prosecutor's Office. I knew you, Monsieur Ferrand and the more vigorous S & amp; D when it came to denouncing the failings of the state in relation to human rights.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, Mr Timmermans, there is a legitimate focus on Malta, no doubt about that, but I think the issue is unfortunately beyond the borders of that country. We live in a time of immersion in overly rich people, at a time when millions of people are below the poverty line. This money, the trillions - estimated by many - lost from tax evasion could well greatly boost the European Union's economy. I said that it goes far beyond Malta and let me refer to a Spiegel article where after evaluating thousands of pages of documents, it refers to reprehensible tactics of famous companies and talks about virtual subsidiaries of groups and branches of companies such as famous and BMW, BOSCH, BASF, Deutsche Bank and PUMA based in Malta. As Spiegel reveals, many of them are not even mentioned in the phone book, nor do they have staff, while 3 of them share the same bell. We need to focus on specific rules in order to devour - if possible - this system of tax evasion, gangsterism and crime.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: - Madam President, I have three bad news for Maltese Prime Minister Joseph Muscat. First, a re-election will never replace the work of justice. Suspicions of corruption and money laundering against those close to him taint his political action. The lack of investigation undermines her credibility. Second, Malta's tax rules must change. They undermine European cohesion and, more broadly, the future of the Union. The revelations of the "Paradise Papers" have ended up disgusting citizens, on whom austerity is imposed and who see their public services deteriorate. An infringement procedure, as mentioned by Commissioner Moscovici, would be a minimum. The European Union must go further and put an end to unfair tax competition within it. Third, the Maltese government needs to know that Daphne Caruana Galizia's investigative work will not end with her assassination. Other journalists will end it with the support of European citizens shocked that such horrors can occur in the heart of the European Union.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: - The death of a journalist, regardless of the country in which it took place, is a tragedy that must not happen again.Equally, the deaths of judges, prosecutors and police officers investigating corruption and other criminal offenses must not happen again.Perhaps the resolution we are proposing could finally be the starting point from which concrete steps should be taken to protect individual members of society, regardless of their profession status, from persecution and retaliation.I hope that this tragic case will not just be an opportunity for cheap politics and famous statements.Let the words of the resolution fall into the hearts of the Heads of Government and become well-functioning legislation.Human deaths must be stopped.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF).
text: - Madam President!“What's going on here, in beautiful Malta?” One would like to exclaim.“What's going on here?” One would like to ask the socialist family members of the socialist head of government Muscat here in the house.In any case, one thing is clear: there are very serious things that we are seeing in Malta.An investigative journalist is blown up with a car bomb in broad daylight.It is more reminiscent of the Netflix series Narcos, which is about the drug dealer Pablo Escobar, than of the political reality in the European Union.Unfortunately, that is the reality in Malta.In addition, more and more new facts and assumptions are emerging: drug trafficking and corruption.It is investigated there against drug dealers and corrupt politicians, but it is never brought to trial.I ask myself: What is wrong here in Malta?I think we should urgently ensure that we shed light on the darkness.

name: David Casa (PPE).
text: - Is-saltna tad-dritt hijada millħ ijjed valuri importanti u essenzjali għaliex mingħajrha, jikkrolla kollox. Kummissarju Timmermans, is-saltna tad-dritt tinqered: meta bank li jinqabad jaħsel il-flus ta ’dittaturi mill-Azerbaijan, jitħalla jopera f’Malta. Galiex? Għax qed jaħsel ukoll il-flus ta 'nies fil-Gvern Malti. meta l-Kummissarju tal-Pulizija jintgħażel speċifikament minħabba l-incompetenza tiegħu. meta l-FIAU, azenzija ta 'kontra l-ħasil ta' flus, tirrapporta korruzzjoni estensiva u bla precedent li timplika lill-Gvern; u l-Pulizija ma jieħdu l-ebda azzjoni; the correlation of the titular effect of the in-nickel implication of the human flesh; meta l-kultura ta ’impunità issir in-norma f’pajjiż, jikkrolla kollox. Kummissarju, illum qegħdin hawn magħqudin, biex ngħidulek li l-istat tad-dritt f’Malta għandu bżonn l-intervent immedjat u urġenti tiegħek. Dan mhux kliem ġdid għalik, Mr. Timmermans, għaliex jien u l-kollegi tiegħi ktibnilek uffiċċjalment xhur ilu, u ma sar xejn. Jien u l-kollegi tiegħi issottomettejna mistoqsijiet parliamentarians fuq din il-crisis, u ma sar xejn. This is the case with the establishment of a Parliamentary Assembly, which has been adopted. Tkomplux intom u l-Kunsill tiddefendu l-indifensibbli. Nappellalkom colleagues were involved in the work of the European Union, the European Union and the European Union. There are many correlations that can be found in the poplar. Din mhijiex kontlieda kontra il-poplu Malti, din hija ġlieda għall-poplu Malti, u lill-familja Caruana Galizia li qiegħda hawn magħna llum ngħidilhom, ommkom u l-mara tiegħek kienet mara bla biża, I will be able to help you, but I will help you. Iżjed iva milli le, kienet tispiċċa one-woman army, waħidha, tiġġieled il-korruzzjoni u l-abbuż tal-poter għax ħadd i öjed ma kellu l-kurġġli jagümmel dan magħha. Lil uliedha nixtieq ngħidilhom: mhux ser inħallu l-qtil ta 'Daphne jkun għal xejn, u jiena ngħidilha li bħala ħabiba tiegħi mhux ser inħalli li l-qtil tagħha jkun sar għal xejn.Rubber kits, ibda investiga dad.Mr Timmermans, let’s finish together what Daphne started;do not ignore us any more, please.(Applause)

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: – Madam President, one does not have to be a journalist, like I was for most of my life, to mourn over Daphne Caruana Galicia. This is a tragedy that concerns us all. Journalists in more and more countries live a dangerous life: they are harassed and coerced and are often thrown into prison, or, in countries such as Honduras, Mexico and Russia, they are killed. But in the European Union? We did not deem it possible that this could happen here. Something is terribly wrong. We know that Ms Caruana Galicia was trying to join the dots with regard to the Panama Papers and the possible enmeshment of government officials in the affair. Since she was murdered before the Paradise Papers became public, we do not know what else she might have discovered. There have also been other questionable affairs in Malta. I am very concerned when I hear that foreigners have been buying Maltese passports just like that, a couple of tens of thousands of euros, and the door to the European Union becomes wide open. This is unacceptable. Daphne Caruana Galizia must not have died in vain. The circumstances of her murder must be scrutinised until every stone is turned and everything is laid bare. I support the decision by the Maltese Government to get both Europol and the FBI involved in the investigation. The rule of law must not be compromised. And to one side of the House I would also say that as long as you do not support whistle-blowers, you have no credibility in trashing Malta.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: - Madam President, scorpions tend to live in secret. They thrive especially between rocks and cracks. However, when they are illuminated with ultraviolet light on scorpions, they are clearly visible, because all scorpions have a fluorescent outer layer, so they simply light up. And so it is time to shed light on corruption and uncover hidden scorpions that are also hidden in politics and business. Such a murder of a Maltese journalist is a clear manifestation of the perniciousness and pernicious network of evil people who cling to and help each other. But it also begins with the inability of the force and the judiciary to often translate good laws into practice. Instead, we see frustrated citizens who do not trust the institutions deeply. And my country, Slovakia, can also be considered the flagship of such corruption, clientelism and dirty business, which we see in politics too much. However, I believe in change and I look forward to the time when citizens, as well as officials and government officials, will gain courage and shine light into the dark corners of corrupt systems. Like Daphne Caurana Galizia. But removal will come when there are honest people in places of responsibility who are willing to take responsibility to God and to people and to remain honest.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we don’t have to use Malta as a scapegoat to cover up our collective mistakes. Is Malta the only tax haven in the European Union? No. Is Malta the only country that facilitates tax evasion? No. Is Malta the only country that facilitates money-laundering? No. Is Malta the only country in the European Union that does not protect whistle-blowers? No. All these phenomena together are producing corruption, and corruption produces violence and crime. So if we want to avoid crime we have to establish pan-European legislation against those phenomena: against corruption, against money-laundering, against tax evasion, against tax havens. Let’s do that. Stop crying crocodile tears for Caruana.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I will focus only on points 5 and 6 of our resolution on Malta. Point 5 expresses concerns about the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights, including freedom of the media, independence of the police and judiciary. Point 6 calls on the Commission, the Council and Parliament to establish a dialogue with the Maltese Government. Thus, concern and dialogue with a Member State. But a similar concern and wish for dialogue in relation to Spain is not shown by the European Union institutions, in spite of having there more than strong signals of breaches of the rule of law, of democracy and of fundamental rights. There the police have brutally beaten peaceful people; the central government has sacked a democratically elected regional government; half of this government is in prison, the other half in exile; the President of the parliament was sent to prison; 700 mayors are judicially indicted. Do we need more? There is more. Why this unequal treatment? I ask Mr Timmermans: are the European institutions applying the principle of be strong with the weak, be weak with strong?

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many things to be said about what is happening in Malta from my neighbors. But, in a minute, I would first like to express my appreciation for Parliament's decision to send the delegation of deputies from the LIBE and PANA committees to the island. However, I consider the decision to keep any reference to the case of the brutal murder of Dafne Caruana Galizia, the journalist who came to this Parliament to shed light on the Panama Papers, extremely contradictory. On that occasion, she denounced what she had discovered about the tax havens system and the affairs that revolve around it, both European and non-European. His investigations of her had reached a crucial point when they were abruptly interrupted by who she had and she still has an interest in keeping these serious financial crimes under wraps. Therefore, I ask myself: with what courage do we speak of the rule of law today if we do not consider it an absolute priority to shed light on an attack of this significance? As rapporteur of the directive on combating money laundering through criminal law, I hope that real progress can be made both on the fight against money laundering at European level and in using this delegation that will go to Malta to shed light on the problems that are emerged.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF).
text: - Madam President, at the beginning of November, the Commission rejected calls for an independent investigation into the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. Yet intransigent against certain states like Hungary, the Commission therefore seems inclined to allow an endemic system of corruption to flourish in the Union. This "double standard" is all the more striking as this crime comes after multiple warnings, in particular from the monitoring body for media pluralism, about Maltese shortcomings in terms of fundamental freedoms and transparency. When Malta assumed the presidency of the Council, it nevertheless made the fight against money laundering a priority. Tributes to Ms. Caruana Galizia should not be a cover-up in the fight against corruption. The Commission must take responsibility for practices such as the purchase of citizenship, denounced by the resolution of my colleagues, which seriously undermine the whole of the Union.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Madam President, standing up here today is not easy. Standing up rarely is. I represent a fiercely proud people, a hard—working people. We Maltese have worked tirelessly for everything we’ve ever had, and battled geography to claim our rightful place as EU members. That is the Malta I know and that is the Malta I fight for. But all is not well in my country today, and to remain silent is to be complicit. Too many people have sacrificed too much for me not to speak as our authorities pillage our children’s legacy and destroy our reputation. To this House I would say: you have become the last bastion of hope for the people we represent, and this is what the EU means to us – hope, and a guarantee that the rule of law will always be protected, because joining the EU was our way of ensuring that no politician with delusions of grandeur would ever trample on our rights again without our European partners stepping in to help us. Daphne Caruana Galizia was executed – assassinated – and her killing exposed the urgency of the situation in Malta, where the ruling party has used its majority to ride roughshod over the rule of law. Malta is a great country, but we have to have the courage to say that it is unacceptable that journalists are killed with impunity, that it is outrageous that the press is under threat, and that it is disgraceful that the police refuse to investigate corruption. Because we know that there can be no rule of law without law enforcement, that there can be no true democracy with a shackled media, and that there can be no justice when those exposing crimes are the ones targeted. Instead of facing the issue, our Prime Minister spends his time addressing rallies, calling us traitors, claiming he is defending Malta, even from Europe. He thinks he can intimidate everyone, but we will not be silent, and neither should the Commission: it should launch a rule-of-law dialogue with the Maltese authorities and help our country move forward.
