The situation is desperate. I ask all of you: stand with us, do not let us down now that we need you most. (Applause)

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: - Fil-fatt, iva kienu ġimgħat diffiċli għal Malta wara l-qtil atroċi ta 'Daphne Caruana Galicia, imma kontra l-impressjoni inġusta li qed tingħata f'dan il-Parlament, Malta għandha u qegħda tintroduċi liġijithu li jaħd , u iva, Malta lesta tiddiskuti fejn hemm bżonn, jiġi indirizzat, kif diġà insistiet. Il-Partit tal-Popular Ewropew qed jgħidilna li r-Rule of Law f’Malta ikkollassa. Nistaqsi jien: f’pajjiż fejn ir-Rule of Law jikkollassa, jidħlu liġijiet ġodda bħal-liġi tal-funding tal-parties? Bħat-tneħħija tal-preskrizzjoni dwar atti ta ’korruzzjoni minn politiċi? Bħal Whistleblowers' Protection Act? F’pajjiż fejn il-gvern jhedded il-liberty tal-espressjoni, tkun ippreżentata liġi li temenda l-Att dwar l-istampa billi tipproponi t-tneħħija ta ’libell kriminali, u Precautionary Warrant f’każ ta’ libell ċivili? F’pajjiż mingħajr Rule of Law, jiddaħħlu fost l-aqwa liġijiet favur il-komunity LGBTI? Dawn huma kollha liġijiet li ddaħħlu f'dawn l-aħħar grass' snin f'Malta kemm ilu li hemm gvern Soċjal Demokratiku, liġijiet li l-Partit Nazzjonalista, li jagħmel parti mill-familja tal-EPP, lanqas biss'kkamsaidra f u għoxrin sena. F'pajjiż fejn ir-Rule of Law suppost ikkollassa jkun hemm is-secrecy u nirreferi hawnhekk għall-Financial Secrecy Index mit-Tax Justice Network, li jikkunsidra lil Malta aktar transparenti minn pajjiżi bħall-Ġermanja, ir-Renju Unit, u l- Luxembourg, li huma plejers kbar fis-servizzi financialjarji offshore. Ara dan l-index, dan l-index but ġiex ikkwotat fir-riżoluzzjoni konġunta li dan il-parlament ser jivvota dwarha. Malta mhijiex tgħid li ma tridx tirranġa fejn hemm bżonn, imma unfortunate l-għaġġla ta 'xi uħud f'dan il-Parlament biex jikkundannaw lil Malta mingħajr lanqas biss jippruvaw jagħmlu analiġżi standards kompikkon double qemikkon tegkoni kompikkon double adoption tegkoni teg different pajjiżi.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The accusations against the Maltese elite of corruption, unfair practices of cooperation with business and supporting the functioning of tax havens are not new - suffice to mention the case of John Dalli, the former health commissioner, which rocked Brussels in 2012. It is also significant that this year we are discussing the rule of law of Malta here in Parliament. Earlier, we did so in the context of the Panama Papers and Malta's controversial citizenship sales program. More and more often it is said that too loose financial regulations in Malta have turned it into a country of organized crime. In this regard, I would like to ask President Timmermans, whose concern for the rule of law in Poland is well known to us, how did it happen that you were not able to notice earlier, until this terrible murder, that in Malta perhaps it is not the best of rule of law? How is it that you are unable to see the fundamental rights problems in Spain, in France, in your country? Maybe you have false priorities? Perhaps your attention is selective? Or maybe you have double standards?

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Daphne Caruana Galizia was a journalist apart, not just because of the quality of her writing, not just because of those whom she was exposing for their corruption decided to murder her, but because of her courage in an ocean of cowardice. Traditional journalism was about fearlessly and objectively holding authority to account, about protection of the interests of the masses, about exposing wrongdoing, especially at the highest level. All of those would describe Daphne to a tee. Modern journalism is about fearfully and subjectively kowtowing to authority, about protection of the interests of the powerful few, about burying wrongdoing especially at the highest level. I can think of many so-called journalists whom that would describe. People who aren’t just writing and speaking to defend those named and shamed in the Panama papers and the Paradise papers but in some cases are actually on their payroll, owned and controlled. In the same way that we have political parties, who besmirch the word ‘people’ by incorporating it in their name, we have news outlets who besmirch the word ‘independent’. I hope Daphne’s death was not in vain, but given how this place works I fear it will be.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what happened in Malta and what happened to the journalist Dafne Caruana Galizia is terrible, because she was an honest person, who was investigating very complex issues, in which there are enormous conflicts and interests between politics, organized crime and finance, in short, very large powers that in some way also influence our business a little. She posted a message on her blog before she was murdered that these institutions would do their utmost to try to marry her cause of her. Unfortunately, she is no longer here with us. I would not want this signal to remain in the shadows, as happens every time in these cases, given that even in Italy we have had cases of bloody murderers like these. We need to react, we need to make sure that the healthy part of the institutions begins to really make healthy rules and that we stop covering everything that happens afterwards in reality. For example, I am sorry that Commission President Juncker is not here today for the second debate in this Parliament on the subject. He did not appear today on the Paradise Papers scandal. A little seriousness would be in coming to represent the institution of the European Commission on issues that also see him directly involved, as in the LuxLeaks scandal.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: - Madam President! While we are discussing the rule of law in Malta, the Prime Minister in Hong Kong is selling passports. He calls this nobly "to promote investment and job creation in Malta". That is exactly the point: the arrogant manner in which the socialist government in Malta has dealt with the PANA committee, with the public, with the journalists. This shows that there is a lot going on here. The self-healing powers in Malta are not sufficient to comply with European law. The proud people of the Maltese count on us, on our help and, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, on your help too. It is not enough to say: We checked all of this. You will also need to re-examine the terms of joining 13 years ago. In the morning, the Socialist Group leader sheds crocodile tears in connection with the Paradise Papers, and in the afternoon the entire squad of the S&D is either absent or defends the lack of rule of law in Malta as normal and distracting. That cannot be the division of labor. As long as the socialists do not watch their member Muscat, he will not give up his arrogant behavior. And we have an obligation to look to Malta: what is the system? What is government failure? Where is the failure of the European Commission? How can we help? We have had the experience: After the investigation, the police chief was dismissed, the advocate general, the results of the investigations against members of the government were never published, the proceedings are not concluded, internally there are people in responsible positions in the judiciary who leave us the impression: The separation of powers is not properly guaranteed. And, Mr Vice-President, Malta also needs massive support from the Commission and Parliament. We'll deliver that. (Applause)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: - In Malta, there is no ostensible attack on the rule of law by the Government, as we see in Hungary or Poland. The problem in Malta is the capture of the State, through members of the Government, deputies, supervisory authorities, magistrates, police, officials, by financial interests or services of intermediaries, such as Nexia BT. For this reason, Malta opposes transparency on the beneficial owners of the trusts that this Parliament proposes in the negotiations under the 5th anti-money laundering and terrorist financing directive. The problem is not confined to the current Government: it was decades-old deregulatory policies, transversal to political parties, orchestrated from London with the approval of Brussels, which made Malta a tax haven within the European Union, developing an industry there specialized in aggressive tax planning and the multiplication of shell companies, instrumental in money laundering, corruption and other criminality schemes. The Maltese and European nationality sales program is at the heart of these policies with greater risks to the security of Malta and the European Union. The bombing of the courageous journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia is an alarming testimony. Prime Minister Muscat keeps the chief of staff and minister exposed by the Panama Papers and has not yet allowed an independent investigation into allegations about an account linking his wife to the Pilate bank. How can you ensure that the Maltese Government guarantees, as it should, the independence of the means of supervision, the depoliticization of the police and the judicial authorities? It is not even proposed to end the accumulation of political and state functions with the provision of financial, fiscal and business services! We cannot deceive ourselves. Malta has to rethink its development model and stop serving as one of the European centers specialized in facilitating tax evasion and money laundering. Up to The Commission and the Council not only pressure Malta to do so, but also ensure, through European legislation, that these practices are outlawed and combated in Malta, in the European Union - and there are more tax havens in the European Union - and globally.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the killing of Daphne must represent a turning point. It is absolutely not enough the indignation that everyone has expressed through the media, but also to the family. This is not enough. We must seek the truth and the truth must come out of it, and the first to be responsible for this search must be the Maltese government. The European Parliament, which I remember being the largest democratically voted institution in the world, has the task of rediscovering the truth together with Malta, and above all the appeal also of our colleagues is not to leave this reality and this State of the European Union alone. . The battle for Daphne and for her family must in fact become the battle of all Europeans, respecting tolerance. Alongside Daphne there must be all citizens who believe in this civilized Europe. You see, it is Malta that must prove to be a state of law and I have great perplexities, even as an Italian, when a state allows you to sell your citizenship, your values, your dignity and your origin, selling it off. for a few euros. This is also to be evaluated within the rule of law and, you see, I would also like to receive a clear and precise answer - but I think not only me, but also all European citizens - because Daphne has received threats, she has denounced, but no one did nothing. Why this? Why didn't anyone move? Because this death could have been avoided and there was no reaction from the Maltese government and from the authorities and the police. I really thank the European Parliament and I hope that the Commission will tell the truth and push Malta to find the truth.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Timmermans, in the last eighteen months six car bombs have exploded in the smallest country in the European Union, which does not have a widespread crime problem: Malta. The last of them has taken the life of Daphne Caruana Galizia ahead, which shows supremely the unacceptable sacrifice of the whistleblowers who have the courage to work for the public exposure of the unacceptable, corruption, seeking transparency and serving to the expression freedoom. The sacrifice of one's life has indeed taken place in Malta, which does not have a general problem of a decline in freedoms or the rule of law. It does have a problem of a financial system used to inadmissible practices of raising money of illicit origin and unfair tax competition, extremely vulnerable to the penetration of money from organized crime and laundering. And, therefore, Malta has to make an effort and clearly show its commitment to reparation, not only by urging a full and independent investigation in which Europol and Interpol collaborate in the clarification of each and every one of the crimes and , especially, this one. But, as Daphne Caruana's children Andrew, Matthew and Paul dramatically ask us, Malta has much more to do. It has to combat this corruption in its financial system, joining the European Public Prosecutor's Office as a crucial tool for the investigation of serious transnational crime. Because that will be the definitive sign that their sacrifice will not have been in vain and that the European Union is willing to take to its last consequences the repair of this vulnerability of the Maltese financial system and to do the good job for which Daphne Caruana Galicia has sacrificed his life. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (article 162 (8) of the Regulation))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I would particularly like to thank you for the argument, because I believe that this is our common basis, that we want to promote the rule of law and the separation of powers.Do you think that OLAF should play a stronger role here in the future?

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: "blue card" response.- There is no European institution that can escape the commitment to strengthen the rule of law now that it is so threatened, but particularly in the face of organized crime, which is surely the most excruciating threat.And one form of organized crime, without a doubt, is corruption and money laundering from illicit businesses.We were discussing it here this morning in relation to the paradise papers, which are hell for taxpayers who pay their taxes honestly and want to have confidence in their institutions.Therefore, OLAF, but also Europol, Eurojust and, development of Eurojust, the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to which Malta has a moral and political duty to join if it wants to effectively show commitment to the fight against serious transnational crime.

name: Michał Boni (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Malta is a beautiful country but its Government has let it down. We have journalists being assassinated, the press being targeted by a bank at the centre of serious criminal accusations, high Government officials implicated in corruption and money laundering, and a police force that defends the Government instead of people in the streets calling for justice. All these issues taken together indicate to me a collapse of the rule of law. Winning an election does not mean the victorious party can divide up the country and ignore its obligations as an EU Member State. Malta and Poland joined the EU on the same day in 2004. Our people share the same values and joined for the same reasons. We – Poles and Maltese – act in the name of the EU and want the EU to act. The Commission should immediately launch a rule—of—law dialogue with the Maltese authorities. The Maltese authorities should immediately investigate money-laundering activities. The independent international investigation into the killing of Daphne Caruana Galizia is necessary. I will say something about the Maltese colleagues who have taken the floor today. I have heard that the Socialists in Malta have called them traitors. This is unacceptable. They are doing their duty. We stand with them. We stand with Malta. (Applause)

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: - Għat-tieni darba f’ħames xhur l-Istat Maltti qiegħed fil-bank tal-akkużati - b’mod l-aktar diskriminatorju - quddiem il-Parlament Ewropew; u din mhix ħaġa normali. Hemm min qed jinqeda b’dan il-Parlament biex jimmina Stat Membru u jagámmel bsaten fir-roti lil gvern elett demokratikament u biex jaqdi aġenda partiġġja. Din ir-riżoluzzjoni miktuba bla dubju minn idejn Maltin hi taħwida ta 'punti u ta' akkużi inttii biss biex jitfgħu dell ikrah fuq Malta u li ħafna minnhom lanqas biss għandhom x’jaqsmu fuq ir-Rule of Law. L-istituzzjonijiet Maltin mhumiex perfetti, bħalma mhumiex perfetti f’kull stat ieħor. L-ebda stat mhu meħlus mill-kriminalità - ukoll dik finanzjarja; l-ebda pajjiż ma jista ’jgħid li hu meellus mill-iskandli. I am a member of the Maltese Republic of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. Kull wieħed minnkom li qed tippuntaw subgħajkom lejn Malta għandkom erba ‘swaba’ oħra jippuntaw lejkom. The Maltese tintuża bħala scapegoat mhijiex xi ħaġa li għandha tiġi aċċettata f’din l-istituzzjoni. The situation in Malta has intensified and increased investment, impacts, economic growth and future growth. L-iskop ta 'din ir-riżoluzzjoni mhijiex ġenwina iżda intti biex tagämmel illsara lill-gvern Malta, imma fuq kollox biex tipprova tniżelel lil Malta għarkobbtejha. Mhux se jirnexxilkom.

name: Monika Hohlmeier (PPE).
text: - Madam President! I find it a bit bold to say that we are all here in the European Parliament accusing Maltese society. We are not indicting the Maltese society, we want to help women, men and citizens in Malta to get rid of corrupt people, organized criminals, terrorists, black money, tax evaders, black coffers and whatever and to get orderly structures. That means: We want to give support to the people and not to those who have expanded the system into a felt system. The sale of passports to dubious people - criminals - will no longer be allowed in the future. Dubious sources of money, dubious flows of money, e.g. B. Daphne Caruana Galizia has researched - it should have been given help and support, that the relevant institutions help her with the investigations, and she should have been given protection on the part of Malta. That would have been necessary and not to attack them as well. Furthermore: Is it necessary that this government also appeared arrogantly in a Panama Committee, did not provide any information, did not show any willingness to cooperate? This is not the Malta that actually wanted to join here. Because according to the criteria of this accession, the institutions and laws must already be in place and accordingly none of the things that we have to complain about here should not exist. We want to help the people of Malta so that they have a healthy state, and not protect a socialist government. Otherwise the socialists are constantly getting upset with Hungary or whatever, but when it comes to their government it suddenly becomes very quiet here in the room. Please demand the same conditions for everyone.

name: La Présidente. –
text: So, Mr. Lavrilleux, did you have a point of order?

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I wanted to speak to protest against the fact that from time to time you give a blue card and that on other occasions we do not have the possibility to send one, whichappears to be a breach of equality of parliamentarians within this hemicycle.I just wanted to respond to our Socialist colleague who spoke a few moments ago, who dared to say that in Malta what is happening in many countries.I am not aware of any assassination of journalists in other countries of the European Union investigating the corruption that plagues a government.If she knows of such facts, could she report them to us?

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, I wanted to tell you that I do not think there are differences between us when it comes to expressing the sentiment that the murder of Daphne Caruana produced. I believe that we condemn the murder with the same force and defend the same European values ​​in relation to Malta and to the countries of the European Union. The leap that perhaps with all honesty I would like to transfer to you is the one that I do not dare to make in order to link or to link this crime with the State. I do not dare to establish a direct relationship between this crime and the destruction of the rule of law in Malta. I demand justice, but I do not condemn a country. I demand an independent investigation and that the culprits be brought to justice, but I do not question the separation of powers in Malta. I believe that we must demand Malta, and we are all united there, that we must demand that it discover the murderers, bring them to justice, put an end to the mafias and organizations linked to dirty money and to put an end to fiscal fraud. There we all agree.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra (PPE).
text: - Madam President, I want you to hear what Daphne was saying thirty minutes before she was murdered: 'Everywhere you look, there are criminals everywhere. The situation is desperate. What you saw, Daphne, was organized crime comfortably installed in the country, a nest of organized crime. You saw money laundering facilitated by banks; you saw persecution against the hostile press, the death penalty for free and uncomfortable journalism. That is what you saw. You also saw a Police that does not investigate and a Government that says, but does not do. Malta does not deserve what is happening. It is essential that the independent press have their space of freedom, that the Maltese government and the police forces are involved in the investigation of the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. Security in democracy is an essential issue, linked to the strength or weakness of the rule of law. I very much appreciate the fact that two Europol officials are already in Valletta on a permanent basis to help clarify this murder. And finally, Mr Timmermans, I would like to ask the Commission to get involved immediately by initiating a dialogue on the rule of law with the Maltese authorities.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, “my mother was murdered because she was, like other journalists, between the rule of law and those who violate it, but she was also targeted because she was the only person to do so. This is what happens when state institutions have become incapable. The last person standing is often a journalist. ” It was with these words that the son of Maltese investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia, who was murdered in her vehicle blast, described his mother's murder. The moment you have decided to give me here in this Chamber, I have wanted to devote it to her and all those whistleblowers who risk their lives for what they believe is right. And this Maltese journalist’s fight was fair, it served the public interest well. In the spring, a well-known American magazine listed Daphne Caruana Galizia as one of the 28 people who move Europe, describing her as an entire WikiLeaks, one woman crusading against the lack of transparency and corruption in Malta. I agree with the statements of the European Commission on this subject, I too am horrified by this assassination. I ask this same Commission to go beyond posture and take action. This heinous murder in Malta has to be the last, hopefully. We look forward to the European Commission finally proposing legislation that protects whistleblowers, as the European Parliament suggests, through several requests. Finally, we must realize that the disappearance of Daphne is an attack on freedom of expression, is an attack on those who fight for good governance, is an attack on all those in Europe who fight for more justice. They wanted to assassinate her to silence her, let's make sure to continue to carry her voice and to continue the fight for cleaner practices.Justice must be served.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: - At first, allow me to express my sincere condolences to the family of Daphne Galizia, who was brutally murdered for her courageous and honest journalistic work. It is even harder to come to terms with her death if we know that this act could have been prevented. It seems and we hear today that Malta is having problems with the rule of law and the deteriorating situation in the field of media freedom. With this act, a terrible and clear message was sent to corruption and crime investigators and investigative journalists. Bullying is known to be the way the mafia works. However, if the judiciary, the police and the media are not truly independent and resilient, then we already have a systemic problem. But Malta is no exception. Recently, a commission of inquiry of the Slovenian parliament revealed a case of large-scale money laundering. Some took advantage of Slovenia's largest bank and laundered a billion euros seven years ago in favor of the Iranian regime, which was allegedly used to finance terrorism. The president of this commission of inquiry, dr. Anže Logar and his parents were publicly threatened with death by a radical leftist. Prominent journalist Jože Možina was also threatened with death a few days ago, even before politician Janez Janša. But nothing happens. Where is it going? Where do all these threats lead? Some Member States are clearly not in a position to provide security for their citizens on their own, so I call on the Union to act more quickly in such specific situations in order to open a structured dialogue with governments and thus protect those at risk. Finally, let me thank the President of the European Parliament, who yesterday named the hall or press center in the European Parliament after Daphne.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: - Madam President!Is it worrying that a critical journalist is being killed in cold blood in Malta?Yes!Is it worrying that Malta is a tax haven?Yes!But is that reason enough to equate Malta with countries in the EU that do not comply with the rule of law?No!Malta is not Hungary, Malta is not Poland.Malta is in dialogue with the rest of the EU.Malta has reached out and asked for help.Let us use that dialogue to help Malta solve the murder, find out how to better protect journalists, stop tax havens and help strengthen the rule of law, including transparency in Malta.So now do not compare Malta with Hungary and Poland.On the other hand, we could call on Poland and Hungary to do the same as Malta, namely to reach out and ask for help from the European Commission.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (PPE).
text: Madam President, as is well known, Daphne Caruana was killed in her car bomb. Daphne became known for her fight for transparency, exploring the Panama Papers and possible links to the Maltese government. She denounced the threats she received but was not granted protection; she is subject to the rule of law within the European Union and this cannot be accepted. We call on the Commission to uphold the rule of law and to take all necessary initiatives in each Member State of the European Union to shed light on this case and any unresolved cases. As Plato said in "The State", let us see the "really beings", that is, things as they are, the truth of things. The reality of the rule of law in the European Union is beginning to become problematic; Poland, Hungary, Malta, Greece are just the beginning. We are waiting for initiatives from the European Commission and the European Council.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Dafne was considered by many to be a pioneer of investigative journalism. She dafne was included among the people who would shape and shake Europe in 2017. she Daphne she believed in freedom of expression and she carried out with passion and professionalism a profession that she loved more than anything else. Dafne was brutally murdered because she, with the force of her words, she was defending the fundamental values ​​of freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, and she stood in the way of those who try to violate this rule of law. . There is no single person responsible for her death. There is a corrupt system which acts against the great value of democracy and which has ramifications inside and outside the European Union. We count on the Maltese government and the assistance it receives from leading European and international investigative agencies to shed light on this barbaric murder, to do justice to Daphne and her work as an investigative journalist and her extraordinary contribution to the affirmation of the rule of law. , not only in Malta but throughout Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, dear colleagues, the situation of the rule of law in Malta has been raising many questions in recent years. Now it has reached its peak. Daphne Caruana was murdered because she reported on the Panama Papers scandal which directly implicated the Maltese Government. This murder has become a symbol of the fight against corruption and lack of activity and transparency of the Maltese Government is completely unacceptable in an EU Member State. It is proof of a weakened state institution. I would like to appeal to Maltese colleagues from S&D, the Maltese Labour Party – you must put pressure on your Prime Minister and Government. Mr Commissioner, you have to play a more active role of control and enforcement of justice.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: - President! The horrific and painful death of Daphne Galizia has shaken and intimidated all of us - not just those who would take action against corruption or for human rights, for freedom of the press. We think about it several times, I think, how to get involved in such matters from now on. We have known so far that it is possible to die in investigative journalism, but that it is in Europe, in the 21st century. It will happen in the 20th century ... And then I will not even talk about the reactions of the Maltese government. This is completely frustrating, and I would say to colleagues who compare Malta to Hungary or Poland, that this indicates a great deal of ignorance, and I think we must reject this manipulation. Here they took a life, slaughtered a woman, a journalist. The aim was to obscure the truth, and the Commission, in my opinion, reacted remarkably slowly. It was a huge mistake that we did not get much clearer answers today either. I would like to ask the Commission to call for an immediate dialogue between the parties and, in any case, to avoid even the appearance of judging EU countries by double standards.

name: Francis Zammit Dimech (PPE).
text: - Ninsab kburi li nkun f'dan il-Parlament nirrapreżenta lill-poplu Malti, għax il-poplu Malti meta vvota għad-dħul ta 'pajjiżna fl-Unjoni Erropea ried preċiżament li jkollu l-ħarsien tas-saltna tad-dritt u tal- the fundamentals are included in the terms of the espression. Ngħixu f’sitwazzjoni mill-iktar surreal. Galiex? The name of the company is limited to the amount of red wine in the Daphne Caruana Galizia. Illum qegħdin fis-sitwazzjoni surreali li min qed jgħidilna li jrid jagämmel ġustizzja magħha fil-mewt taghaha, naturalment ma kienx kapaċi jipproteġiha f’ħajjitha. Illum qegħdin fis-sitwazzjoni surreal li li kasbarha fil-ididma Journalism taghaha issa qed jgħid li jrid iħares lejn kull ma kitbet biex jara jasalx għal tarf fuq il-qtil tagħha. Kummissjoni, il-poplu Malti jistenna li inti tkun l-għassiesa tal-valuri Ewropej u mhux apoloġista ta ’gvern jew ieħor.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I visited Malta as part of the Committee of Inquiry into Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA) investigation. The reason for our visit was that several names of Maltese Government high officials appeared in the Panama Papers and we wanted to get some explanations. Unfortunately, we met with a lack of cooperation on the side of Maltese Government. The Prime Minister’s chief of cabinet simply refused to meet us. We even asked the Prime Minister to help us in organising the meeting with Mr Schembri, with no result, unfortunately. The other minister of Mr Muscat’s cabinet failed to convince Members of the European Parliament of his innocence. And then we also met with Daphne Caruana Galizia. She explained to us the situation in the country, and only a few months later she was assassinated. Mr President, I think that this strategy should mobilise all of us to make sure that all those responsible are brought to justice and that such a tragedy never happens again.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, before the shocking assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia, before the massacre perpetrated against the freedom of expression and the European way of life, I can only recall the surprisingly sensible, calm and quiet words of Mark Anthony before the corpse of Julius Caesar in Shakespeare’s masterpiece: ‘O, pardon me, thou bleeding piece of earth, That I am meek and gentle with these butchers!’. The only thing that we ask the Commission and the Maltese authorities to do is to grant respect and observation of the rule of law. Malta is geographically and historically one of the gates and one of the doors of the European Union. It should be the bastion of the protection of human rights, the rule of law, the independence of judicial power and impartially of criminal prosecution. Daphne Galizia was known internationally, was known globally for her fight against corruption. She reported on the corruption. She reported on the Panama Papers and we have seen, we have read, we have heard and we could not ignore that the Panama Papers are directly implicated with some Maltese authorities. Nothing was done to protect her life, to protect her job, to protect her freedom. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: - Media freedom is a pillar of modern democratic societies.Today's debate on the rule of law in Malta shows that the European Parliament is not silent when it comes to advocating freedom of speech and media pluralism.Slovenian journalist Mirot Petak was found severely beaten in front of his home in 2001, it was an attempted murder.Journalist Miro Petek wrote about the machinations of Nova kreditna banka Maribor, a local economy intertwined with the political and capital interests of individuals.To date, the Slovenian state has not been able to detect and punish the attackers.The murder of journalist Galizia is a black day for democracy.In addition to strongly condemning such acts, we must call for an independent international investigation into the murder and call on the Maltese authorities to protect media freedom, the rule of law and fundamental rights.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, we once again condemn the murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia and express our concern about the silence of the press and the threats against journalists. The unfortunate journalist was investigating the Panama Papers and possible connections of government officials for money laundering and corruption. Mr Timmermans, the European Union has a key role to play in strengthening the legal framework against money laundering and corruption, while at the same time tackling the effects of tax havens, tax evasion, tax evasion and tax evasion. Of course, this does not only concern Malta, it concerns many Member States of the European Union, it concerns Luxembourg, it concerns the Netherlands. Aggressive tax planning must stop and the rule of law must be strengthened.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the motion for a resolution on the rule of law in Malta goes too far and I consider that it goes beyond the bounds of political correctness and is an attempt to intervene directly in the internal affairs of a Member State. Let me first demonstrate once again the selective reference to the rule of law, which does not apply in cases of political and judicial persecution of nationalists. On the other hand, the Republic of Malta has a legally elected government which has the sole responsibility to enforce and protect the area of ​​freedom, security and justice and to respect fundamental rights. Of course, the mild phraseology used by the socialist group, in contrast to the cases of Poland and Hungary, is justified by the existence of socialists in the Maltese government. I therefore propose to the MEPs who tabled the motion for a resolution to take similar action, naming and condemning all socialists and non-corrupt politicians involved in scandals. They have harmed the public interest, abused power, evaded taxes and their names appear on lists and papers.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the assassination of the unfortunate Daphne Caruana Galizia has brought to light some issues related to the rule of law in Malta. For this reason, the government must, on the one hand, identify and arrest its killers, but at the same time provide convincing answers as to whether there is corruption in the country or not. Of course, Malta is an independent state and is trying to apply the principles of the rule of law within itself, but can the government guarantee the protection of the press as well as the protection of scandal investigators and whistleblowers? It is true that the main source of wealth for the country is the provision of services, but does this justify turning the country into an economic paradise? In any case, the Maltese government must answer the questions, otherwise it will enable the European Union to intervene internally and abolish the independence of a free and sovereign state.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, if a journalist is murdered it is to silence her. If it is done in this way I surmise it is not just to silence her but also to send a clear message to anybody else who might want to investigate things. That is why the way this murder was carried out is reminiscent of the attacks on Borsellino and Falcone. So what we are dealing with here is a very serious matter that needs to be pursued, and the investigation should be allowed to run its full course and no stone left unturned. That is why it is good that the Maltese authorities also engage in international cooperation with the FBI, with Scotland Yard, with the NFI in the Netherlands, calling also on the European institutions and on Interpol to help them. What is not on though is already today to draw conclusions about who did it. I think we should be clear that we stress that this investigation should be allowed to run its full course, regardless of the consequences for anyone anywhere in Malta, or elsewhere by the way. But I would caution in drawing conclusions today, as some appear to be doing here, about who is responsible for this. That is not for now. My second point is this. Many questions were put here today, many pertinent questions about many issues relating to the situation in Malta in a number of areas. I give you the assurance here today that the European Commission will pursue all these questions and give you answers when we can, especially Mr Giegold had a number of questions – we’ve taken careful note. Other Members had also a number of questions. We will pursue those questions and then provide them with the answers whenever we can and continue to pursue them if we need to investigate further. But again, what is not on as far as the Commission is concerned is to start with a conclusion and then look for facts to support that conclusion. That is not how we do this. We first look into the questions that were put on the table, and then if we come up with conclusions on those questions it is soon enough to then see what other steps might need to be taken. I think every Member State deserves that way of acting when we look into issues pertaining to the rule of law and other such subjects. One issue I want to briefly highlight, because it was raised by many Members, is the so-called sale of passports. In our 2017 citizens’ report we announced that we would produce next year, 2018, a report on national schemes granting EU citizenship to investors. And by the way, Malta is not the only Member State that has such a scheme. A few Member States have it and, aside from that, other Member States have schemes to grant permanent residency to people who invest. So it is not just a one Member State issue, it is a broader issue and we will refer to that in our 2018 report. This report will describe the Commission’s actions in this area, current national law and practices in all Member States, and provide some guidance. We are working on this report right now. Member States – and this I can already say now – should use their prerogatives towards citizenship in line with their international and EU law obligations and in a spirit of sincere cooperation with other Member States. Simply because, if you become a citizen of one Member State that grants you access to all the other Member States. So you have to have an attitude of sincere cooperation with all Member States. So we will go into that in our report. And I want to stress also, because that was raised several times, the Commission insists with Malta to really seriously look into the possibility to join the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. It would be in Malta’s interest. There is another Member State that I know very well that also did not want to join the EPPO but now, with a new government, they have changed their mind and they have expressed their intention to join it, and I welcome that. I think Mr Michel is right when he says that it would be good for all Member States to be part of that so that we can have these European investigations into the use of European funds. Let me conclude very briefly by saying that I do express the hope that, given the seriousness of this issue, and given the seriousness of the questions that were put on the table, we do not turn this into a party-political fight. That is not what she deserves. That is not what Daphne deserves. Let’s continue to act as this House has always done with integrity and perseverance so that we allow the investigation to run its full course so that the ones responsible for this atrocious crime are brought to justice, and if we discover systemic issues that need to be addressed, that we address them in a spirit of cooperation with the Member State concerned.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the Estonian Presidency and the Council as a whole attach great importance to upholding the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States and in the Union. We are confident that the Maltese law enforcement authorities are capable of upholding the rule of law in the face of recent developments. The Maltese citizens seem to believe that as well, according to a recent opinion poll. One observation of a more general nature: the EU is much better at dealing with the political issues between the Member States than within the Member States because that is what the Union was created for. It is also worth remembering that the effectiveness of the EU rests on the delicate balance between respecting the sovereignty of its nation states and cooperating together to make states stronger together. Nevertheless, it is clear that all Member States have to comply with fundamental democratic standards and the rule of law.  Speaking on behalf of the Council and in the name of all its members, I am not in a position to state more at this stage. However, the Council is following this debate closely and I can assure the honourable Members that I will pay particular attention to the views expressed here today.

name: President. –
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: written. - Daphne Caruana Galizia, a journalist and blogger who investigated corruption in Malta, was assassinated on 16 October 2017 in a car bomb attack. That murder led to protests in Malta. The Country Report on Monitoring Media Pluralism 2016 identified the high risks of market pluralism and political independence for the Maltese media. They were exacerbated by a number of factors, such as the lack of protection and self-regulation of journalists and editorial autonomy, political ownership of the media, and lack of media literacy. The 2017 Freedom of the Media Index, published by Reporters Without Borders, found that in Malta, freedom of expression is particularly restricted by defamation laws, which can be used to impose fines or imprisonment and are widely used by journalists, especially against politicians. Politicians representing the entire Maltese political spectrum had brought several charges against Daphne Caruana Galizia on the grounds of defamation. His bank account was also frozen earlier this year by a court ruling related to a defamation lawsuit filed by a government minister that had not yet been resolved in court. The Maltese media is reported to have come under intense pressure from Pilate Bank, which is the subject of money laundering allegations. Pilatus Bank's customers have mostly been politically influential Azerbaijanis, for whom the bank has not exercised due diligence as required by the Anti-Money Laundering Directive. Malta has been found to be selling its citizenship for EUR 650,000 to third-country nationals, such as Russians, who are also acquiring EU citizenship and related rights. The situation in Malta is very worrying, so I strongly support the one adopted by the European Parliament on 15 November 2017 resolution on the rule of law in Malta.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: in writing.- Daphne Caruana Galizia was a journalist investigating political scandals in Malta.An investigation into her death was assigned to the judge who was investigating him.Is it a state governed by the rule of law?Daphne Caruana Galizia pointed to the corruption of Maltese politics.After her death, it became clear how great the scale of corruption is in this democratic Member State and how no one accepts responsibility.Is it a state governed by the rule of law?All this reminds me of my country, Slovenia.In Slovenia, too, we are witnessing corruption, which has its tentacles high in the country's top.In Slovenia, as in Malta, no one has resigned.We have one of the worst judicial systems in the EU.People who were in positions at the time of the big money laundering and business affair with Iran are today in the role of investigators, discovering that there were no irregularities in NLB's operations.Dear colleagues, what is this, is this a rule of law for you?

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on Multilateral negotiations in view of the 11th WTO Ministerial Conference (2017/2861(RSP)).

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, there is only one month remaining until the WTO member states will be in Buenos Aires for the 11th Ministerial Conference of the WTO. It is a critical moment for WTO. A strong, multilateral trading system with the WTO at its centre is very much in the interests of the EU and the world. It is the best way to deal with international trade issues and it is now being seriously challenged. Both central features of the WTO; its negotiating and its dispute settlement, are under severe pressure for the moment. A month from MC  11??, the prospects of a negotiated outcome still remain highly uncertain, although some elements are becoming clearer. We will see a difficult process of negotiations regarding a possible ministerial declaration where the questions of how to prioritise work for the future will be key.  Preparations for the conference are significantly affected by the situation surrounding the ?? body where the unprecedented decision of the United States to block the appointment of new members put at risk the functioning of one of the most important and well-functioning elements of the WTO. We are, of course, ready to discuss possible concerns regarding the ?? body but we cannot and we will not accept measures which weakens it or puts its independence into question. Today, it is more important than ever that the EU shows its strong support for the work of the organisation. Following the success of the last two conferences in Bali and Nairobi – notably they accepted the adoption of the trade facilitation agreement – and an agreement on agriculture export competition, it is important that the positive momentum is maintained and that concrete outcomes are agreed.  The European Union is working very hard in Geneva with other countries and we have taken the leadership in preparing such outcomes by tabling texts in several key areas. Unfortunately, the divergences among the members are still strong. Despite our efforts to build convergence among members, there is a huge uncertainty. The WTO members are pursuing the objective of reaching agreement on public stock-holding for food security and fishery subsidies. We support this; this would be good, but we strongly believe that it would not be enough; it has to be part of a broader package, in particular, including e-commerce, domestic regulation in services and new transparency rules benefiting SMEs. In this context it is necessary to accelerate the work towards a balanced package. Let me just give you a few details on where we are. Firstly, public stock holdings for food security purposes and fisheries subsidies have garnered support of most of the membership in terms of aspiration for outcomes. If this is not sufficient in terms of the outcome, we will continue to work in these areas, but also it has to be accompanied by progress in other areas. We have tabled together with Brazil and other WTO members a former current proposal for a comprehensive solution addressing domestic support in agriculture and public stock-holdings, and we really think this is a realistic proposal. However, there are other proposals on the table reflecting unrealistic ideas that are not boding well for a substantial outcome in agriculture. Regarding fishery subsidies, the political commitment to implement the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goals on marine resources has contributed to advance work here, but it remains doubtful whether we can be able to achieve an ambitious outcome. Secondly, we also believe that other issues that are of relevance to many WTO members and relevant to today’s global trade should be addressed. As I mentioned, domestic regulation of these services, e-commerce, transparency of regulatory measures; these issues are right for the MC 11. Moreover, it would be important to agree on a strong future-orientated element which would set the stage for the post-Buenos Aires work avoiding contentious and sterile debates about Doha Joe and non-Doha work.  Thirdly, there has been call by some members, notably the United States, to reform the WTO. We are ready to engage in discussions on this, but we need to see concrete proposals on what precisely such reforms would entail. We are also finally committed to work on trade and gender, and we support the declaration on trade and women’s economic empowerment, and that will be adopted in the margins of the conference. Mr President, Honourable Members, this is an up-coming conference which is of utmost importance. We need to make sure that we can defend a strong, functioning WTO with concrete outcomes because it has to be at the centre of the multilateral trading system. I very much appreciate the support of the European Parliament and I am looking forward to seeing the big delegation that you will send to Buenos Aires in four weeks. Thank you very much.

name: Paul Rübig
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Malmström! I would like to thank you for your commitment, and I believe that it is important for us - and I believe that I am speaking for Mr Lange too - that we advance the agenda. If we assume that the WTO was only founded in 1995 with the mandate to conclude multilateral trade agreements and therefore to fight poverty in the world, then we have seen that it is not so easy to come to a common denominator with over 160 countries come. I can still well remember 1999, when we stood in front of huge demonstrations in Seattle and tried to put forward sensible arguments, and ultimately also the 2001 Doha agreement with trade aid for developing countries. We have now received a supplement from the UN with the goals for sustainable development. These are big steps in the right direction at the international level. Ultimately, we succeeded in setting up a parliamentary assembly for the WTO on equal terms with the Interparliamentary Union and the European Parliament in 2003, the main task of which is to educate the MEPs of the least developed countries and to help them with their governments to negotiate at the same level. In 2015 we finally pushed through the agricultural agenda. I think it is important for all of us that the agenda now brings another great success at the eleventh conference. That helps people in this world.

name: Bernd Lange
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! Yes, we support the work of the Commission, even if we have disputes at one point or another. But in this case, 100% support, because we really want the multilateral trading system to be strengthened. Only if we succeed in continuing to work on a rule-based level can we guarantee that trade is beneficial for development. That's why we're so behind it that we will also have a success in Buenos Aires. We need a clear signal that the overfishing of the seas through illicit subsidies will end. We must also give a clear signal that food storage, in order to guarantee food safety, has a longer-term solution. We also have to look at how we can integrate the goals for sustainable development, as well as the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, and also the question of trade and gender balance. These are the most pressing problems that we must tackle multilaterally. Therefore, of these 164 countries, it cannot be that one or two countries should join in sabotaging this system. I find it scandalous that the United States is trying to challenge the system by not nominating judges to the Appellate Body. I find it scandalous that the United States is refusing to think about concrete progress and even refusing to put a text on the table at all. This is of course a basic requirement in order to be able to actively participate, that we agree on a text, on concrete steps that may also go beyond Buenos Aires. That will be the central task so that this one country does not get away with it, but that we can move forward together.

name: David Campbell Bannerman
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, having recently returned from an international trade mission to New Zealand, a country that is among the world’s greatest exporters, and now with no subsidies for its farmers, I reminded them of the importance of free trade and open markets through the World Trade Organization (WTO). The ECR Group is committed to the multilateral trade agenda and to a positive outcome at this biannual WTO ministerial conference this December. I will do my part working together with the world’s trade ministers to champion the central role of the WTO as a global rules-based organisation. The WTO is quite simply the spring that flows into the rivers of trade agreements around the world, including all EU trade deals and amongst the WTO’s 164 members. We support the outstanding items of the Doha Development Agenda, but where progress is not possible, the WTO should not stay stuck but advance in areas where it can progress, for example, e-commerce, investment facilitation, and in services by seeking to unlock the Trade in Services Agreement (TiSA) on top of GATS. Trade liberalisation has shown huge benefits for developing countries, but trade facilitation and market opening must be accompanied by appropriate flanking measures covering, say, education, equality, infrastructure development and good governance. The work of the WTO and a commitment to multilateralism are absolutely essential to this aim.

name: Hannu Takkula
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - (FI) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, multilateral trade is currently going through difficult times, with a few members in the WTO who are not strongly committed to a common agenda. However, we need multilateral rules for global trade, and the commitment of a few countries to common decisions is not enough. Achieving sustainable solutions requires that everyone play by the same agreed rules. In Buenos Aires, we must also have a strong debate on substance issues. It is absolutely vital that the EU takes an active role in the next Ministerial Conference so that we can guarantee constructive results. Agriculture and e-commerce are themes where we have a lot to discuss. In these sectors in particular, common rules are absolutely essential, and with regard to agriculture, we still have room for concrete results in the Ministerial Conference. As we know, we have Members who are unwilling to commit to anything concrete at the moment, but we must also always remember what the situation looked like before Nairobi, the last meeting. So we still have the opportunity to get a constructive result in Buenos Aires if we just go there with an ambitious agenda. And I believe that is what we will do.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner! The world is changing. The WTO is changing. Multilateral trade is facing enormous challenges. Global value creation processes, changes in traditional goods production, data-based production in industry and agriculture, services and new rules are increasingly determining the agenda of trade and economic cooperation in all countries and regional cooperation structures. The old trading powers - and the USA has already been mentioned - are fighting back against new competitors. The globalization of the productive forces has brought about changes in the world economy. At the same time, all WTO member states have to deal with the fact that they have committed themselves to the sustainability goals of the 2030 Agenda within the framework of the UN. Keyword: poverty reduction. How to deal with it responsibly in the interests of citizens and citizens on all continents? That is the order of the day in Buenos Aires in December - no more, no less. This WTO ministerial meeting will only move forward if the old commitments of the Doha Round are finally honored. Before that, there will hardly be a universally acceptable breakthrough, including on the other questions already mentioned. The EU has to deliver. Perhaps the Parliamentary Conference can help.

name: Klaus Buchner
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! We take every opportunity to make it known how important common global and multilateral trade rules are to us. At the same time, the EU is rushing forward and concluding trade agreements with only one or with a few trading partners. In this way it weakens the chances for an agreement of the World Trade Organization and at the same time for global agreements in which the developing countries can also have a say. They are left out of these bilateral agreements. But now to my most important concern: At the forthcoming 11th World Trade Organization Conference, the conclusion of the so-called Doha Round is of particular importance. This is about an agreement on food safety and the dismantling of unfair food and fishing subsidies that make poor countries even poorer and destroy the environment. If we do not manage to abolish this soon and get fair rules, then we will create even more refugees, even more poverty in these countries. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, it would be fatal news for these developing countries if we were to vote the resolution that will be voted on tomorrow as it is proposed, namely that we start negotiations on electronic commerce immediately, without the Doha Round. Please think of the developing countries!

name: Tiziana Beghin
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the world has never been so interconnected and yet it has never been so unfair. That is why the WTO must function and ensure fair trade based on clear rules for all. The WTO undeniably needs a renewal that puts citizens at the center, but this cannot happen without the essential contribution of the United States, which instead is working systematically to weaken it or enslave it to their own interests. Rights and trade run along the same track, and if the WTO begins to do the dirty work of Americans and question the danger of using cadmium, glyphosate and hormones in food, then we will stand still and look at big countries like the United States or China to destroy our laws. From the Buenos Aires conference I expect a concrete commitment to finally relaunch the WTO in this sense, or we might as well say goodbye to this institution.

name: France Jamet
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 21 different and varied points are raised in this motion for a resolution. And if, as Director General Roberto Azevêdo acknowledges, these suggestions should probably have no impact - each state benefiting de facto from a veto right -, unfortunately it sometimes works and, in these cases, it does. t is always to our detriment. Thus, in Occitania, and more particularly in Sète, our rapeseed biodiesel producers have been forced to reduce their activities and lay off workers following the European Union's decision to promote the import of Argentinian soybean biodiesel. Indeed, each time, Brussels prefers to sacrifice the interests of the economic actors of the Member States on the altar of ultra-liberalism, which the WTO defends, rather than to protect our entrepreneurs and our producers from globalism and unfair competition. We are determined to defend another choice: that of intelligent protectionism and the defense of our production and the jobs of our compatriots.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, after Brexit I am pleased that the United Kingdom will have its own functioning trade policy outside of the European Union. We should freely look to new global markets where 90% of the world’s growth will be seen in the next 15 years. Since December, the Government has been in discussions to reclaim our place as an independent member of the World Trade Organization (WTO). The final terms of our membership will depend on the deal struck between the United Kingdom and Brussels. A comprehensive free trade agreement that retains cooperation with the European Union is the most preferable. However, the European Union’s block on opening talks on the future relations is preventing progress. A no-deal scenario would see us revert to trade on most-favoured nations tariffs. Research by the think-tank Civitas suggests that this would cost EU firms twice as much as those in the United Kingdom. UK exporters would face 5.2 billion in tariffs on goods being sold to the EU, while EU exporters would face 12.9 billion in the opposite direction. There would be 1.8 billion worth of tariffs on German car-related exports alone. So consider, colleagues, while Brussels continues to preside over demands for the divorce bill, it should be aware that actions have consequences on both sides of the Channel. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – In 30 seconds I have many questions, and I accept your figures about the potential costs from a ‘no deal’. You and I share a boundary – it is called the border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland – and I hope and expect that both you and I understand the dire consequences for our citizens if there is no deal and should things go wrong. I would ask you to reflect on your words about a divorce bill and, rather, frame it as a divorce settlement. For all divorces, if they are to be good ones, there is a cost, and I would ask the UK to meet its commitments so that we can move on.

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – Of course, and I thank my colleague for the question. In terms of the divorce bill we are an honourable people. We have said we will meet reasonable demands and I believe that that is right and proper, and I am happy to put that on the record. But what we should not meet is the exorbitant, ever-ongoing demands that seem to be now made, and we need to progress quite quickly. In terms of Northern Ireland, I think that you and I would both agree that we do not want to see a hard border, but this will require cooperation from both governments, the Republic’s Government and the United Kingdom’s Government, and so far I think that the Republic has been lacking. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I simply wanted to ask Ms Dodds if she would look at the screen, which says: ‘multilateral negotiations in view of the 11th WTO Ministerial Conference’ and tell us in her reply to my 30 seconds, what on earth her contribution had to do with the subject we are debating today?

name: Diane Dodds (NI)
text: blue-card answer. – The World Trade Organization (WTO) will be an incredibly important organisation for the United Kingdom going forward. We seek individual membership of that organisation and we continue to support it as a rules-based organisation for international trade. However, what we should absolutely be clear about here is the consequences of not negotiating a free-trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the rest of the European Union, and sometimes this needs to be spelt out for our European partners and for the benefit of their constituents.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, last year's election of the President of the United States has not only changed the foreign policy of this country - we have seen the recent visit to Asia, or with China, Russia, Iran or Cuba, but above all and fundamentally commercial policy. The TTIP negotiations have been suspended, it has been decided not to ratify the Trans-Pacific Agreement, the NAFTA agreement has been revised and, above all, a series of batteries of protectionist measures have been adopted. It must be said, Commissioner, that the Commission has reacted quickly and efficiently, carrying out a whole series of very important negotiations at the bilateral and regional level. It is in this context where the meeting of the ministerial organization of the World Trade Organization is located, which the commissioner has defined in her initial intervention as critical. And here it is not only a matter of maintaining the agenda, which is supported by Parliament's Resolution, but above all of trying to ensure that the principles of multilateralism that the World Trade Organization represents survive. Non-discrimination, progressive and reciprocal liberalization of exchanges through dialogue, predictability and legal security, and the resolution of disputes. For this reason, Commissioner, this meeting in Buenos Aires is very important. We trust the Commission and we hope that the multilateral round and the bilateral negotiations under way - Japan, Mercosur, Mexico and Chile - will prosper successfully and on schedule. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, you said that, among other things, the Commissioner stated here that it is a critical situation at the meeting in Buenos Aires and you also mentioned the future agreements that we have to make: with Japan, with Chile, Mercosur.What do you think are the critical points regarding future trade agreements?Do you think we need to make trade deals and, if so, what are the critical points you see?

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE)
text: "blue card" response.- I think this is a question that is more directed at the Commission than at me.It was the commissioner who said that we are experiencing a critical situation.I share that statement and I believe that trade is progress, that trade is peace, and I believe that the walls, the walls, today are situated in the Palaeolithic of European history.And precisely what we have to build, as Commissioner Malmström says many times, are bridges and not walls.These negotiations are obviously very important.They have their sensibilities on both sides, but I think that logically we should aspire to build and conclude successfully ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: - Mr. president. Thank you very much, Commissioner, for your work and defense of multilateralism and the WTO, and of course, my congratulations also to the two co-rapporteurs. We all know the difficulty of reaching international agreements, but also that they are essential in defense of world peace and stability. It is true that it is necessary to reform the WTO, but, as you have just said, with concrete proposals. Multilateral entities cannot be blown up in a misunderstood defense of national interests or block any progress in favor of the global governance of trade. We are seeing Trump's protectionist threats become reality as he blocks the election of members of the WTO Appellate Body, putting the very raison d'être of this organization at risk. Against Trump's "America first", we defend "People First" in the European Union. And that is why tomorrow's favorable vote is so important. To support the Commission in its negotiations before the next ministerial conference in Buenos Aires and, of course, also, so that the recommendations of this Parliament are taken into account, so that we can advance and update the Doha development agenda, ensure fair and sustainable trade in agricultural and fishery products, effectively achieve a permanent solution for the public food security reserve and face new challenges. It is also important in e-commerce, in SMEs and of course, to include the gender dimension in trade policy. I'm done, president. I ask, please, majority support for this report. (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: - Taking the floor in the debate on the preparations for the 11th Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organization in Buenos Aires, I would like to emphasize that it is agriculture that should be the central element of the declaration that will be made at it. In my opinion, future EU obligations under the WTO should not force a change in the current support mechanisms for European farmers and agriculture under the Common Agricultural Policy. These obligations should also leave the necessary margin of freedom to shape the current CAP, also in the future, including the possibility of using instruments currently classified into the so-called amber box, and thus support disturbing international trade. European agriculture has so far provided effective food security for Europeans, and it is only the violent turmoil in some agricultural markets that we see how food prices develop when certain products are becoming scarce, such as the butter and chicken eggs currently on the market.

name: Marietje Schaake (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, this debate could not be more timely. While the EU continues, and we should pursue an ambitious trade agenda with global rules, other parts of the world are also moving on. Last Saturday, 11 countries agreed, in principle, to move ahead with the Trans-Pacific Partnership, without the US. The Trump Administration seems to have no desire to advance a multilateral trading system either – how quickly times can change. The blocking of judges on the World Trade Organization’s (WTO) Appellate Body is also a troubling case in point. More than ever, European leadership is needed to safeguard international trade based on rules. Only by thinking globally, but also joining forces with like-minded partners, can we advance the multilateral trading agenda. An agenda including modern 21st century principles, such as services and digital trade, but first and foremost an agenda that sets high standards and is based on the values that we here in Europe cherish.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would remind the Commissioner that Parliament, led by the rapporteur Ms Schaake, is now discussing the EU digital trade strategy and it is very important that the EU should manage to bring its values and norms in digital trade to multilateral bodies such as the World Trade Organization. However, I would like to issue a brief warning: in my view, this should not be done at the cost of unfinished negotiations in the WTO. I would like to know what you think about this, Commissioner. There are challenges for the global south in including this very important new dimension in trade agreements at all, so I would suggest that before formally engaging in negotiations on new topics we should conclude the Doha Round. Let me also point out that the EU has a lot to do in terms of increasing the transparency of the WTO’s processes and introducing the Sustainable Development Goals to its work.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė (PPE).
text: - A strong World Trade Organization is vital for Europe to promote open markets and free and fair trade in the world. It is therefore very important that the decisions of the Buenos Aires Ministerial Conference are balanced in the interests of the European Union and provide clear work programs for the future, in key areas such as horizontal subsidies, e-commerce, removal of non-tariff barriers, streamlining the WTO and implementing transparency commitments. Given the passive involvement of the United States in the run-up to the forthcoming Ministerial Conference, the avoidance of the appointment of judges, it is necessary to find ways to constructively involve the United States in the processes and to put issues of European Union agenda on the agenda. We face new challenges as overproduction. The problem is great, with significant economic consequences. As a result, the EU's efforts in the WTO, the G20 and other formats are crucial to tackling this problem, which is caused by unfair subsidies to certain sectors. An example is the steel sector, where Chinese government subsidies have caused the crisis. The solar modules and batteries sector faces the same challenges. This also directly and negatively affects Lithuanian producers. In conclusion, at the same time, it is important to ensure that the commitments made at this conference in the area of ​​domestic support for agriculture do not in any way affect our room for maneuver in reforming agricultural policy. The "red lines" cannot be crossed.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, notwithstanding the Commission’s and the Commissioners’ Herculean efforts to keep the show on the road, it is, frankly, quite difficult to imagine a positive outcome to the 11th Ministerial Council. The agenda that the Commission are promoting on fishing subsidies, on food security, on transparency and on e—commerce is the right agenda.  But it is disappointing that, as other colleagues have said, historically, our biggest ally on many of these issues, the United States, will not be supporting us in Buenos Aires. It is sad that they have moved from a nation based on promoting a global rules—based system, to one that now seems to be more interested in protecting its own very narrow interests. The 2017 US Trade Representative (USTR) trade policy agenda, for example, states that the administration will not be bound by WTO rulings that undermine the ability of the United States to respond effectively to unfair trade practices. That does not inspire you as a nation that is committed to seeing the development of the WTO as a rules-based organisation. Nevertheless, notwithstanding that, we should be prepared to listen to the United States’ proposals for reform, but that has to stop short of undermining in any way the developments that we have seen in terms of two thirds of the WTO membership now being from developing nations, and we should not undermine their role and their equality in the organisation. Reform, yes, but not back to a rich man’s club.

name: James Nicholson (ECR).
text: – Mr President, there are many misconceptions about the attitude that EU producers have towards free trade. The truth is, all they want to be given is a level playing-field and it is an understanding from the sensitive sectors that they will be defended. All too often, there is a sense that agriculture is simply used as the last bargaining chip in the negotiations, so I do welcome the fact that the Committee on Agriculture (AGRI) will have a representative travelling to attend the meeting in Buenos Aires and this is particularly timely in respect of many of other things, and I have to say that this debate is extremely timely as well. The truth is, I think we should go to Buenos Aires and the World Trade Organization (WTO) in a positive way because in Europe we don’t believe we have much to fear. I think we have got to be positive, we should not be negative. I posed the question on agriculture the other day about multilateral versus bilateral, and I think that when some of us look back to the past we are maybe sorry we didn’t get better deals under the multilateral system, and I am more worried about what the Commissioner is up to in the bilateral negotiations she is having in Mercosur at the moment than I am with the rest. Trade is extremely important, we all know how important it is, so that is why I believe we must go positively forward. But we all know there is no such thing as a quick fix, and there is no such thing, above all else, as a quick trade deal. So from that point of view can I just say that compared to the last speaker I am not as confident that the UK will come out of the negotiations all that well.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the idealistic days when it was argued that trade could help to ‘make poverty history’ seem long ago now. The data are clear that trade has benefited a tiny elite and massively increased global inequality. The trade system we have now prioritises the interests of capital above those of people. We can change this and we must, if we are to defeat the forces of nationalism and reassure our citizens that globalisation can work for them. Forgive me if I doubt the extent to which this concern was considered seriously at the recent WTO discussions. While Commissioner Malmström is developing plans for a Multilateral Investment Court to protect businesses from potential losses, the UN is debating an international binding treaty enforcing minimum human-rights standards on multinational corporations, who too often slip through national legal controls. Given the clear support by the European Parliament for such a charter, it was deeply disappointing that the EU chose to hold hands with the Trump administration in an attempt to block this process.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: - Mr Chairman! It seems that the rumors of the disappearance, not to mention the death of the WTO, which appeared in recent years on the wave of the growing popularity of regional agreements, have turned out to be premature. This organization continues to be the most important forum for trade negotiations on a global scale.
