The agenda of the upcoming 11th WTO ministerial conference in Buenos Aires is dominated by issues related, inter alia, to internal support for agriculture in the world. It is good that the European Commission adopted a proactive approach in the context of this meeting, although the joint EU-Brazilian proposal did not satisfy everyone. The overriding objective of the Union in the area of ​​trade, including agricultural trade, should be the unification of standards and the removal of technical barriers in order to level the conditions of competition on the global market. To this end, it is necessary, inter alia, to help developing countries to build their certification systems. At the same time, of course, we must fully safeguard the interests of our agriculture, especially if the negotiating partner is a significant exporter of agricultural products. At the same time, concessions in the agricultural sector cannot be accepted for benefits elsewhere. The European Commission recently published an analysis of the impact of future trade agreements on the agricultural sector in the Union. However, this study did not take into account the full range of agricultural products and did not consider processed products. There are also no references to non-tariff barriers. Therefore, a supplement is needed to increase its usefulness. (The chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: - (Start of intervention off microphone) ... harder will be at the center of discussions at this conference in Buenos Aires with the issue of support for farmers on the menu. I am one of those who think that the common agricultural policy must be reformed in depth and the positions of the European Union at the WTO should not preempt our future debates. Let us not place additional constraints on ourselves, Commissioner, I ask you, in particular, to allow us to continue to provide support to our sectors in difficulty. Please, no cap on the blue box, we must keep some leeway in managing future crises. Europe has already modified its agricultural policy several times to comply with the WTO with market-oriented components and export subsidies. This is not the case with the other major agricultural powers. Once again, the Union should not behave naively like the only good student in the WTO.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, in the last two years there has been a strengthening of sovereign political options and movements in the Western world.I view this process with approval, but unfortunately it also shows some side effects, such as negative attitudes towards free international trade and open economic cooperation between countries.In this way, it is difficult to create new wealth and ensure stable growth.A multinational trade framework, no matter how unpopular it is today on both the left and the right, must exist in order for bilateral talks and fair agreements to take place against it.The resolution correctly recognizes the need for a better framework for digital commerce and easier investment.I agree that in this respect the rules of the WTO must be improved in order to fully follow the spirit of the times in which we live.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the agenda for this ministerial conference is not overly ambitious and I am not so sure that our hopes are very high, but I think we will go there as the European Union in good faith. What strikes me is that, in the absence of a structure like the World Trade Organization that functions, there is a yawning gap, a vacuum. The real worry – and others have mentioned this – is that one of the main global players, the USA, is not participating fully in the WTO at the moment and is perhaps acting to weaken the structures that we all rely on. It is also important to mention that, every time trade is discussed, agriculture is very high on the agenda, and there is no agreement as to how to deal with agriculture, save to say that it is a sector different from others. It is about rural areas, about people, about food and food security, and I hope the sensitivities of agriculture will be fully taken on board at our meeting.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - We support various trade agreements that facilitate the purchase of services and products, but also reduce prices.What I would like to emphasize today is, first of all, not to seek compromises, but to seek optimal solutions.In these optimal solutions, the key is to protect smaller business entities.Flexibility is very important, as is faster response to the changing market, especially to trade, exchange and internet services.The digital world has changed the world of commerce.What is worrying now, however, is primarily the attitude of the United States towards international agreements.The American market is almost self-sufficient, but individual markets of countries weaker than those that operate in the European Union are not so strong.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I do not know if the interministerial meeting of the WTO in Buenos Aires will be the last chance, but what I know is that it is urgent to act if we want to save this institution currently struggling with the multitude of bilateral agreements and the lack of enthusiasm - to say the least - of certain established or emerging countries to respect common rules. More judges are essential to enforce them. The European Union, which is the good student of the WTO, must not suffer from this lack of sufficient control. For my part, I would like to speak specifically on the issue of public services which, from my point of view, must be protected in order to meet the needs of citizens and territories. Yes, to international rules for trade in market services, but an exception for public services freely set up by public authorities.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the WTO Ministerial Summit in Buenos Aires gives us the opportunity for a fruitful reflection on the future of the WTO, which, while supporting fair trade and development, in practice reinforces social inequalities, poverty and openness. markets that disintegrate local economies. The famous facilitation of international trade through the WTO is therefore dissolving the European South, small and medium-sized enterprises, the Union's agricultural and livestock sector. The WTO is stepping up outsourcing, the transfer of industries to the developing world and unfair trade practices, as these European and other multinational industries located in the developing world do not comply with the International Labor Office's labor laws and are now thriving there. child labor. So despite the growth of trade and the increase of food stocks, the hunger of the populations is increasing. We expect another study of the social impact of the WTO operation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, we are, in principle, opposed to the public statements and actions of the US President, which disrupt and undermine the equitable cooperation of States. Some things need to be done immediately. Increase pressure on the United States to comply with the Climate Change Protocol and, secondly, consider referring the United States to the Arbitration Committee, as the US position is tantamount to a covert subsidy for its domestic industry, which which is not in line with WTO regulations. Finally, an immediate solution is needed to the copyright agreement. Trade, ladies and gentlemen, must serve the people and not the other way around, that is, the people or the states must serve trade. What is happening today is that weak states, in order to defend themselves, prefer to enter into bilateral agreements rather than be in WTO cooperation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: - Mr President, the Union's participation in the World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference can play an important role in the regularity of a multilateral trading system. The topics of discussion, such as the goals of sustainable development and the commitments of the Paris Agreement, are not of minor importance in relation to trade promotion and connectivity for sustainable development. However, the results of the common commercial policy, despite good intentions, show that it has destabilized the markets of the Member States, does not fully guarantee reasonable prices for European consumers and does not fight unfair competition. What primarily affects the lives of European producers and consumers is the legitimacy of public procurement, the survival of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, subsidies, e-commerce, unnecessary quotas and the viability of their companies. Especially for the Greek producers and traders, who have been literally destroyed by the memoranda, the recession and the arrhythmias of the Common Agricultural Policy.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I really appreciate the support that you have given to the Commission and the EU negotiating tactics here, and the priorities. Ideally we would depart from Buenos Aires just before Christmas with a balanced package of negotiated outcomes and an ambitious agenda of work going forward. It would show that the World Trade Organization (WTO) is still relevant, still alive and kicking, and that the multilateral global trading system is still there and is functioning. Certain forces are putting that into question. I can tell you that it is not only the US, there are also other countries who are problematic in this regard, but we are really working towards that aim in the European Union. Our team in Geneva is doing a fantastic job to reach out to the different embassies and delegations there. I have personally spoken to a lot of different ministers, and our people around the world are trying their utmost to see if we can find compromises that are as broad as possible. As I told you, we have in the EU, sometimes together with other countries, put forward proposals that we think would bring the multilateral agenda forward. We always had the least—developed countries in mind at the centre of this, in order to see how we can help them to further integrate into the global trading system. As for the proposals, you could say that they are not ambitious enough, but they would still move the global agenda forward in a way that is reasonable in 2017. Bilateral trade agreements are today necessary as a complement to that – the WTO cannot solve all the issues that ambitious trade agreements can do bilaterally, but the multilateral system is still key in this, together with its disputes system. That has been working very well and it has served us in the European Union well, but it has also served the United States very well – evidence shows that they very often come out winners of their procedures. We must really find a solution to the blockage of the Appellate Body. I heard many concerns here about agriculture. There is a willingness to debate trade in more general terms. I am happy to do that on another occasion. I can assure you that we are very aware of the limits and the red lines when it comes to agriculture. So you can rest assured that we will not compromise on this, and I will also be going with Phil Hogan, we will be there together for the whole week. We are not naive, we know that it is not easy to agree, it is difficult enough between 28 countries in this Union but in the WTO there are 164 Member States. So it is not easy, but when we do agree it is really powerful. We are also willing to listen to calls for reform: an organisation always needs to reform, but it has to be in a way that strengthens and further develops the WTO; it cannot be a way to undermine or to weaken the WTO. That is why we need to listen to concrete proposals and bring that forward. That discussion cannot take hostage the actual agenda of the WTO Ministerial Conference. I thank you for the resolution that I hope you will vote through tomorrow. It contains a lot of very important issues and I am happy that there will be such a knowledgeable and an engaged delegation in Buenos Aires from the European Parliament, and I look forward to cooperating with you there.

name: President. –
text: Madam Commissioner, thank you. I appreciate the fact that this is a debate where you have responded to the question – I think the applause is a sign of that. This is not always the case with every Commissioner, so it is highly appreciated. I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 15 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The World Trade Organisation regulates international trade. All major decisions are made by member governments, either by ministers who usually meet at least once every two year. The forthcoming 11th WTO Ministerial Conference will be held in Buenos Aires (Argentina). In this context, I call on the Commission to be closely involved in the preparation of the WTO Ministerial Conference. The EU, as a world’s leading trading power, should persuade WTO Member States to further develop e-commerce and turn digital opportunities into trade realities. WTO Member States should acknowledge the fact that internet connectivity offers business opportunities like never before by making trade easier, cheaper and accessible.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing.- The WTO (World Trade Organization) is an instrument of neoliberalism that promotes the globalization of markets through liberalization, deregulation and privatization.The economic prosperity it promises does not exist, the rules it imposes and the free trade agreements it promotes consist of making it easier for transnational corporations to continue to obtain enormous benefits at the expense of the increasing exploitation of the working class, the peasantry, the indigenous peoples, land, territories and natural resources.Through the WTO and free trade agreements, large corporations are trying to usurp peoples' sovereignty, undermining the ability of democratically elected governments to take legislative measures to protect the rights of the population and the environment against the abuses of multinationals.Agriculture, public services, medicines and common goods must be out of the hands of the WTO.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Laima Liucija Andrikienė and Knut Fleckenstein, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on a European Parliament recommendation to the Council, the Commission and the EEAS on the Eastern Partnership, in the run-up to the November 2017 Summit (2017/2130(INI)) (A8—0308/2017).

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the Eastern Partnership policy is an important and long-standing policy of the European Union. We want this policy to be effective and result-driven. The summit in Brussels should be forward-looking, injecting new dynamism and providing a clear political vision for the future of our Eastern Partnership. If the Brussels summit lacks this and is only a stock-taking summit, if its final declaration lacks novelty, then the November summit will demonstrate the inability of the European Union to meet the challenges ahead of us, and it will be another missed opportunity. The European Parliament is far more ambitious than for instance some EU Member States. We in the Parliament fully acknowledge our responsibility for the consequences of any failure of our Eastern Partnership policy. That this why in our recommendations we propose very concrete steps to be taken by the European Union in order to guarantee that our Eastern Partnership policy is a success. The European Parliament is playing its legitimate role. Its recommendations to the summit should be taken into account and duly reflected in the final declaration. Among other important aspects of the EP recommendations, we propose an EAP Plus format which includes the establishment of a trust fund, a new European investment plan, a financial support mechanism for the implementation of the association agreements, etc. All these proposals are for the countries which have association agreements and free trade agreements with the European Union and enjoy a visa-free regime with the EU, namely Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova. When that time comes, when the homework is done and the necessary requirements fulfilled, potential membership of these countries in the customs union, the digital union and the energy union should be considered as an option. Secondly, differentiation is key, as our resources are limited. The principle of ‘more for more and less for less’ should be implemented. We should focus our resources much more on those Eastern Partnership countries who have made remarkable progress on their European path. A few words now about the trust fund and the new European investment plan. In the present geo-political context, and taking into account the geo-political realities, we should offer Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova – and in our recommendations we proposed that – a new European plan for these countries, including a new investment plan to boost investments and economic development. According to international experts, a sizeable doubling of the volume of investment, for instance in Ukraine, of up to EUR 5 billion annually can result in 6-8% annual economic growth in the country over the next 5-10 years. Conditionality is in place also. I have in mind structural reforms and the creation of an investment-friendly environment, the strengthening of the rule of law and the fight against corruption in the countries concerned. This is absolutely a must. The investment support is dedicated not to the oligarchy – not to profit oligarchs in these countries – it is dedicated to ordinary people, notably in such fields as energy savings, road infrastructure, jobs, public services, small and medium-sized businesses and reconstruction if, as in the case of Ukraine, the country is at war. I look forward to our debate.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The aim of the Eastern Partnership is to offer our neighbors Ukraine, Georgia, Moldova, Armenia, Azerbaijan - and hopefully soon Belarus - political dialogue, economic cooperation and support in their reforms. Therefore, the summit must not be an exclusive inventory. We have put a lot of effort and work into the AFET committee, which is also evident from the fact that there is a great deal of agreement between the groups here. We did this because we believe it is important that we give a unified signal that we still want and want to develop this Eastern Partnership. I am very excited to see how the Council will deal with our proposals, especially since the summit declaration has already been written. Yes, Article 49 of the European Treaties applies. But in fairness we have to say so as not to arouse false hopes: We are far, far away from it. Still, there is no reason to despair. Because we would like to contribute to the summit and show that our report also provided attractive long-term models for an expanded Eastern Partnership. Accession to the customs union, energy union, digital union, the Schengen area and the gradual abolition of roaming charges indicate a wide range of ways in which this Eastern Partnership can and should be further developed. This applies first of all to the associated states. But we also agree that the path must also be open to others who follow within the Eastern Partnership. We recommend that the Commission do its utmost to encourage multinational or multilateral financial institutions such as the European Investment Bank to become more involved. Various types of trust funds are also conceivable, as we have shown. But we also have to say very clearly that we are the Eastern We want partnership and that we have ideas to further develop it intensively. The prerequisite for this is the implementation of the agreed reforms. So far we cannot be satisfied with this implementation everywhere. The summit must therefore not only talk about what has been achieved, but must also clearly state what still needs to be done and where schoolwork has to be done. This is not about the rules that we make out of Brussels. Every country is free in its decisions. Nobody has to do Commissioner Hahn or President Juncker or Mrs Mogherini a favor. However, the results of our cooperation must be tangible for the local people. The results of our cooperation are important for the citizens in the partner countries, and therefore it is important that we not only talk about infrastructure, reducing socio-economic disparities and visa-free travel, but also about the fight against corruption, for example. It is also important for our fellow EU citizens to want to know from us who we are actually benefiting from with our measures. They don't end up wanting to hear that a few oligarchs got richer. They want to hear that something is moving in the system. To conclude, let me say one thing: I know that this is always critical here: relations with Russia are also important for the economic and political stability of our eastern neighbors. The Soviet Union no longer exists, everyone has to get used to it. But those who do not take their neighbors and their interests into consideration will not be able to live in peace with them in the long term.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I wanted to participate in this debate because the Eastern Partnership Summit is coming up and I would like to share with you some thoughts and to listen to your recommendations. The fifth Eastern Partnership Summit on 24 November will be the key event in the Eastern Partnership since the last summit in Riga in 2015. I do not have to underline the importance the Estonian Presidency attaches to this event and indeed to the whole policy of Eastern partnership. In Riga, we reaffirmed our strong engagement and our firm determination to pursue closer, tailor-made relations with the six partner countries. This summit, which will be held for the first time in Brussels, will build on that. It will provide an opportunity to reaffirm the EU’s united and strong commitment to its Eastern partners and project a message of confidence. It will also highlight the value of the Eastern Partnership for citizens of the European Union and the partner countries, while providing them with tangible solutions and concrete benefits. The summit will take stock of developments across the four priority areas of cooperation: economic development and market opportunities; strengthening institutions and good governance; connectivity, energy efficiency, environment and climate change; and, fourthly, mobility and people-to-people contacts. There has been much progress since the Riga summit. Association agreements between the EU and Georgia, the Republic of Moldova and Ukraine have fully entered into force. Significant reform efforts in Georgia and Ukraine have enabled visa liberalisation for the citizens of these countries. Relations with Belarus, Armenia and Azerbaijan are being enhanced on a tailor-made basis, either through the pursuit of new Framework Agreements or through new coordination arrangements. The Eastern Partnership has also further advanced on the basis of the revised European neighbourhood policy and the EU global strategy. However, the summit will also have a forward-looking and result-oriented agenda and will provide an opportunity to discuss ways of strengthening bilateral, multilateral and sectoral cooperation. The Council is currently working hard on the summit joint declaration, with the aim of reiterating the inclusive, consolidating and forward-looking nature of the Eastern Partnership. On the basis of the 20 deliverables for 2020 prepared by the European External Action Service (EEAS) and the Commission, in cooperation with Member States and partner countries, the summit is expected to provide guidance, in particular, on the four priority areas of cooperation with their tangible and visible impact on people’s lives. The list is long. It includes the fight against corruption, the modernisation of public administrations, improved transport and energy connections, digitalisation, greener economies, trade and investment promotion, support for small and middle-sized enterprises, educational exchanges and youth empowerment. Several important events have taken place in the run-up to the summit, demonstrating that the Eastern Partnership goes beyond inter-governmental relations to involve civil society, media, businesses, youth and other stakeholders. I would like to recall the following events that have contributed to preparing the discussion among the summit participants: the third Eastern Partnership Youth Forum in June in Warsaw; the second Eastern Partnership Media Conference in September in Kiev; the Eastern Partnership Civil Society Conference and the Business Forum in Tallinn in October. In addition, the Estonian Presidency organised an e-Partnership Conference at the beginning of October in Tallinn, as well as four ministerial-level meetings: on justice and home affairs, transport, and the digital economy as well as a post-Gymnich informal lunch for Foreign Ministers, devoted to common challenges in the security field. As you see, the preparations for the Eastern Partnership Summit go hand in hand with the activities undertaken by the European Parliament when preparing and adopting the report containing the recommendations to the Council, the Commission and the EEAS. The Council agrees that further actions need to be built on the previous commitments and on citizens’ expectations, and they need to provide new impetus for the future of the partnership. Last but not least, we will work to ensure that the visibility of the EU’s engagement in the Eastern Partnership demonstrates that we are stronger together. The Eastern Partnership is based on a free choice of the parties involved and is aimed at promoting prosperity, stability and good governance without affecting third parties. The Eastern Partnership is the only EU policy in which we state that the policy is not directed against anyone – and, of course, this is true. Bearing that in mind, we also need to recognise that the Eastern Partnership has become part of the EU’s policy towards Russia. In March 2016, the EU Foreign Ministers adopted five guiding principles for the EU’s policy towards Russia: one of the principles is strengthening relations with the EU’s eastern partners, and rightly so. Active communication about the summit and its objectives is being coordinated with EU Member States and the six partners, with the aim of providing factual information and countering disinformation. I would like to thank the honourable Members for their attention, I will listen carefully to their recommendations and I will convey them to my colleagues in the Council.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this discussion is, of course, extremely timely in the light of the summit that starts in a week, but, as the President has indicated, the summit has already started in a way. There have been a number of related side events involving young people, media, civil society, business, etcetera, because the whole point is to engage broadly, putting citizens at the centre of this partnership. Our engagement goes well beyond governments and, as you know, it has a very strong parliamentary dimension. The Euronest Parliamentary Assembly ordinary session took place two weeks ago in Kiev, and I know that both the plenary and the various working groups were conducted in a very constructive atmosphere, and the message of the Euronest bureau was adopted unanimously. That has sent a very powerful message to those involved in preparing for the summit. We welcome the attention that the European Parliament is paying to this, and I would like to thank the two rapporteurs and acknowledge all the work that has been done in the various committees and groups. As the report highlights, the summit is an opportunity not only to build on achievements to date but also to inject new dynamism into relations with the partnership countries. We are building on the existing policy network and particularly the global strategy for foreign and security policy, the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) review and previous summit declarations. However, let me also stress, as your report does, the importance of the 20 deliverables for 2020. This is an ambitious programme aiming at very concrete achievements. The report by the Committee on Foreign Affairs takes into account some of the key elements that have been identified for the summit: firstly, supporting an ambitious investment for the trans-European transport core network; secondly, increasing political ownership of energy efficiency; thirdly, supporting SMEs and their access to finance; fourthly, paving the way for a reduction in roaming tariffs among partner countries; fifthly, boosting trade opportunities with the EU and among the partner countries; sixthly, providing broad and targeted support to grass-root NGOs; seventhly, supporting young people, and especially addressing youth unemployment through entrepreneurship education; and, finally, stepping up strategic communication through a comprehensive approach based on the four priorities agreed in Riga and the new Eastern Partnership visual identity. These initiatives are all in line with the 20 deliverables. Our priorities are perfectly aligned and they all stem from the most urgent needs of our citizens. We take these deliverables very seriously and we want to make sure that they are implemented in a transparent and accountable way. The recent evaluation shows that, overall, we have made good progress on our commitments, especially with respect to the milestones set for the summit. But, at the same time, each country from the Eastern Partnership has specific needs and specific aspirations, so differentiation is an important principle of the partnership. Association agreements are now fully in place with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. We have concluded negotiations for a comprehensive and enhanced partnership agreement with Armenia – we will sign that on the fringe of the summit – and we are negotiating a new comprehensive agreement with Azerbaijan. Relations with Belarus are evolving through the EU-Belarus Coordination Group. We have taken note of the proposed ‘EaP+’ model contemplated in the report, seeking to offer new opportunities especially for the associated countries and, while we remain ambitious in our proposals, we must also remain realistic and preserve the inclusive nature of the EaP which involves all six partners. This inclusivity is key, not only to bringing our people closer together, but also to contributing to further coordination and cooperation between the partners themselves. This has been part of the logic behind the whole partnership from its inception and, for these reasons, we believe the focus should be on implementing existing commitments reflected in the various agreements and documents and the 20 deliverables, as I mentioned. In doing that, the Eastern Partnership should be taken forward not in isolation but in conjunction with other global commitments: the Sustainable Development Goals, the Paris Agreement, etcetera. Sustainable development in the Eastern Partnership matters to the European Union. We all realise that our neighbour’s strength is our own strength, so our neighbours’ security and stability are very much linked to our own security. The fact that five out of six partners suffer from protracted conflicts is a reflection of the challenging security situation that we have in our neighbourhood. Our Eastern partners are indeed experiencing at first-hand the challenges of the European security architecture, as the Foreign Affairs Committee report highlights. The Eastern Partnership was never designed as a conflict-resolution mechanism, but it has a unique framework for building confidence and progressively strengthening the resilience of states and societies. We believe that the resolution of conflict in the region requires respect for international law and that peace will come in the framework of agreed negotiated formats. But peace also requires good governance and democracy, better economic opportunities for all, better infrastructure and closer people-to-people contact. This is what the Eastern Partnership is about and this is what we will highlight at the summit next week – not a partnership against anybody, as the Presidency said, but a partnership for the economy and for trade, a partnership for resilience and good governance, a partnership for democracy, the rule of law and human rights. The summit next week is essential to achieve practical progress on all these issues. I know this House is very committed and we count on your support not only in the run-up to the summit but also afterwards, to help in implementing and moving forward.

name: David McAllister
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! Indeed, the Eastern Partnership Summit in ten days' time is about finding new ways to achieve the objectives of Article 8 of the Treaty on European Union. It is about building special relationships with our neighbors and at the same time creating an area of ​​prosperity based on the values ​​of our Union. Just as the Commissioner has just done, I would also like to make the association agreements with Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine, which have come into force over the past 18 months, very positive. Nevertheless - and everyone in this room knows the six countries concerned - regional tensions and strong deficits in democracy and the rule of law slow our partnership to varying degrees, depending on the country. In order to increase the willingness to reform in the countries of the Eastern Partnership, the European Union should - and it should do this more clearly than before - formulate requirements that are more concrete and measurable, better support civil society in the partner countries and, in particular, the principle " Apply more for more and less for less ”more consistently. These key points are contained in the report by colleagues Andrikienė and Fleckenstein. It's a good report. It was passed by a large majority in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. We share the expectation that these points will also be taken into account in the conclusions on November 24th.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to start by highlighting the importance of an efficient and strategic Eastern Partnership for the security and stability not only of our partners, but also of our Union, and this is the right place to welcome and applaud the commitment, the energy and the vision of the Estonian Presidency in building such an opportunity for all of us. The importance of these countries is shown by the way other actors like Russia behave when we try to bring them closer to the European project. We have already managed to achieve a lot and to show the benefits to our partners, including visa liberalisation, the freedom to travel across Europe, and economic exchange which has only increased in recent years. And yes, more appetite for the democratic functioning of their societies. But here, referring to the shopping list, I will start first by referring to the frozen conflicts. We have and we need to have the courage to discuss the frozen conflicts because these are the ones which destabilise not only those countries, but equally, the region, and have a negative impact on our Union as well. In addition, let’s not forget hybrid threats and cyber—threats to our partners and the daily propaganda campaigns that destabilise and negatively affect the perception of our Union within those societies by trying to destabilise the functioning of the institutions. The November summit should enhance East StratCom capabilities and focus on the way to fully promote the principles of democracy, the rule of law and good governance. In a nutshell, all the advantages of EU integration. But let’s be open, let’s be wise and be strategically driven, to treat the region not in terms of how much money we spend but of how many strategic benefits we take out of this more stable, better functioning region. This is our duty, and we are the only ones who can do that. At the same time, we must also be ready to give all the support and assistance required without ignoring the specificity of each and every country. I wish us every success.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, given the strong political links that I have enjoyed for many years with many of the Eastern Partnership countries, some of which boast large diaspora communities in my London constituency, I am pleased today to debate the upcoming November summit. This September has finally seen the full implementation of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area (DCFTA) with Ukraine and talks continue to progress with Armenia, in concluding a comprehensive and enhanced partnership agreement – one that does not affect its membership of the Eurasian Economic Union. We also see an existing Association Agreement in DCFTA with Moldova and Georgia already in force. All of these initiatives are important, improving economic and political links between the European Union and each of the respective Eastern Partnership countries, but we can still do more. If the Eastern Partnership is to become a meaningful instrument, its incentives must move beyond those on offer to other third countries further afield. This resolution proposes, therefore, the Employee Assistance Programme (EAP+) model which would plot a course beyond visa liberalisation and Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) to potential membership of the Customs Union, the Energy Union and perhaps the Schengen area. This would follow the mantra of ‘more for more’ and act as an incentive to encourage further reforms and bring the Eastern partners more closely into the European orbit. Allowing greater benefits as outlined in the EAP+ model would offer a favoured relationship to countries with whom the EU is geographically, culturally and historically linked. This is not a partnership against anyone, but it is a partnership of our common, shared democratic values. Maybe post-Brexit, this will be the kind of arrangement that the UK ends up with.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I wish to start by welcoming the Parliament recommendation on the Eastern Partnership summit to be held in Brussels in 10 days’ time. It is a solid and forward-looking document which contains very concrete elements of further engagement, such as Eastern Partnership Plus and fully fledged CSDP missions, just to mention a few. I call on the summit to read the document very carefully, and most importantly, to come from a perspective that is the role of the European Union to act, and to be an engaging and responsible partner. Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are the only EU neighbours with Europeanisation and pro-European reforms clearly set as their national and strategic goals. They expect reaching a true partnership with us, the European Union. If the summit fails, despite being action- and engagement-oriented, this will only mean that our partners are addressed with a message of a new, so-called ‘paper curtain’ – another effort to keep Europe divided with a huge bureaucracy, distrust, and indifference that we brand as ‘fatigue’. It must not be us and them, it must be all of us together, it must be about a Europe whole and free. My worry is, however, that the ‘more for more’ principle so proudly proclaimed in Riga is now being turned into a ‘one-size-fits-all’. This size will be destined by the participation of Alexander Lukashenko, Europe’s longest-serving dictator. I remain strongly convinced that this invitation is a critical mistake.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner! It looks as if your colleague Hahn's term of office will continue to be shaped by the fact that he has to shape a failed policy. Unfortunately, I have to draw a different conclusion than many of my colleagues. Two years ago the Eastern Neighborhood Policy was supposed to be realigned. There is no talk of that today, despite the Association Agreement and more for more. Some target countries are migrating to alternative integration projects. The Associated Ukraine and Moldova are politically stagnating or experiencing regressive social developments. The intended standard export from the EU to these countries is politically ineffective. The hopes that the peoples of these countries have attached to the EU for support for social, political and economic transformation for all members of societies are disappointed. The European Parliament recently started to press the Commission finally to binding conditions for EU services. However, today's resolution throws that approach overboard: blank cash checks and perks are being redistributed to oligarchs. The upcoming summit will not induce the positive changes announced here by the rapporteurs, the Council and the Commission, which sound good.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mister President! Especially after Mr Scholz's speech, I would like to say again that it is actually very fortunate for the citizens of the European Union that the states in our eastern neighborhood are in favor of the way to the west and the way to the European Union decide. Democracy and the rule of law in our neighborhood are the best assurance that we too can continue on our peaceful and stable path in the European Union. Just after your speech, I would like to point out again that, in my opinion, the reforms to which the states in our neighborhood - our partners - have committed themselves in the association agreement, are taking place under much more difficult conditions than the reforms that are being carried out in the Baltic countries or in the countries of the Warsaw Pact - including in your home country. Because these countries had clear prospects of accession for the difficult path of reforms. Today we no longer make it easy for our neighbors. We make it much more difficult for those who have it much harder. And that is why I would like to take this opportunity to expressly appeal to the summit as the chair of EuroNest: Don't be petty! Appreciate this decision, which is basically made for democracy and the rule of law! And keep the doors open to the European Union. Because the reforms that are now pending without going through this perspective make it much more difficult. In addition, Russia has made every effort, Putin has made every effort, to complicate this process, which the states had voluntarily chosen, to make more difficult. It is a very important point in the resolution of the European Parliament that points out that we must also help the countries against occupation, against annexation and against these so-called frozen conflicts to find a way against Putin.

name: Raymond Finch
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, our shared security on the European continent is vital to our mutual safety and prosperity. The UK has always contributed to maintaining this security and will continue to do so in the future. NATO and the Commonwealth have shown the way for sovereign status to cooperate while retaining independence. State governments have built up over the last 70 years an expertise on Russia and the East and this, along with NATO, has kept the peace. Instead, what the EU offers is political subjugation to Brussels. The idea that the EU equates to security for either its current or potential members is false. The EU shooting from the hip can only jeopardise this fragile peace. I firmly believe that the ambitions of your European project run contrary to the security of Eastern Europe and are a direct threat to the hard-fought independence of the countries in this region. Fear of Russia should not lead towards serfdom to Brussels.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, when it gets involved in foreign policy, the European Union has it all wrong. This recommendation from Parliament is a perfect demonstration of that. Unsurprisingly, she is very hostile to Russia, made solely responsible and guilty of Ukrainian evils. May the Atlanticists, here present, remember the Kosovo jurisprudence. They also remember the interference by NGOs funded by Georges Soros and supported by the European Union, on the pretext of strengthening civil society. The path taken by this partnership pushing to put Russia at odds with its neighboring countries is irresponsible. The European peoples, whom you are supposed to represent, have no interest, but then really no, in seeing relations between the European Union and Russia deteriorate even further. The sanctions, in addition to being completely unnecessary, have cost tens of billions of euros to our farmers, in particular, not to mention billions of euros in aid poured into these corrupt countries which are also costing taxpayers dearly. Europeans, but pay big to some elected officials or European officials, for example, the "caviar diplomacy" of Azerbaijan, according to the revelations made by the press last September.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: - Mr President, the Eastern Partnership is an ambitious but also a sensitive policy of the European Union, which if not implemented properly risks creating many problems in the Union. Although 8 years have passed since its inauguration, the positive results are very limited. It is the signing of association and free trade agreements with Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine and some promises from the European Union to liberalize the visa regime for the issuance of visas. On the other hand, in almost all the founding members of the Relationship, there have been problems of deteriorating human relations and the application of the principles of democracy. In addition, Azerbaijan and Armenia continue to have disputes over the Nagorno-Karabakh region, and Belarus, among others, has participated in the large-scale Russian-led Zapad exercise in October 2017. The European Union must therefore pay particular attention to the further handling of the Eastern Partnership and not use it as a means of putting pressure on Russia by making concessions to its partners, especially when they demonstrate that they do not respect international law and challenge and enforce fundamental principles. European authorities.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Eastern Partnership has been a success. It has been an important instrument in building support for democracy, the rule of law and human rights in the countries of our Eastern Neighbourhood, and it has also been instrumental in supporting the process of reform. But having said that, we also have to admit that the progress along the road of reforms and on the pro-European path has been uneven among the partner countries. In this context, I very much support the recommendations of our Parliament, especially of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, to apply the principle of ‘more for more and less for less’ which would simply mean that the European Union is ready to respond to more expectations and hopes on the side of countries that are willing and able and ready to be more ambitious on the pro-European path. I think this is an important signal that the European Union should send in order to support pro-European tendencies in those countries. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, I always appreciated very much your interventions on issues like the Eastern Partnership. Don’t you think that it might be time for the European Union to differentiate, among the member countries of the Eastern Partnership, between those countries that have or could have the possibility in the future to join the European Union, and other Eastern Partnership countries that will never join the European Union?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am very much in favour, let me repeat, of the principle of ‘more for more and less for less’. Those countries that are willing and display more ambitions to join the European family of nations should be given this possibility and this opportunity. I do not want to close the doors to the European Union to anyone. I would never say that any country would in future not be admitted. Everything is in the hands of the countries concerned. We should be open to those who are prepared to fulfil the conditions, display the respect for democracy, the rule of law and the principles of the market economy. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking my blue card. Have you not just let the cat out the bag by saying what you said about those countries that want to seek European Union membership? Is this not actually a ploy and openness about your, the European Union’s, neo-colonialist ambitions now to actually increase your empire further? And now that you have this defence force, does that not now give you the military power that you’ve desired for so long?

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I could not disagree more. I have never had the idea of the European Union as a colonial power, contrary to the UK in history. So I have to insist that it is up to the applicant countries first of all to display this ambition to join the European Union and then to fulfil the conditions. Nobody forces anyone, any country in Europe, to be a Member of the European Union, but everyone is welcome provided that the conditions are fulfilled.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, firstly I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on this excellent report. As many colleagues have already said, this is a significant report with substantial recommendations. It highlights the need for clear, political vision for the Eastern Partnership and it is important to note that this specifically includes gender equality, which I’m afraid neither the Council nor the Commission representatives mentioned. Our European values are part of what makes us attractive in the EU, and in our partner countries. The inclusion of the principle of a ‘more for more and less for less’-based approach and the aligning of financial support to this principle is a practical way of implementing the differentiation that is necessary. I’m also glad to see the inclusion of Georgia in a proposed Trust Fund, and the stress that the fund should focus on social and economic infrastructure. I hope the Brussels summit conclusions will respond to and reflect the direction of this report.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Russia’s policies create a direct security threat to a majority of our Eastern partners. War in Ukraine, including the annexation of Crimea, borderisation in Georgia, and destabilisation in Moldova are matters of the utmost international concern. Acknowledging the open, inclusive character of the Eastern Partnership, we have to ensure that countries pursuing aggressive policies, violating international law, are excluded from participation in the project. We have to ensure this by adopting appropriate language in the summit declaration.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Eastern Partnership summit, among the few successful foreign policy projects of the European Union, is doomed to continue and is doomed to be strengthened and supported because it is imperative that the security situation in the area, a situation quite delicate in a rather turbulent period, to be maintained, a beneficial issue for the European Union as well. It is also important that this partnership includes elements of economic cooperation and it is very important to support the European aspirations of the three states and to strengthen democratic standards and cooperation with the other two that have chosen less than the other three states. We must not forget that these states are former Soviet republics and the data, geopolitical reality and security in the area is not one that makes us abdicate and behave beyond what a partnership means. These states need support, they are fragile democracies, they have an economic situation, the vast majority of them are precarious and if the European Union wants them together it will have to support them.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, the European Parliament's recommendation on the Eastern Partnership is a special mix of realistic, ambitious goals, political declarations, senseless Russophobia and ignoring the results of referendums in many countries. The ambitious goals include the liberalization of the visa regime, or the achievement of visa-free travel on the basis of set criteria and a readmission agreement with individual states. Unrealistic goals include efforts to reduce dependence on fossil fuels with the decommissioning of older nuclear power plants and attempts to prevent the construction of new facilities, such as the Ostrovec nuclear power plant in Belarus. The report completely ignores the results of the popular referendum in a number of countries in the region. There is no mention at all of the inadmissibility of building foreign bases in this part of the world. And it sets out in an unprecedented way what is and what is not acceptable in the military. The Minsk agreements completely lack an appeal to Ukraine, which is clearly not complying with them. For these reasons, I cannot support the report.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: - I would like to reiterate the statement that has already become an axiom that the Eastern Partnership is first and foremost a testament to the soft power of the European Union.And a test of how much Europe can be a world leader.How much can be an alternative to aggressive chauvinistic dictators.It is very good that we review the results of the Eastern Partnership every year at summits.It would be even better if the leaders of the European Union and the countries used such meetings to articulate our core values and ensure that they were implemented.We must make it clear that creating a nuclear threat at the European Union's border, as Belarus is doing, is strictly outside the 'red line'.Otherwise, we will continue to have an inexplicably generous Europe and its neighbors who think that Europe has something to give them just because they are.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the European Union has long sought justification for its defence ambitions by seeking out problems in its near neighbourhood and fabricating a role for itself, despite the existence of more appropriate and effective institutions such as NATO. A consequential side effect of the British electorate’s wise decision on Brexit has clearly increased its impetus for a common EU defence policy. There are many things that I fear about these developments – some more pressing than others. This report openly discusses the deployment of Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) missions into Ukraine and elsewhere. Thus, the EU now seems eager to try out its new toy and Eastern Europe might well prove to be its playground. This clearly contradicts its ridiculous mantra about the EU supposedly keeping the peace in Europe.  Do not become entangled in complex security situations as a means of justification for your political ambitions! Have you learned nothing from the lessons of European history? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – When I listen to our colleagues on that side of the House, I wonder: have you learned anything about European history, and do you notice anything in European history? Do you look upon the development of Russia – where the rule of law is undermined, where democracy is undermined – as a good thing for Europe? Do you like that Russia is trying to do the same thing with all these countries? What would you prefer – for these countries to go the way of Russia, or to go the European way? Would you like them to be freer and more democratic or would you like them to follow the system of Putin and others? Tell us now – what would you prefer?

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – What I prefer is a military approach through NATO. Having had a grandfather who fought at Passchendaele and on the Somme in 1917 and 1918, and having had an uncle who laid down his life in a Lancaster bomber over Berlin in 1944, I very much know the expensive price of freedom that has been paid. I’m absolutely delighted that my country has taken the route through NATO. And I think history, as has often been said, is littered with wars which everybody knew would never happen. And this, I fear, is what is coming for the European Union.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF).
text: - Mr President, the Eastern Partnership, this European mechanism responsible for concluding political and economic agreements with non-EU Eastern countries, is still a fool's game which has tragic repercussions for them. Take Ukraine for example. This country has nothing to expect from the European Union in return for the Eastern Partnership, not even eventual EU membership, as a majority of member states oppose it. The Deep Free Trade Agreement itself is a European hoax for Ukraine. Most Ukrainian products, especially in the eastern industrial regions, will never be able to meet EU market standards and will therefore never be exportable. The more competitive EU products will continue to wipe out local productions in Ukraine and put millions of Ukrainian workers out of work. In reality, the only hidden goal of the Eastern Partnership was to deconstruct the previous economic and political relationship between Ukraine and Russia. Recall that the populations of Eastern Ukraine are of Russian culture, they are demographically straddled between Russia and Ukraine, and the entire economy of Eastern Ukraine was entirely Russian-oriented. Out of respect for the Ukrainians, let us stop this institutional lie of the European Union, the Eastern Partnership.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: - Mr Chairman!Starting with the freedom issue, I would like Mr Hökmark to compare taxation in Russia and taxation in the European Union and see then where there is more freedom, because the numbers decide.By contrast, when moving to the Eastern Partnership, very different countries are participating: countries where corruption is relatively low, such as Georgia and Belarus, and countries where corruption is huge, such as Ukraine and Moldova.It is a fact that corruption is a huge problem in these countries.There is one man who has partially mastered the corruption in Georgia and has improved the administration in Georgia.This is Mr. Michał Saakashvili, who is currently in Ukraine.I think it would be good for the Union to do something to help Mr Saakashvili, who is fighting the corruption of the current government in Ukraine.Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the Eastern Partnership is a partnership for freedom, democracy, the rule of law and peace. That is what we see. But we also see all the difficulties. And when I listen to the colleagues over there, and some of the colleagues over there, I see even more the importance of the Eastern Partnership, laying down the infrastructure for cooperation between all these countries and together with the European Union; but also calling for Russia to respect the sovereignty of each of these countries, because it is only in this way that democracy and freedom can be real. And calling upon all these governments to do more in order to get more, to secure the rule of law, fight corruption and strengthen democracy. Many of you over there, and many of you over there, are against that and that is why we are supporting the Eastern Partnership, for democracy, freedom and the rule of law.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, today Ministers Margot Wallström and Witold Waszczykowski published a joint opinion entitled EU’s Eastern Partnership needs revival. In it they point out that, despite past successes, the Eastern Partnership (EaP) needs a revival to remain relevant in the future and that it needs to be more focused on the needs of people and produce more concrete results. The other week we were in Kyiv at the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly and in our Committee on Employment and Social Affairs two burning issues came up. One is tuberculosis, the other is irregular and undeclared work. The data shows that the tuberculosis increase rate in all Eastern Partnership countries except Armenia is above 100 cases per 100 000 inhabitants, while in the EU in general this rate is below 24. We also agreed that our next joint report will be on irregular and undeclared work, which is another scourge both in the Eastern Partnership countries and in the EU, so I very much believe that it is high time for the Eastern Partnership to come down to earth and face real people’s needs. And one last quote from the joint opinion. Next year, Poland and Sweden will be represented at the UN Security Council. They say: ‘We want to use this opportunity to promote conflict resolution and crisis management, especially in the EaP region’. So let’s move beyond these geopolitical and reform—transformation mantras and try to use the Union’s Eastern Partnership to a good purpose.

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: - First of all, I would like to warmly thank both rapporteurs, my dear colleague Andrikienė and dear colleague Fleckenstein, for solid and inspiring recommendations for a vital Eastern Partnership. I also see their line well substantiated in the recommendations just published by a working group of experts from France, Germany and Poland, the so-called Genshagener Papiere. These experts rightly emphasize, and this is also reflected in the report by our Parliament, on the EU implementation of the Eastern Partnership "a shift from a government-centered policy to a citizen-centered policy". In other words: Brussels creates visible and tangible support among the population of the countries concerned. So, for example, provide stronger support for small and medium-sized businesses, an excellent driver of reforms and the growth core of a strong middle class. Two things were particularly appealing in those recommendations. Wouldn't it be a good idea to establish an Eastern Partnership University in the region to give promising young people a boost for European integration? And finally, consider the psychological effects of those unresolved territorial conflicts. There, too, a "Post-Conflict Trauma Healing Center" of European origin would be suitable.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the forthcoming 5th Eastern Partnership Summit will discuss the way forward in further strengthening cooperation between the partner countries and the EU. I believe it is time for the EU and the Eastern Partnership countries to achieve further progress in the four priority areas agreed in Riga: strengthening institutions and good governance; mobility and people-to-people contact; economic development; and market opportunities – but also connectivity, energy, efficiency and climate change. In particular, I believe it is time for the EU and the partner countries to meet the high expectations of citizens in the Eastern Partnership countries by adopting and fully implementing reforms related to the judiciary, public administration and the fight against corruption and organised crime, on the basis of an adequate road-map with clearly defined objectives and deadlines. In addition, the EU has to focus on its support for civil society across the region, because in recent years this has come under increasing pressure.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL).
text: - (FI) Mr President, the EU provides a lot of financial support to countries where values are still rooted in deep-rooted corruption and human rights abuses.We ourselves have reason to reflect on our values, because our own values have also hardened considerably recently: in speeches we glorify peace and equality between people, but in practice we also live whole families on the streets and Europeans are divided into successors and losers.What is the value for money we expect from our Eastern partners: for example, for people in different language groups to be entitled to the services they need and for children to be educated in their own language, or for some Eastern Partnership countries to brazenly collect EU money in their own pockets?

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: - Mr President, the complex mechanism and imperialist alliances that the European Union is setting up in Russia's soft underbelly, known as the Eastern Partnership, are accompanied by a number of shabby pretexts: tackling corruption, fighting terrorism, consolidating democracy. The media are known: gathering troops with or without NATO, infiltration of monopolies in new markets, sanctions, weeping and well-funded NGOs. At issue: which imperialist power - the European Union, the United States, Russia or China - and which monopoly groups will control its markets, energy sources and transportation routes? It is just one piece of the puzzle in the wider competition raging in the Middle East, the Balkans, the Mediterranean, Africa and the Arctic. The Greek government is also in the game, involving our people in adventures to upgrade the geostrategic interests of the Greek bourgeoisie. The peoples should not pay for the imperialist rivalries with their blood, with their struggle to claim and become the owners of the wealth that they produce and reap a handful of monopolies.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Estonian Presidency’s endeavours to reaffirm a united and strong commitment for the Eastern Partnership, because what we really need is to inject new dynamism and set a clear long—term political vision for this system, because association agreements do not necessarily constitute a final goal. Therefore, I would say that the summit should knowledge very clearly the European aspirations of these nations, including sometimes a right to apply for EU membership. I should encourage also the European Commission and European Investment Bank to agree on a long—term strategic investment bank, especially for Ukraine and also the other two Association Agreement countries, accompanied by a necessary support mechanism. Finally, I shall support the establishment of the special trust fund for Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia and hold a donors’ conference to support Ukrainians’ humanitarian needs. I think they should constitute priorities for the next conference.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is now time to take stock of the different choices and the specific progress made by the six countries. We can no longer ignore the gap and the divergence in ambition and aspirations. The new state of play must be reflected at the summit and in our policy. The three associated partners, Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine, have made substantial progress on EU reforms while also making a clear strategic choice and political commitment. They have real and tangible European ambitions – they are simply part of Europe. This is why it is high time to inject a new dynamic into the Eastern Partnership and to set a clear political vision by doing more for those who have decided to join the European path and who deliver. This is the spirit of the EaP+ model and the trust fund, and we expect the Council and Commission to embrace this new vision.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: - On November 24, at the summit, we must tell the Eastern Partnership countries two things clearly: first - we are with them, we want them to come to Europe on the road to European integration because only in Europe is democracy, peace, true justice and justice for all and individual prosperity. I know it's very hard, the fight between communism and democracy, and it's very hard for them to break away from communism, but we help them and we are by their side. The second thing we need to say very clearly is that they will join the Union only under certain conditions. We no longer accept the double language: money from the Union and reforms on paper. People want to see real reforms and new ones as well. Another thing I would like to refer to briefly: the fake Russian propaganda that is everywhere in these countries and that is very harmful. It presents the European Union, for example, that it is collapsing or even absurd statements that we are banning snowmen in the European Union. So this propaganda can no longer be accepted, we have to come up with smart means, with knowledgeable communicators, to overturn these lies about the European Union.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: - I am pleased that Estonia, as the Presidency of the European Union, has always unequivocally supported freedoms and the strengthening of the rule of law in the Eastern Partnership countries. At the same time, unresolved conflicts remain a concern for several Eastern Partnership countries: Russia's continued aggression in Crimea; war in eastern Ukraine; Georgia, South Ossetia, Abkhazia; The conflict between Transnistria and Nagorno-Karabakh in Moldova. These conflicts are a major obstacle to the development of our Eastern Partnership countries and also a threat to European security. It is therefore very important to maintain the European Union's common approach and pressure to resolve these conflicts that still exist in Europe. The Eastern Partnership Summit in November must also send a clear message that the European Union expects to make substantial progress in eradicating corruption, fighting organized crime and strengthening the rule of law and good governance. Reforms must move forward and the principle of 'more for more' must be followed. Reforms to strengthen the rule of law and democracy must also be carried out in our Eastern Partnership societies, first and foremost for their own sake.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - President! There is a delicate, sensitive issue for the Eastern Partnership countries: their relationship with Russia. There are those in conflict between them and there are those who nurture good friendships. Russia is a dominant state in the region, without the elimination of conflicts and the completion of the partnership. The US President said in Hanoi that it is very important to maintain good relations with Russia. Will the EU still be in sync with the American view, as it did under President Obama? The EU should also review the effectiveness of sanctions. It did not achieve its political goal, but at the same time caused severe trade losses for many member states. Just tomorrow, we will be discussing here the critical situation of the EU fruit and vegetable sector, which has arisen as a result of the Russian ban. That speaks for itself. So, also in the context of the Eastern Partnership, the Union should rethink its policy towards Russia.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: - Mister President! First of all, thanks to the rapporteurs for a forward-looking break. It is good that we have tailor-made programs for the six countries. Because we accept that their level of ambition is different. If someone does not want to sign an ambitious DCFTA, we certainly do not answer with green men and tanks. Four of the six countries certainly claim to become democratic European states that function normally internally. We already support this extensively: the focus here is on establishing the rule of law and fighting corruption. Let us continue to encourage all political and civil society actors in these efforts. I expect the Council to take note of the more far-reaching ambitions of some Member States and not fall behind the wording that has already been agreed. Success in the democratic and economic development of these countries is in our own interest. In the long term, however, we will only be able to secure this if we give those who wish to join the prospect of membership, as provided for in the treaty.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think that the European Partnership Programme is an ideological challenge: we understand that something does not work but really do not understand what. In Ukraine we have a lot of problems with mass media freedom, the fight against corruption and economic reforms. The new education act that eliminates education in national minority languages is an example of nationalistic policy that is not compatible with European values and the respect of national minorities. We cannot understand how to react in the absence of progress. We have received empty words and promises from some of our partners who exchange inertia for money and political support. We in the European Union should change our attitude. The positive example is Georgia. Georgians have made big progress. They have a lot to do in the future, but we can see real progress. I think that the European Union should support Georgia more actively and should not bind Georgia with the Ukraine and Moldova which, let’s be frank, do not show this progress.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR).
text: - The Eastern Partnership is a very important political project which is crucial for the future of Europe's immediate neighborhood. We have achieved a great deal so far, especially in relations with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. The reforms implemented by the governments of these countries must be continued with the consistent support of the European institutions and the Member States. They also enjoy the concrete achievements in demanding relations with Armenia and Azerbaijan. I hope that the November summit will bring concrete proposals to strengthen cooperation in specific areas and will guarantee long-term financial support for the most important projects. Realism in this area is more important than big, but impossible to implement in the short term, ambitions. Investments in infrastructure, building a professional public administration, or joint fight against disinformation and Russian propaganda, are currently the most important areas in which the EU can be particularly active.

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: - President! I appreciate the regional dimension of the Eastern Partnership. We must continue to build on this. Nevertheless, as the People's Party rapporteur for Armenia, I consider it important to introduce a longer-term 'Eastern Partnership +' model for countries that have made significant progress in implementing reforms. However, in order to strengthen the stability of the region, it would also be important to open this model to other countries in the partnership as soon as they are ready to make an increased commitment and make significant progress on reforms. Secondly, this time too, I raise the legitimate issue of the new Ukrainian education law. I welcome the proposal that the summit's final declaration explicitly protect the rights of national minorities in the field of education. The provocative Transcarpathian demonstration of the extremist Ukrainian military unit in Karpathsk-Sichi last weekend is a warning that the European Community must firmly reject the spread of ethnic intolerance and anti-minority discrimination.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, on the eve of the Eastern Partnership summit, it is good that a compromise has been reached on this report between the two rapporteurs so that potentially harmful political problems are avoided during tomorrow's vote. The European Parliament should have a more unified and clear position on this issue. The summit is significant, but its true value will be measured by the tangible results that the citizens of the partner countries must feel. The Eastern Partnership, there is no doubt, needs new energy and a renewed European vision. Adherence to the principle of "more for more" is crucial. I am pleased that the report confirms the European Parliament's current position that any European country can apply for membership of the European Union, provided it meets the Copenhagen criteria and respects the principles of democracy, the rule of law, fundamental freedoms, human and minority rights. The European Union is a community of values, its borders cannot be determined exclusively by geography. The association agreements with Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine are important, but they must not be the final stage in those countries' relations with the European Union.

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: - Madam President! Each country has a duty to maintain good relations with benevolent neighbors just as each country must defend freedom against unkind neighbors. The Ukrainian authorities should take into account that if in this House people who have always defended Ukraine's right to independence, defense and territorial integrity, today they must protest against the threats that have arisen for minority communities due to the school law, if these people protest is the best sign that there really is a problem to be solved. I call on the Ukrainian authorities to supplement the current education act as soon as possible with a stipulation that minorities whose rights are regulated on the basis of bilateral international agreements or agreements with international organizations are exempt from the rigors of this act. Ukraine has the right to resist sovietization in the social plan as well, but the fight against sovietization and the consequences of centuries of contempt for the Ukrainian language cannot take place at the expense of indigenous minorities who share the life of the Ukrainian nation.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: - Mr President, congratulations to Laime Andrikienė and Knut Fleckenstein on a very good report and recommendations for the forthcoming summit. The Eastern Partnership is without a doubt one of the most successful initiatives in the European Union's foreign policy. However, many neighboring countries are currently going through a turbulent period. We must therefore have a clear vision about the direction of this project and what we want to offer our partners. I am convinced that the Eastern Partnership should be about tangible results and the needs of the people of the partner countries. However, we must not forget the values, whether in the form of functioning democratic institutions, the rule of law or even the fight against corruption. I agree with the principle of differentiation in the approach to our eastern partners. It should also mean further fulfilling the "more for more" principle and stimulating reforms in countries that want closer cooperation with the European Union.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the Eastern Partnership cannot be questioned, it is based on a commitment between the European Union and the countries that are part of the Eastern Partnership, and I think we need to focus on the summit.
