In November, we will see how we look to the future, how we can instil a new force for action and establish a clear political vision for the future of the Eastern Partnership as a long-term policy, to ensure that the results of this summit a primary priority, a basis for respecting the fundamental values ​​of the European Union. It is necessary and necessary to check whether all the commitments already made by the Member States are respected and, of course, it has been said here and I would like to emphasize the need for Ukraine to revise the education law because yes, there are citizens who live there and cannot to study in their language. But I believe that we, the European Union, must work together for greater mobility with partner countries, support Moldova, Georgia, Ukraine in implementing the visa liberalization agreement, and take steps to ensure that suspension mechanisms are no longer activated in the future, in particular through close cooperation in the field of police and customs.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: - A few weeks ago I was still in the east of Ukraine. The immense damage, the stories, but especially the faces of the people made an impression. Sometimes full of upheaval, but often also full of expectation. From here this conflict seems to be over, but for the population there nothing could be further from the truth. Russian aggression and repression remain a daily reality. The integrity of other Eastern partners is also still under threat. We can expect a more active role from the EU here, because these conflicts also threaten European security. We must also be fair to our partners. Europe is built on pillars of democracy, the rule of law and solidarity, a well-functioning free market. The power of oligarchs, sometimes repression and corruption fundamentally run counter to this. Yes, there is progress and visa liberalization for Moldova, Georgia and Ukraine is the result of it. But we must ensure that all agreements are implemented. They are not best efforts obligations, but result obligations. Midfield is an important player in this. That must be able to play its part fully without being cut short. Let us deliver a strong message to the Eastern Summit. A message of support and partnership, but also of reality and commitment.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Russia's aggression against Ukraine continues, the annexation of Crimea continues and the occupation of two Georgian regions continues.It is essential that the forthcoming summit declaration explicitly names the fact of aggression, as the European Parliament does in its report.Russia's hybrid threats are spreading false information about the EU in the Eastern Partnership countries and trying to drive wedges between the nations of the Union.I would very much like the conclusions of next week's summit to address, in particular, the serious security threats.The summit declaration should express support for the deployment of an OSCE armed police mission to eastern Ukraine, as well as a determination to involve Common Security and Defense Policy missions or operations.Without outside reinforcements and international control of the border between Russia and Ukraine, the conflict will continue.

name: Joachim Schuster (S&D).
text: - Mister President! The Eastern Partnership is in a difficult phase of development. This is partly because the necessary reform process among our Eastern neighbors is very slow. The fight against corruption and the establishment of constitutional structures have stalled in Ukraine, for example. That is why the report rightly calls for financial support for our Eastern partners to be linked to specific reform requirements. Financial aid must not be disguised support for oligarchs, but must promote the reform process that must benefit the entire population. Conversely, this also means that financial aid can only be paid out if the requirements are met. To my regret, this has not always been the case in the past, because in an audit report on Ukraine the Court of Auditors found that financial support was paid even though anti-corruption requirements were not met. From my point of view, this must not happen again in the future. The fact that conditions are meant seriously must also be made clear at the summit and must always determine the Commission's practice in future.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, at the beginning I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on this report, which they managed to compile just before the Eastern Partnership meeting. I agree, it is not easy to win the battle between communism and democracy, but the Eastern Partnership is a success story and I am glad that all six countries are showing European aspirations and it is necessary, of course, that the citizens of those countries also notice this. The good position of our Committee is also the principle that we have applied "more for more and less for less", which gave us a chance for each of these countries to individually express their wishes and approach European integration individually. In any case, the geopolitical situation of these countries is very delicate, democratic standards are very fragile and from here, today, the message from my side to Russia is to enable them to develop in peace, to nurture democratic standards, to have less Russian propaganda there and to These six countries, especially I mean first of all these four countries: Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, but also Armenia, and of course Azerbaijan in part, which show aspirations, but also an invitation to Belarus to get involved in democratic processes. In any case, this Resolution before the Eastern Partnership meeting next week in Brussels was welcome.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - The Eastern Partnership is undoubtedly in a state of a certain crisis.Maybe this crisis is not very deep, but it is quite extensive.I am talking about this for two reasons: first, there is a clear gap in the assessment of what has been achieved.Our partners say that we are doing too little, we believe that their reforms are insufficient and implemented at an insufficient pace.What worries me, however, is a certain disproportion between the words themselves and the actions.And I will start right away with a reflection on us MEPs.Today about 50 people participated in this debate.However, we recently had the Eastern Partnership Summit, our Euronest summit in Kiev.There were only a dozen of us there.This worries me because proper dialogue, good communication must mean physical presence every time.Otherwise, we will not be able to convince our partners and our activities will not be effective enough.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: - First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleagues for producing a very important document.Since the last meeting of the Eastern Partnership countries in Riga, two years ago, great progress has been made, both in terms of the Association Agreements that have entered into force and in terms of granting visa-free travel to both Georgia and Ukraine.However, the actions of the Eastern Partners and the European Union need to be further strengthened and developed.It is crucial that the full potential of the Association Agreement is fully realized and that substantial progress is made in implementing the necessary reforms.I hope from the forthcoming meeting that new incentives will be agreed to deepen the political and economic integration of the Eastern Partners, that the mutual commitments of the European Union and the partners will be reviewed and that cooperation will be deepened to meet common challenges, especially in the field of nuclear safety and environmental protection.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the Eastern Partnership concerns Armenia, Azerbaijan, Belarus, Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine. Their economic relations can play an important role with the European Union, provided they are mutually beneficial. However, the European Union Free Trade Agreement with Ukraine, once implemented, is sure to lead to particular problems for European agriculture and livestock, especially for Greek farmers. We will have a particularly critical situation, as we will now have duty-free imports, total imports of livestock products - of dubious quality in fact - from Ukraine. In addition, what we need to keep in mind is that these countries must abide by international agreements on nuclear safety, and we are particularly concerned that there are obsolete nuclear power plants in Belarus and Ukraine. Unemployment will be tackled with investments in the region and of course not with the free movement of workers to the countries of the European Union. It is certain that, both in Greece and in the rest of the European Union, we cannot tolerate other economic migrants.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, there are some things that need to be specifically recorded. These six countries, which, together with the European Union, want to strengthen their relations, should take this issue into account and combine it with the necessary political balances with the region and Russia. Three of the six eastern countries, Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova, are pushing for closer ties, while Azerbaijan, accused by Brussels of human rights abuses, is taking a neutral stance. Armenia and Belarus lean more towards Russia. Thirdly, everything must be aimed at development within the framework of peace and sustainable development, and this can certainly not be achieved either in a spirit of conflict or, of course, by strengthening the oligarchs in some of these states. The fight against corruption should be the foundation of any European Union cooperation.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in my experience, if dialogue between governments is key, people-to-people contact is just as important for cooperation, intercultural dialogue and the breaking down of barriers. I therefore call for more support for grassroots projects and civil participation. I deeply believe that more consideration must be given to the power of civil society to pursue intercultural exchange, people-to-people dialogue and peace—building initiatives. Because it is what I did before I came into politics, I know that the Arts can be a powerful tool to bring this about. For example, the EU with its cultural diplomacy strategy can be a key player. It is able to share, support and develop best practice, particularly in respect of young people. I particularly welcome, therefore, the call in the report to guarantee access to key programmes such as Erasmus Plus and Creative Europe. A young generation in the Eastern countries has grown up with a European vision: they must not be let down. Their participation in decision—making that will affect their future is absolutely key. The Eastern Partnership mechanism must also encourage that, along with visa liberalisation.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, I remain convinced that the Eastern Partnership project makes sense in certain circumstances. However, I believe that it is absolutely essential to make a thorough assessment of his few successes and failures. Of course, it is necessary to think about its further development and direction. The variant of a multi-speed project seems to me to be as unacceptable as the idea of ​​a multi-speed Europe. It will only be a justification for the European Union's double-meter policy. Instead, we need to ask our partner countries what they really expect from the EU and in what areas we can help them. The headless pouring of money into the budgets of these countries without demonstrably successful reforms in the fight against corruption and justice also makes no sense. We need to focus more on investing in immediate progress for citizens. We are not talking about unraveling the whole project, but about its greater efficiency. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: blue card issue.- Thank you, Mr Maštálka, for accepting my blue card question.My question is: we know that Russia does not participate in the Eastern Partnership program, and it has certain conditions in terms of history and attitude.My question is: can you imagine a situation where the Russian Federation will one day participate in the Eastern Partnership?Thanks!

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- I remember when we spoke on this subject at the last plenary session - the Eastern Partnership - that the Commissioner said that this Eastern Partnership project was not directed against anyone, that is, against Russia, but for cooperation with Russia.So, colleague, I can imagine that it will be interesting for Russia if we create it so that it also cooperates on this project.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it has been a very long debate, but it shows the engagement and the high expectations that you all have, not only for the summit per se, but also for the whole Eastern Partnership agreement and how it should be developed. As was said, this is a partnership for cooperation, it is a partnership for trade, it is a partnership for people-to-people contact, and it involves a lot of different projects. Different countries have chosen different ways of incorporating, but they are all part of a very big network of different projects where we can support them on their way towards a stronger rule of law, fighting corruption, increasing the involvement of civil society, free press, and so on. This is not easy. Many of you know that these transitions do not happen overnight. Also, all six countries joined this partnership voluntarily and I am a bit surprised that some of you think you know what is in their best interests better than their governments themselves do. I would like to express my gratitude to the rapporteurs. You have done very good work on this, and I think the resolution is a useful contribution to the reflection on the future of the Eastern Partnership – for the summit, as I said, but also beyond that. Eight years after it was launched, it now has an established framework and it has reached cruising speed, but it has a lot of untapped potential. The focus needs to be on implementing the commitments that we have made for ourselves in making sure that all countries can benefit from the opportunities that are there. In this endeavour, we must be realistic and ambitious all at once, and I hope that the summit next week will convey a sense of unity and confidence in this partnership. I would like to pay tribute to the important role that you play as a Parliament and in the Euronest Parliamentary Assembly, and I hope that you will continue to support the legislative process that accompanies the reform effort in our partnership countries.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for the opportunity to take part in this valuable discussion, and my thanks to the rapporteurs for their invaluable work. I am sure that the summit on 24 November will reaffirm the EU’s united and strong commitment to the Eastern Partnership and will also provide guidance on how to strengthen this policy even further. I want to thank sincerely all those speakers who commended the Estonian Presidency’s commitment to this policy of ours. It really means the world to me. There were many contributions that showed clearly how much work still needs to be done in stabilising our neighbourhood, but there were also many comments about history, and indeed about geopolitics. The Eastern Partnership is a geopolitical issue. There is currently no consensus among the Member States about the membership prospects for the Eastern partners. Meanwhile, we need to do our utmost to help and assist these partner countries, who have freely opted to be that, to get as close to Europe as possible, and to integrate them as closely as we can into European policies, and, indeed, European bodies. It is a very simple piece of foreign policy wisdom that you want to have your neighbours as similar to you as possible. They are more predictable that way, and they are better to deal with. This very basic foreign policy wisdom applies to the EU’s neighbourhood policy as well.

name: Puhemies. –
text: Thank you to the Council, and Mr Maasikas, this is the first time I am chairing a plenary session as Vice-President, and this subject is very close to me, as is the next one.But before we move on, I will give the floor to two more rapporteurs.First of all, Mrs Andrikienė, two minutes, please.

name: Laima Liucija Andrikienė
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, first of all I would like to thank my co-rapporteur Mr Knut Fleckenstein for your excellent cooperation. I cordially thank our shadow rapporteurs and all colleagues who contributed to the draft report, in order to have well-balanced European Parliament recommendations for the Eastern Partnership Summit. I thank the Estonian Presidency for your commitment and your leadership and I sincerely wish the forthcoming summit every success. I very much hope that the recommendations of the European Parliament will be well reflected in the final declaration of the summit. On Belarus, President Alexander Lukashenko is invited to the summit. I hope and I wish that he will use this real opportunity to present and prove his country’s achievements in the process of European integration in becoming closer to the EU. Certainly, no one can expect the EU to stop defending human rights, equal opportunities, the rule of law, democracy and human dignity. These are our core values and we will stand firmly behind these values, whatever country is concerned.

name: Knut Fleckenstein
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I want to save a little time. I would therefore like to thank everyone whom Mrs Andrikienė also thanked, but not myself. But I thank you for your cooperation. It was not a given that we came to a common denominator so quickly - sometimes not so quickly. That's a good sign for this house. Second: I ask for caution. I don't want to go into everything now, I can't do that from the time, because we've already talked the house almost empty. But I would like to say something about one word, that is the word “success story”. I warn against it. To this day, the Eastern Partnership is still not a success story for me. In Moldova we had a government of friends of Europe that almost ruled the country to ruin. We notice that in Ukraine today the government is suddenly going backwards again when it comes to minority rights. And we didn't do everything right either. But I agree with all those who say: It can be a great success story if we can, so to speak, take each other at their word, if those who promise the reforms also do the reforms so that the people in their countries know that it is it is sensible to take this path - and if we remain predictable, that means: on the one hand, we do not promise too much, but on the other hand we stand by our word and really support it, not only in speeches here in the plenary hall. I am sure most of us will. And I'm sure it will be a great success story.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: written. - I consider it very regrettable that the EU continues to promote policies that threaten the well-being of European citizens, and that is why we reject the current Eastern Neighborhood Policy. The Eastern Partnership policy represents the EU's instrument for geopolitical rivalry with Russia in the common neighborhood and thus causes instability and insecurity in the eastern neighborhood of the EU. It ignores the historical, economic, cultural and human relations of these countries with Russia. It was developed as a tool for offensive strategies towards the relationship with the key neighbor - Russia - and underestimated its political, economic and security interests. While the EU made progress in developing relations with the countries of the common neighborhood, negotiations on strategic association agreements with Russia failed. This development culminates in a policy of confrontation between the West and Russia. Additionally, the ENP has never clarified its ambiguous relationship with EU enlargement, raised expectations about membership, which the EU is not prepared to meet, and fails to address the structural problems of poverty, unemployment and sustainable growth.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. - The Eastern Partnership Summit is a good opportunity to clearly define the future of our policy towards those neighbors who fulfill the obligations of the association agreements. Making the Eastern Partnership more attractive by enabling the neighbors to access in the future, e.g. the Customs Union, Digital Union, Energy Union and Schengen Area 8 of the Treaty on European Union, which states that the Union shall develop a special relationship with its neighboring countries, seeking to create an area of ​​prosperity and good neighborliness, based on the values ​​of the Union and characterized by a close and peaceful and cooperative relationship. However, both the deepening of relations within the "Eastern Partnership +", and even more so the possible prospect of EU membership, require significant progress in the process of systemic transformation in our neighbors. There is a need for consistent implementation of structural reforms for strong institutions and good governance. It is also necessary to implement EU values ​​such as respect for democracy, human rights and the rule of law. Together with the citizens of these countries, we expect a real reform of the economic system aimed at gradual elimination of monopolies, limiting the role of oligarchs and effectively combating corruption. The level of cooperation should depend on progress in implementing reforms. However, in the event of withdrawal of reforms, I support the Union's consistent compliance with the provisions on conditionality, including the possibility of suspending agreements.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: in writing.- The Eastern Partnership is high on the EU's agenda.We all understand that a secure neighborhood is also a guarantee of a secure European Union, and we must continue to actively contribute to and promote democratic change in the partner countries.I support the principle of 'support for progress' enshrined in the report.We must not forget that the application of this principle to partner countries must be clear, setting out the scope and quality of the necessary reforms in the field of human rights or the development of a market economy.The assessment of current commitments should also be focused on.The message of the EU institutions should be clear, appropriate and not subject to political sympathy or antipathy.EU leadership in this context is an opportunity to contribute to a breakthrough in relations, the development of democracy, the resolution of frozen conflicts and peace throughout the region.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE)
text: in writing. - In the context of the upcoming Eastern Partnership Summit in Brussels, summaries and assessments of achievements so far are justified. Particularly noteworthy is the inclusion of security elements in the policy towards our eastern partners. It is in the interest of the Eastern Partnership countries, as well as the EU itself, to diversify foreign policy, which may give greater guarantees of independence. In this context, there is a justification for the policy of promoting sovereignty and freedom of choice in the foreign policy in Belarus pursued by the Commission and the EEAS, although little progress has been made towards political liberalization. The multilateral dimension of the Eastern Partnership is of key importance here for countries such as Belarus. The example of Armenia, which joined the Eurasian Union in 2015 and then signed a "Comprehensive and Deep Partnership Agreement" with the EU in 2017 shows that some limited form of diversification is possible. However, greater flexibility in engagement does not mean that the EU should abandon conditionality, as it provides the impetus for the necessary reforms. The EU must place emphasis on enforcing existing commitments and implementing arrangements. Finally, we do not always manage to make good use of the opportunity to communicate the practical benefits of the Eastern Partnership. Where politics produces good results, they need to be talked about.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Salvatore Cicu, on behalf of the Committee on International Trade, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against dumped imports from countries not members of the European Union and Regulation (EU) 2016 on protection against subsidized imports from outside the European Union./ 1037 (COM (2016) 0721 - C8-0456 / 2016 - 2016/0351 (COD)) (A8-0236 / 2017).

name: Salvatore Cicu
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that we have a great responsibility towards the citizens who ask us for concrete and targeted answers to solve the dramatic problems that beset them. In the light of the commitments made by the European Union through the 2020 strategy, which refers to raising the employment rate in Europe by 75%, we need to ask ourselves a question. The important question is whether trade policy plays a central role in ensuring that growth, prosperity, employment and the maintenance of the welfare state are all interconnected. I strongly believe so. In fact, millions of jobs depend on the European trade agenda, looking for new markets abroad and certainly, also and above all, defining effective tools that protect our European industry. The question we are discussing today is not only whether China is a market economy or not a market economy, but rather that of understanding whether our European system can and must - in an obligatory manner in my opinion - fulfill the condition of giving rules that are equal for all and to give rules that start everyone from the same starting line, that is, fair and loyal competition. We know that European industry employs 34 million workers in our Member States, including hundreds of small and medium-sized enterprises, that between 2000 and 2014 the share of European production fell from 18 to 15%, which between 2008 and in 2014 3.5 million jobs were lost, and in the steel sector alone there is an overcapacity that becomes logically dangerous compared to the international market. I say this to make people understand and underline the strategic importance of this measure, which has aroused great interest from European industry but also legitimate concern, and which has always aroused motivation and interest here in the European Parliament. I am convinced so that the result we are arriving at is an important, fundamental, central result, with great work. And it is thanks to the collaboration of all the political groups and shadow colleagues of the Commission and the Council that it has been possible today to arrive at a shared text and a text which, in my opinion, is the best result we could have achieved. I try to quickly indicate which are the fundamental steps. First of all, the possibility of continuing to use an alternative method of calculating dumping compared to the standard one, the strengthening of the definition of significant destruction and with the inclusion of criteria that finally become complete and strong, also especially to the contribution of Parliament with respect to the valid Commission proposal, and which also go in the direction of finally giving an opening to the social, to the environment and also to the passage of the burden of proof, where the declaration of the Commission was precisely that there will be no further burdens on the our industry with respect to the procedure, transparency and reports of the Commission.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, allow me to congratulate you on your first session in your new job, and I think it is also your birthday today, so let me congratulate you on that as well. My best wishes! I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Cicu, for the work he has done, and all the shadow rapporteurs. We have jointly put in a lot of work on this legal text, in the trilogue and in the different committees and the groups. There has been a lot of effort and a constructive approach to the Commission proposal. This legal text will introduce into our anti-dumping legislation a new method for calculating dumping on imports from any World Trade Organization country where there are significant distortions. This is essential in order to address the realities of today’s international trading environment and to restore a level playing field. It will ensure that European industries remain well equipped to deal with the unfair competition they may face from dumped and subsidised imports in the future, without, as the rapporteur said, placing an additional burden on them. I have repeatedly stressed the importance of free but fair trade, and this agreement endorses that view. We must be able to tackle distortions in exporting countries that affect free market principles – distortions that result in prices and costs which are not in line with reality. The new anti-dumping methodology will be country-neutral and it will deal head-on with the many distortions that we know exist in a number of exporting economies. It will also be the first time that our legislation will acknowledge the significance of social and environmental standards in the trade-defence field. This is an important development, and the efforts made by the legislature in striking the right balance here can only be praised. The speed with which this legislation was adopted is testimony to our commitment that the EU must have efficient tools to tackle unfair international trade. I would like to thank Parliament again for the work it has devoted to this very complex issue.

name: Daniel Caspary
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! China's accession to the World Trade Organization was an important step and the European Union made many compromises at the time. If you look at the plenary debates in the European Parliament from back then, you realize that even then the concern was: Will China use the time, will China tackle economic, social and structural reforms, or will China continue to remain a communist planned economy? The reason for our change in the law today is that China's accession treaty to the World Trade Organization contains a formulation that forces us to act. I am very grateful that the European Commission has presented a very good proposal, which our colleague Cicu, together with all of us in the Committee on International Trade, has further improved. We will continue to be able to protect our European industry from unfair competition, from dumping from China and other countries. That this is not just about China, but that it is about dumping in general, that it is about combating unfair competition in general, is made clear by the fact that we are finally stopping dividing countries into market economies or non-market economies, but that we are with them This change in the law, with this change in the regulation, take a big step and simply say: If countries act unfairly, if countries introduce market distortions with the support of the state, if countries are unfair in competition, then the European Commission must be in a position to support our companies, our employees, ours Protect jobs and eliminate market distortions. That has not always been easy for us. But we have a very, very good point and I am very, very grateful to the Commissioner and also to Mr Cicu for their effective approach.

name: Bernd Lange
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Thank you, Madam President! When I go to a shop and want to buy an e-bike, I often see products from Europe and from another non-European country with a huge price difference. I ask myself: Is this price difference really to be understood on the basis of better quality or because it is dumped in a structured manner, that is, it is brought onto the market under production costs? We must indeed address this problem. If structural dumping is really carried out - and this includes whether state-owned companies are active, whether energy is subsidized, whether company law, land law favor companies or whether energy or access to finance is subsidized, these are all factors that structurally bring a competitive advantage with them - then we have to take action. In this respect: Yes, now I am praising the Commission, especially Cecilia Malmström, for the second time today for saying its intelligent proposal, which we have indeed developed further in the trialogue: We are looking at structural dumping and are making a country report accordingly can prove if we have serious problems. And the Commission will ultimately get to the point and launch an investigation. This means that we have a focus on structural dumping, but it is also clear that it does not place any additional burden on European industry. In particular, we have succeeded in including compliance with employee rights and environmental standards as a criterion for the dumping calculation. This is the first time we have succeeded anywhere in the world, but I think that is part of it. Dumping is also when you disregard labor and environmental standards, and that has to stop. Trade yes, but fair.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - As a politician it is important to be very ambitious. If you want to be successful, it is also wise to be realistic in your approach. And exactly that is what we are in this dossier. We are very ambitious when it comes to international trade and we should be. I come from the Flanders region, a small region but a very ambitious region, a very open region, self-confident too. It is the third most open economy in the world, Europe's logistics port. As a region we have to be open because we have to sell our products, our knowledge worldwide. That is precisely why we are always very careful when it comes to measures that can promote protectionism, when it comes to measures that can hinder trade. So our principles are clear. We are very strong for trade. We are also realistic. We are realistic and realize that the globalized economy does not work perfectly, that the playing field is simply not always fair. Goods are being dumped on our European market of which the price is artificially low, goods of poor quality also sometimes. And there can only be support for that international trade if we ensure that we have measures to tackle that effectively, too, so that trade runs fairly and correctly. And then you need instruments that ensure that fair trade is protected and that you have a level playing field. That is exactly what we are putting on the table here today: those fair rules that ensure that fair European competition can take place in Europe and worldwide.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, while finding a solution and a new method of calculating dumping was very urgent, finding a compromise was not easy. We worked on a new way to assess trade distortions in third countries that would stand up before the World Trade Organization, because if we want others to play by the rules we are strongest and most credible when we lead by example. Protectionism is not an answer to the challenges we face either. The agreement on anti-dumping methodology that we reached will ensure that our trade defence instruments are modernised. This is a general task that requires broader updates to the EU’s rules and methods. I hope that, on the question of broader trade defence instruments, we will soon achieve an updated proposal and reach the negotiation stage. While we base our trade on values, it is important to set the highest possible global standards. I therefore also welcome the fact that the EU will be the first international protagonist to take into account labour and environmental standards when looking at systematic trade distortions. As we update our trade tools, we have no time to lose to modernise them because the world is not waiting for us to finish our work. Nor can we hold our new trade defence methods hostage, as some in this House had suggested, so I look forward to voting tomorrow, with no further delays.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! The Council and Parliament have for the first time agreed to punish cases of social and environmental dumping. This is an important breakthrough that my group has worked for a long time. But let's not forget: this legislation is aimed primarily and with pressure on our relationship with China. The legislation that should regulate the modernization of trade defense instruments and from our point of view also environmental and social standards in general has been stuck in negotiations for years. At the beginning of the millennium, China's accession to the WTO was important to the EU. They wanted political integration and the really big deals on the China marketplace and therefore agreed to treat China as a market economy from 2017 onwards. Today the EU sees it differently. Instead of a list of countries that are not viewed as a market economy, the EU Commission is now introducing country reports - so far, so good. So far there has only been one such report, a kind of “lex China”. I was able to read this secret document beforehand. It is a market economy purism in its purest form, which classifies every state intervention, every political regulatory change of course as a disturbance of the market. If this gets through at the WTO, any industrial policy measure in an EU member state can in future be sued. We cannot agree with that. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE)
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Dear colleague Scholz!I have the great advantage of not knowing this secret document that you referred to.So I don't know whether I'm addressing things that are in the document or not.But do you think it would be smart to quote in a public session of the European Parliament from a possibly confidential document, the real content of which the public and this Parliament will never know?

name: Helmut Scholz (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Caspary!I did not quote from this document, but drew attention to this country report because in future it will be the basis for how to deal with dumping and possible dumping proceedings.In this respect, the public must also know that these country reports will be a reference paper, and so what is in them is of very far-reaching importance.And I just want to draw your attention to this: We may be circumcising ourselves in the future.

name: Yannick Jadot
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, Madam Commissioner, welcome to your responsibility. Usually when I speak about trade policies, I often criticize the European Commission and our European institutions a lot. I even scream very loudly. But here it is with pride that I speak about the European institutions because we are not on an agenda like deregulation free trade agreements, we are on a regulatory agenda. Because in 2012, when there was the Chinese dumping of photovoltaic panels, this Parliament mobilized, the Commission did its job, but the States became divided. We remember China going to see Greece, threatening it on investments in the port of Piraeus, going to France, threatening it on subsidies in wine and, finally, going to Ms. Merkel and offering to sell her her machine tools to make photovoltaic panels rather than defending the European photovoltaic industry. This was renewed with the steel industry. Basically, we have a structural problem in Europe, which is that we were built on the defense of consumers, the defense of the market, but because of national sovereignty over industry, we have no policy. industrial, we do not have a real producer protection policy. Precisely on this point, for the first time, we are embarking on this approach and I am very proud that, within this Parliament, with the Council, we finally have social dumping and environmental dumping recognized in our protection policies. our industries, our employees, our jobs and, of course, the protection of employees and the environment. It is true that through this rule, we will finally be able to publicly discuss Chinese dumping and the conditions of this dumping. Publicly, we will be able to have a debate on the non- compliance with ILO conventions or non-compliance with multilateral environmental agreements.This reform is welcome and the Council will have to continue its work on trade defense tools.But this is good news.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I’d like to start by giving my sincere birthday greetings to the very distinguished and able Chair of the Committee on International Trade, Bernd Lange. Also may I restate my birthday greetings to you, Madam President, and if it’s not presumptuous to congratulate you on your immaculate chairing of this debate. Trade takes place, it has to take place, under agreed rules that are set internationally. It should be noted that we are talking about international rules, not EU rules. If a trade partner behaves in a way that is unfair, then the wronged party must be able to take appropriate action. Almost always, the unfair practice takes the form of exporting below the cost of production, in one word: ‘dumping’. And, by the way, it’s a huge relief that in the jargon-ridden etymology of trade, ‘dumping’ is a great word – it conveys more or less exactly what it is. So far, so good. But there’s a problem. There’s an EU problem. The EU is a Customs Union. Anti-dumping duties imposed by the EU have to be agreed by every Member State. As some of us will remember from two years ago, the European Steel Association, EUROFER, was crystal clear that China was systematically dumping steel. However, by the time the Commission finally got an agreement and imposed anti-dumping duties, it was too little, too late: the EU put on only a 40% tariff. By comparison, the United States had previously, and quickly, and almost in time, put on a 300% tariff, i.e. one that really worked. In the debate that took place on steel and China two years ago, our distinguished colleague made an important point that was partly valid. He was right: the Cameron-Osborne UK Government of the time would have been unlikely to impose the necessary tariffs on steel produced in China. However, the point is not what they would or wouldn’t have done, the point is that outside the EU the then-British Government could have imposed the necessary tariffs. The fact is that the European Union is just too large, too awkward, too clumsy, too divided, too inept, to be able to make proper and timely decisions on trade defence instruments. In this context, as in so many others, the EU is not fit for purpose. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE)
text: blue-card question. – Lord Dartmouth, are you aware of the fact that in the US ‘life’ in prison can be 300 years? I just wondered, do you think it is a wise idea? Because I understand that you are upset with the fact that in Europe, we have a tariff of maybe 40% instead of 300%. Has it ever occurred to you that virtually all trade might actually stop even at 40%? This means that the extra 260% does not really matter, just as maybe the extra 250 years of life in prison in the US might not matter that much.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Mr President, the question ill becomes somebody of Mr Fjellner’s intellectual precision and clarity. The fact of the matter is that the 40% was not enough to stop the dumping. The 300% was enough to stop the dumping. That is the point – a point that I feel I made very clear at the time.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, dear colleagues, let us open our eyes and read between the lines. It is not a question here of looking at China or Brazil, it is indeed we, the European countries who are concerned by the Cicu report, and I thank my colleague, moreover, for having been able to make progress concerning the distortion of the competition. Today it is indeed a problem between the Member States and not a problem external to the Member States. Take the example of agriculture. Today on milk, on meat, on fruits and vegetables. There is unfair competition between the States on the affair of posted workers, but also on the abusive support of certain States for their agricultural sectors and I believe that it would be dangerous today to take a negative look at China, while we are responsible for what happens within the Union itself. So, even if there is progress, I consider that today, at the last word, it will be the Commission which will take care of deciding the new anti-dumping measures. I do not trust the European Commission and that is why we will abstain on this report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: - Mr President, for many years now, in the interests of multinational corporations and big business, the conditions have been created for the establishment of a global economic system in which social dumping is not simply a wrong practice. It is -essentially- a key part of it. Since you are still pursuing free economic transactions with absolutely no control, eliminating small businesses, it is hypocritical to discuss ways to tackle dumping. In fact, what is being done here is an attempt to tackle dumping by companies in certain third countries, such as Russia and -mostly- China, in order for companies in Germany and other European countries to gain an advantage. This is evidenced by the very existence of the European Union, which has effectively institutionalized social dumping with the free movement of capital and people. We, on the other hand, are interested in the average worker and entrepreneur, we demand the reinstatement of customs duties on products and services produced outside Europe and restrictions on the movement of products and services within it. Only in this way will we be able to give back to the people their lost dignity.

name: Franck Proust (PPE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, a year late, we have finally reached an agreement on a new anti-dumping methodology. The strong mobilization of the European Parliament and the dumped companies was heard by the Commission, which demonstrated that it could change its position without granting market economy status to China. This is what we expect, innovation and above all efficiency. This is a big step forward, but two other pillars are still missing so that we can say that Europe is legally armed in the face of the harsh reality of globalization: firstly, the reform of trade defense instruments and, of course, second, the national mechanisms for screening foreign investments which are yet to be defined. This new ambition is the response to the expectations of our companies and our fellow citizens, but I regret that you cannot guarantee that Europe will give itself the human and financial resources for its ambitions. I can assure you, in any case, that my vigilance on the application of this new method will not be relaxed.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, this report is undoubtedly a step forward for Europe, European businesses, employees and consumers. It is also good to measure that we have come a long way: I recall that two years ago leaders in the Commission and in the Council were considering granting market economy status to China without discussing it, even though this would have been a major historical error. In all our countries, we can measure the damage of unfair Chinese competition. I could name several sectors - ceramics, paper, glass, steel - which are threatened and territories which are also threatened. There, it must be said, Parliament has shown responsibility. We have been able to display a united front, united among ourselves, united with the unions, united with the professional organizations to propose substantial amendments - I obviously thank the rapporteur Salvatore Cicu - which represent a step forward on the burden of proof. said, a step forward on the reports, which is very important because it is the keystone of the new system, and above all a step forward on a new definition of dumping. What will remain from this debate, I believe, is that we are extending the definition of dumping to social and environmental issues and we are happy for that. Finally, and it has not been said until now, we allow access for trade unions and SMEs, which until now had been forgotten, to anti-dumping proceedings. Therefore, yes, undoubtedly, it is a step forward. But, let's be realistic, dear colleagues, there is still an important part missing from the system, because if Europe does not manage to protect itself more - and here I am talking about the issue of trade defense instruments - then all this work that we we have accomplished collectively will not bear fruit. Consequently, let us remain vigilant, let us stand firm for a Europe that protects and a Europe that who knows how to enforce rules and standards.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: - Madam President, we are discussing this report here because the European Union did not rightly grant China market economy status last December, we have a right to do that, we have the right to defend our economy from unfair competition. On the other hand, we must also say that there are also certain risks. One risk, of course, is that the European Commission reacted belatedly. Today, it has been almost a year since we dealt with this matter, and that has already been said here. The second thing, which is perhaps even more serious, is that we do not know how the proceedings against the European Commission before the World Trade Organization will turn out, because China has logically challenged both our decision not to grant it market economy status and our decision on this new one. calculation methodology. So, Commissioner, of course, I do not want you to tell me here whether or not the European Commission has a Plan B. I believe it does, and I believe that even if it does not work for us in the World Trade organization well, so you will be able to continue to protect the interests of the European economy.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I am personally very pleased that we have been able to agree on a new anti-dumping methodology in a relatively very short time. In addition, the agreed text reflects the main priorities of the European Parliament, the effective protection of our companies, the low administrative burden and the compatibility of the new rules with the WTO. From the point of view of European companies, it is absolutely crucial that the European Union has the tools at its disposal to effectively protect them against unfair competition from abroad. International trade is changing, in the context of which a country like China is growing in importance, and even in this situation, the European Union must be prepared to protect its domestic industries if it faces unfair practices from outside. This new methodology will make it possible. It offers protection, especially in those markets where products with a disproportionately low price or over-subsidized products go from third countries. That is why I welcome this result.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new anti-dumping legislation we are debating today has a major impact on the future of European industry and on the lives of thousands of workers and thousands of workers. Thanks to the work of the Parliament, the non-application of internationally recognized social and environmental standards is taken into consideration for the first time in the assessment of unfair practices of unfair competition. It is a timid first step as these assessments are included in the recitals and not in the paragraphs of the new text, but it is nevertheless a significant step. In fact, there are many countries that violate the most elementary international labor standards, not just those that are often the target of our concerns. We believe that the European Union must seriously reflect on its industrial policy, or rather on the absence of its own industrial and development policy. Insisting on the neoliberal economic and social model, which left everything to the market and which prevented member states from planning economic planning, public intervention in economics and the elements of planning, has weakened our industry and exposes us more and more to competition from third countries.

name: David Borrelli (EFDD).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, many times we find ourselves voting on issues whose impact on the lives of ordinary people appears to be very limited or perceptible only to insiders. But the vote we are about to give tomorrow is of a very different nature: its result will directly and for a long time affect all European citizens and the vast majority of our businesses. It is an important vote, indeed I would say a decisive vote. Making a mistake in this choice is a serious matter and will have serious consequences. From the beginning we have tried to remind everyone of the delicacy of this issue. We highlighted how the choice of ways and times to adapt European legislation to China's request was devoid of strategic vision, conditioned by vested interests and destined to be ineffective. The proposed new methodology is showing its heavy limitations even before it is approved. The Chinese government has already announced that it will oppose the reform in the WTO, and the latest Congress of the Communist Party of China has clearly indicated that China intends to increase state control over its domestic economy and have a say in the foreign companies that operate. in China. China is emerging as an economic power that has in no way come close to the market economy as understood by the West. Entire industrial categories have declared that in no more than 5 or 7 years they will no longer be able to stem the aggressive competition from Chinese industries. This new methodology does not strengthen economic legality and exposes European industry, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, to uncertainty. We must have the courage to say that when our strength no longer lies in the certainty of the rules, but in the ambiguity and discretion of the Commission, Europe will be weaker. I will vote against, in line with the resolution passed by this Parliament in May 2016, i whose fundamental points have, in my opinion, been disregarded by the Commission and the Council.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: - Madam President! This proposed amendment on protection against dumped imports brings very important positive innovations. First: If there are market distortions such as a lack of environmental protection measures, child labor or government intervention in production, this test leads to the composition of the import price. The costs that exporters have saved on the environment or on workers can ultimately be offset with the help of protective tariffs from the Union. Second: The protective measures take effect whether a state has market economy status or not. Specifically, this means that European companies can continue to protect themselves effectively against the glut of imports, for example cheap steel from China, in the future. Third countries lose the chance to force domestic products off the domestic market through aggressive production and raw material subsidies. In the case of textile products, which were created under possibly unworthy working conditions, especially child labor, under the principles of massive environmental destruction, the price competitiveness will be interfered with and this will be taken away. However, the decisive factor will be how carefully the Commission examines it. It is to be hoped that this test does not fall victim to political influence. Ultimately, what the WTO says about it will also be decisive.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: - Madam President! For thirteen years, I think, I have worked with - or perhaps rather against - EU protectionist tariffs. For many of my colleagues here, it's no surprise, because we've had a lot of conflicts over tariffs. I still have a hard time understanding why we should impose particularly high tariffs if someone exports something particularly cheap. I think that the Commission's new threat of tariffs on cheap electric bicycles says almost everything - electric bicycles that the government in Sweden also wants to subsidize with state subsidies. I know that there are some people here in plenary today who intend to vote against the new rules tomorrow because they think or believe that it will be more difficult to impose draconian tariffs on e.g. electric bikes from China. I could vote exactly the same but for the opposite reason, namely because I think it is and remains too easy to impose draconian tariffs on e.g. electric bikes from China. However, it is honestly not what tomorrow's vote is about, but it is about something completely different and hopefully something we can agree on, namely whether we should play by the rules, whether we should follow the EU acquis and whether we should see to maintain a regulated world trade. I hope we agree on that!

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D).
text: - Madam President, the truth is that you are very happy that you are playing this role here today and the rest of the legislature. Commissioner, in the face of protectionist tendencies, we Socialists defend a fair trade opening. Against those who promote extreme globalization, we are committed to setting rules that guarantee that we all compete with the same rules of the game. The reform of the anti-dumping regulation that we will adopt tomorrow is born precisely of this double conviction and I thank you for the excellent work you have done, Mrs Malmström. The Union must comply with the commitments acquired before the World Trade Organization, but it cannot sit idly by in the face of unfair competition from third countries. We must act firmly against those who do not respect the rules of the market economy and defend the survival and growth of some of our most innovative sectors, such as ceramics, textiles, photovoltaics or steel, which employ millions of people in Europe and that they continue to face, day by day, the dumping of the subsidized economies. This regulation is a great step forward, it is true, but it is also true that the Council must now allow, once and for all, modern, efficient and more ambitious trade defense instruments.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Madam President, first of all I would like to wish you every success in your duties. Unfortunately, for the last forty years, the European Union, in the name of so-called free trade, has abandoned the principle of Community preference, which has given priority to the protection of European farmers and producers. Market opening has essentially dismantled the European South and European agriculture. It is therefore necessary to arrange for a fair trade based on mutual benefit. Stop the unfair trade practices and distortions of third countries, which, in order to reduce wage costs, do not comply with the conventions of the International Labor Organization and allow child labor. At the same time, the same countries do not comply with environmental standards and do not - of course - comply with multilateral conventions on environmental protection. In addition, we have distorted production costs, as they receive support from their own governments. Measures are therefore needed to protect against dumped imports.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner!After a policy of scare tactics was pursued in the area of anti-dumping last year, I am pleased that we have returned to the essentials.The aim is to reform the anti-dumping regulations so that they are compliant with WTO law and at the same time offer European companies the greatest possible protection, instead of engaging in an emotional debate about whether or not China is a market economy.Parliament and the Council have achieved precisely this goal: regulations that are formulated in a country-neutral manner and are therefore WTO-compliant, but nevertheless ensure that markets such as China, which are still subject to considerable distortions and state influence, are treated accordingly strictly.I am pleased that fact-based policy has prevailed in this case and I hope that this would also be the case more often in other areas.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, China's entry into the WTO required changing the rules of multilateral trade if we did not want inequalities to grow globally. Unfortunately, the European Union is ready to allow full liberalization of trade with China, abruptly dismantling existing protections to consolidate the neoliberal model of globalization. We wanted the fight against social and environmental dumping to be one of the anti-dumping tools of the European Union, but the proposal to be voted on does not contain any binding commitments, only lax and generic criteria, and the burden of proof disappears. On the contrary, the European Union demands that the WTO countries liberalize and privatize their economies if they do not want to be accused of distorting foreign trade, aggravating fierce competition between countries and between workers. We do not want Chinese workers to be exploited by the same multinationals that put thousands of European workers into unemployment.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, nowhere has the impact of EU-wide trade policy been felt more acutely than in Wales. Five thousand jobs were lost in the steel industry last year alone. That is more than one in six. Yet as the crisis deepened, neither the Welsh Assembly, to which I am also elected, nor the UK Government could do anything substantial enough to save a single job. We were blocked from setting our own tariffs to protect against the dumping of cheap steel. We were met with disinterest when we begged Brussels for help, too absorbed with bigger markets in other Member States and more interested in satisfying greedy lobbyists. Even more disgracefully, the UK Government was banned under EU regulation from providing any state aid to Welsh steel as a reprieve while a long-term solution could be found. As a result, thousands of Welsh people from communities that have been built on steel were thrown into the dust heap of unemployment due to unsympathetic policies in Brussels made by unelected and unaccountable Commissioners.  The UK must not, under any circumstances, enter into any ongoing continental arrangements on dumping after Brexit. We fought for our freedom so that we can take care of our own industries and our own people. Enforced homogeny does not work. Nations have unique economic landscapes and needs. I urge fellow MEPs to wake up. Do not slavishly obey diktats issued by Brussels. Campaign for a mechanism to exempt your countries from poisonous EU legislation when your people are faced with hardship. This is your duty. You are elected to represent them, not the EU. I wish that I and my fellow Welsh politicians could have done more to save thousands of innocent workers whose livelihoods were destroyed. At least I can say that I campaigned for Brexit and will keep fighting for British freedom, so that on 29 March 2019 we can say ‘never again’.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in May 2016, a resolution from our Parliament made it clear that China did not fulfill the conditions which would allow it to obtain market economy status. This was urgent, since 15 years after its admission to the World Trade Organization, China would soon be granted this precious sesame to further flood our European markets. This is the very meaning of the English word dumping, unloading, dumping in heaps, in this case by container ships. Granting China this market economy status would have deprived our states of the possibility of taking anti-dumping action afterwards. But to please the Chinese, the European Commission has proposed removing the distinction, which the WTO does, between countries that have and those that do not have market economy status. In these conditions, Mr Cicu's initial report was a lesser evil than Commissioner Malmström's proposals, except that the soft consensus on which we will have to vote tomorrow raises more questions than it now provides credible answers. . Today, the maximum import tax rate provided for by European texts is 35%, which is derisory compared to the taxes decided, for example by the United States to save their industry. Just look at what the Trump administration did last month with its standoff with Canada's Bombardier, after imposing a 220% surtax on every C-Series aircraft sold to states. -United, the Commerce Department added anti-dumping duties of nearly 80%. So, while intra-European negotiations on the modernization of our trade defenses have been frozen since 2014, I invite you to listen to the speech delivered by President Trump last Friday in Da Nang in Vietnam. We can no longer tolerate chronic trade abuse, he said. This is what he told the Chinese president with the outspokenness that we know him.As the European Union ramps up all-out free trade agreements, Trump has announced the United States' withdrawal from the Trans-Pacific Partnership.The President of the United States therefore defends the interests of his citizens rather than those of multinationals.We can and must do the same.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: Question "blue card".- Madam President, I have just heard what colleague Nicolas Bay said and, indeed, the European Parliament's resolution 2016 was a very important resolution, because it marked the will of Parliament, almost on all its benches,to recall the extent to which Europe had to protect itself.There is just one problem in your demonstration, it is that this resolution, you did not vote it, you courageously abstained in committee and I this systematic distortion between words and actions, that poses a problem for me, Itherefore wanted to call the assistance to witness.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: "blue card" response.- My dear colleague, you are not a novice in this house and you therefore know that, very often, the very complex texts which pass in committee or in plenary session indeed contain quite diverse provisions and that, sometimes, one can appreciate suchor such aspect, to consider that it constitutes a lesser evil, without appreciating a text in its entirety, including when it imposes very negative effects on our economy.Often, the abstention position is a nuanced position, a reserved position, a partial support position.I guess, I imagine and I dare to hope that these are nuances that do not escape you.But the main thing is to put an end to the logic of free trade which characterizes the European Union in all circumstances and which places our economy, our industries and our farmers in a situation of unfair competition which is untenable.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: - Madam President, dear Commissioner, I would like to congratulate my colleague and friend, Salvatore Cicu, for the great job he has done. I know it has been a long and complicated negotiation, but it has reached a satisfactory result. With this new methodology we will be stronger when it comes to protecting our industry and European citizens from the negative consequences of globalization. Our economy is threatened by unfair trade policies. Our markets run the risk of being flooded with products made in third countries that do not respect our same standards. I am a staunch defender of free trade, but to ensure that all countries obtain the same benefits, it is essential that we all play by the same rules, respecting international standards in labor, social and environmental matters, thus avoiding any type of dumping. This new legislation is perfectly compatible with the WTO, thereby ensuring that our industries can defend themselves against unfair trade practices.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: - Madam President, just a year ago, the Commission came up with a first proposal to amend the European anti-dumping law. Thanks to intense work on the part of our colleagues, but also thanks to a common front between companies and unions, we have succeeded with an important trialogue in modifying this legislation. Thus, tomorrow, when countries or industries resort to unfair practices, the European Union will continue to have the possibility of taking calculated anti-dumping measures on third countries. But now - and this is a step forward - social and environmental standards will be taken into account in assessing significant distortions. Moreover, the burden of proof will not be transferred to industries. Thus, the Commission will assess and produce a number of reports and this is also to be welcomed as an exercise. This is therefore a victory for the future of European industry and we must be able to celebrate its victories. Now the fight is not over, because there is a second legislation, the instruments of trade defense, which it is important to be able to renovate. So we call the Council because today there is, on the part of the Council, a certain reluctance to modify these trade defense instruments. However, we know that, without this review, we do not have the necessary efficiency to be able to properly protect certain sectors of our European industries. Therefore, the Council must absolutely move on these issues.

name: France Jamet (ENF).
text: - Madam President, for 15 years and within the framework of the WTO, there was no question of considering China as a market economy, and for good reason, out of the 73 current anti-dumping measures taken by the EU, 56 applied to imports from China. Like the United States and Japan, Parliament here overwhelmingly has said it is against granting market economy status to China, and the Commission here is playing a role. double game. From the start, she made no secret of her ambitions to grant him favors. So, under the pretext of consumer protection, it is now returning to the charge by proposing measures to supposedly fight against dumping. No, making a gesture towards the Chinese will not commit them to abandon their mass production or to align their prices with market prices. It is smoke, an aberrant naivety bordering on insolence and seriously jeopardizing our industry which is already under attack. To consider China as a market economy would be to open wide the doors of our European economy to Chinese products and directly threaten thousands of European jobs. "Anoint villain he will puncture you, fist villain he will anoint you."

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this topic is extremely difficult and multi—layered and has a great number of actors involved – often with conflicting interests – but we have struck a balanced deal that, most importantly, provides that the new rules will be country—neutral and in full compliance with the EU’s WTO obligations. As you know, we have serious distortions in the key raw materials around the world – natural gas, minerals, rare metals and others – while some adjustments that the European Commission has used in the past to reject the distorted cost of raw materials and to replace them with the market values when calculating this normal value were under attack in the WTO. With these new rules, we will ensure that the Commission has a way to address such distortions, and I am very happy that we have this good compromise and I would like to congratulate Mr Cicu for a job well done.

name: David Martin (S&D).
text: – Madam President, let me add my ‘happy birthday’ to you and to Bernd Lange. I want to congratulate all colleagues involved in the negotiations in this file, and the progress of Parliament made is obvious if you compare the Council’s initial approach with the final document we have before us. A good job well done, but it is only halfway there; I could have gone for dinner early, but I agree entirely with my colleague Ms Maria Arena: this file has to be complimented by the completion of the trade defence instruments (TDI) file. The Commissioner will recall that in the trilogue negotiations on this file, both the Council and the Commission – more importantly here the Council – made promises that, in advance of the vote that we are going to have this week, they would make a breakthrough in the TDI file. I regret to report that this has not happened, and in fact the TDI file appears to me to be going nowhere at the present time. It is very important that we do make progress in that file, because – as I said – this is only half the job, and without TDI reform we will not have all the tools and armoury we need to defend European industry against unfair competition.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: - Madam President, good evening, best wishes and good work. Ladies and gentlemen, the discussion on this subject forces me to make a clarification in the introduction. First, I contest the observation of those who believe that all this work is aimed at protecting someone from someone else. The game plan here is to defend those who accept the rules of the market from those who do not accept them. So it is not protection, but it is a serious job to protect those who work well. In this context, the Commission's initial proposal legitimately aimed to avoid the risks associated with the litigation within the WTO operated by China, but the Commission's reaction generated a product that ended up putting the companies of this continent in difficulty. The work done by Mr Cicu, for whom I thank him, had the merit of placing Parliament at the center of the battle, so that the measures not of protection but of gratitude towards the European enterprise become clear again.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, a year ago, steel workers were marching in the rain in Brussels to protest the dumping of cheap steel and calling for China to be denied market economy status, fearing thousands more job losses across Europe. Labour MEPs have long pushed for action and the EU has now delivered, and that is very welcome. But what a contrast to the attitude of our Tory Government. They continue to drag their feet on granting workers and industries the protection that they need against dumping in the EU and through weak proposals on post-Brexit trade remedies. Here, for the first time ever in trade defence rules, social and environmental criteria will also now be assessed, recognising the effect of unfair trade practices on workers and the environment. We have a much more progressive alternative before us, but this is just one part of the EU’s endeavour to strengthen its trade defences, and we now need a deal to modernise those vital trade defence instruments overall if we are really to save our European steel.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the European Parliament has fully fulfilled its role in foiling the Commission's intentions, which were to grant China the status of market economy as simply as possible. We have succeeded in establishing safeguards even if we could hope for better. Nonetheless, we have the opportunity to pull ourselves together through the ongoing negotiations on trade defense instruments, for example, set in stone, environmental criteria - this has just been recalled. In Europe, to produce one tonne of steel, on average, two tonnes of CO2 are emitted. The same tonne of steel produced in China emits three tonnes of CO2. What about the extra ton of CO2? Will exporters have to buy rights to pollute like any other European company or are we continuing as before, that is to say nothing? Therefore, the carbon adjustment at the borders of Europe is the essential tool to fight against environmental dumping and also to protect public health. And it is not against WTO rules, as you have often said. We must also send a positive message to the most virtuous: to do nothing is not only to increase unfair competition, but it is also to trample on the collective rules that we have voted. Therefore, let us agree with ourselves and strengthen the instruments of trade defense.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: - Madam President, best wishes. Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, just over a year ago, while someone was explaining to us how urgent it was to grant market economy status to China, this House declared its firm opposition to be solid. We have waged a tough battle, thanks to which the European Union can now equip itself with anti-dumping instruments capable of countering the unfair behavior that occurs more and more often in the global market and that create imbalances within the European market, as demonstrated by the 100 measures in force, of which 85 against Chinese products. The new regulation has the merit of including the reference to international environmental and labor standards, to identify any significant distortions of prices and market costs, and ensures continuity with the current protection system, without additional costs for the industry. European. I am sorry that the Council is not present but, let us say it by heart, we hope that the Council will demonstrate the same ambition on another important game, that of the reform of the trade defense instruments.

name: Puhemies. –
text: Thank you, Mr Danti, this remark about your absence from the Council is, in fact, quite relevant.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: - Mr President, the new anti-dumping methodology, which we are discussing here, is a really important legislative initiative.What this is about is defending the European economy from imports from countries competing on the basis of serious market distortions and unfair commercial practices.With this more rigorous method of dumping control, the European Union guarantees compliance with the rules of the World Trade Organization, but it gains, above all, an instrument to defend the interests of its companies and its workers, and with an advantage, that ofalso to value social dumping, because it takes into account social and environmental standards and the distortions achieved through wage costs.As we have already noted, this is not the end of the road.We need to advocate a deep modernization of our trade defense instruments.But one thing is for sure, we are certainly better off with these anti-dumping instruments.

name: Jo Leinen (S&D).
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Malmström! The EU still exports more to other countries in the world than we import each year. That is why we are in favor of open markets and against short-sighted protectionism.
