On the other hand, I also repeat that our citizens expect to be protected against unfair practices on the world market - unfair when it comes to environmental protection, social regulations or tax dumping. The EU has been far too slow and far too weak to respond to in the past. I also have two steel mills in my region. There was great impatience to appear in good time and manifest in the case of obvious dumping products. As the chairman of the China delegation, I am glad that the tiresome issue of market economy status has been resolved for the country and that we have found an intelligent horizontal solution. We don't look at countries, but rather productions and products. That is the right approach. I hope that this policy can also be made visible so that the citizens of the EU trust the EU even more.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: - "The noose is hanging around our necks because of cheap steel from China," shouted a steel worker from Tata Steel in IJmuiden. There was not much to argue against that. Tata Steel IJmuiden is a modern, innovative steel company with no fewer than 9,000 employees. Indeed, Tata and many other European steel companies are under pressure from the cheap import of Chinese steel. That is why I called on the European Commissioner last year to take strong, effective anti-dumping measures and we are here: at last the EU arms itself against dumping and I am glad that European companies will soon no longer have to provide additional evidence for the the fact that their non-European competitors are guilty of dumping. I am also pleased that trading partners will soon be obliged to comply with labor and environmental standards. And I am pleased that European trade unions will soon have the opportunity to protect their trade with their advice. Now let's hope that it comes in time for the employees of Tata in IJmuiden.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the agreement reached in the trialogue goes in the right direction. In order to determine the situations of dumping, especially in the case of strong distortions of competition, it is essential to refer to the costs and prices of production in third countries. The circumstances from which the existence of significant distortions can be inferred, which can affect free market forces, are defined, resulting in a new methodology for calculating anti-dumping duties, which takes into account both the so-called micro distortions of prices and costs, as well as those macro related, for example, to subsidies and investments. In assessing unfair commercial practices, respect for environmental criteria and, with reference to the standards of the International Labor Organization, respect for workers' rights are duly taken into consideration. Ultimately, industry and European trade unions will be enabled to report distortions to the Commission without further burden on them. An excellent result, therefore, for the European Union, for European industry and for European citizens. Congratulations to the speaker Cicu.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Madam President, the Union and the Member States support and protect individual domestic industries in various ways.Such practices improve our global competitiveness in the short run, but have no positive effects in the long run.How much we strive to protect ours was also seen in the TTIP negotiations from which some industries were exempted from the start.We should not be surprised, therefore, that others resort to similar solutions in order to do better in trade.But there are differences.Although Europe often chooses protectionism instead of the free market, I agree that we must protect ourselves from non-market economies in which a political decree reduces the price of raw materials or labor.The quality of this proposal is that it does not give the Commission a mandate to randomly select those that will make it difficult to export to the Union, but there must be concrete reasons for its action in the form of major price distortions.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam President, the issues we are discussing have been raised to some extent during the previous debate on the World Trade Organization. Weak economic states are unfortunately forced to dump to support their economies, but in no case can we support actions by countries like China to use state structures as a vehicle for imposing tariffs. On the other hand, we are in favor of European Union states being able to support specific sectors of their economy, as long as this is beneficial for sustainable development and does not create an unfair advantage. Finally, the addition made to take into account whether the exporting countries comply with the rules of the International Labor Organization, as well as environmental standards, is positive.

name: Cecilia Malmström
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all the Members; it has been a very useful debate, and it has shown a very broad support for this new piece of legislation – a legislation that will protect our industry from unfair practices, from unfair trade, especially when it comes from market distortion.  It does so in a country-neutral way. With this, we go away from our old system of dividing countries into non-market and market economies. The new methodology will look at all countries to see if there are distortions. This is not – and I would like to repeat that – this is not about giving market economy status to China. It never has been. The historical writing here should be revised a little bit: it has never been about this; it has been about respecting our commitments in the WTO. China is not a market economy – if it were, it would be much easier. This is not about China – it is about any country. The anti-dumping methodology is to capture market distortion; it is linked to intervention in third countries or in sectors of the country. It will ensure a smooth transition to the new methodology for the measures already in place, the grandfather with a clear time frame, and we strengthen our anti-dumping instrument to increase our ability to capture the full magnitude of subsidisation by making it possible to address subsidies identified in the course of the investigation. Also, as you have mentioned, it is taking into account social and environmental standards in a trade defence context for the first time.  The draft reports for a country or for a sector where we find distortions will be made public – there are no secret reports. This is a trade defence instrument that is efficient, and where we comply with international obligations. Trade is good; it leads to a lot of advantages – growth, investment, jobs. But trade has to be fair, and we have to have a fair, level playing field, and with this we will assure that we can contribute to this. The trade defence instrument is also an important piece of legislation. I know that there are two more trilogue plans in the coming weeks; I am sure that we will make good progress if we cannot finish this. We are closer to each other than has been insinuated here, and I am sure that – together with the Council, the Commission and Parliament – we will do our utmost to get an agreement here before Christmas. I would again like to thank the rapporteur Mr Cicu, his team and all the shadow rapporteurs, and all the teams in the trilogue for making this such a good piece of legislation, and I hope for a very strong endorsement tomorrow at the vote.

name: Salvatore Cicu
text: speaker. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that in conclusion, after an intense ten months' work, a work that I believe to be fruitful and effective, we must remember that this is an extraordinarily important step forward, but now we must, after tomorrow's vote , look at the application of this new methodology. So I want to transfer two thoughts to the Commission and the Commissioner. The first is that the role of Parliament will be supervisory over the application of a methodology that is effectively, highly effective, compliant with the work we have achieved, in an extraordinary way in my opinion. The other aspect, Commissioner, is that your remarkably relevant statements concern the fact that our businesses and our industry should have no further additional burden in applying this methodology. So no bureaucracy, but above all, as you said, an equity and a possibility to demonstrate that there must and then exist a guarantee, a protection, a defense of fair competition. Of course, the application of this methodology cannot be less effective than the current one. So I believe that if we also work towards these objectives, we will certainly bring home an extraordinary result in terms of our project, our 2020 program. I want to thank also and above all President Lange, I want to thank the members of the INTA commission for the extraordinary work they have done, and truly all for the contribution they have given to this extent, in this quality and to achieve an extraordinary and important real and strong result. So I believe that tomorrow the transition will be the decisive and most effective one.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The conversation is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! China, Russia or India often try to flood Europe with cheap, dumped products. If this succeeded, European industry, such as the steel industry, would go bankrupt in a matter of days, with tens of thousands losing their jobs. It would also affect us sensitively, for example, we could say goodbye to 6,000 jobs at the Danube Ironworks in Dunaújváros overnight. The only reason why Chinese and Russian low-priced products cannot set foot in Europe is the hard action of the European Union. The EU immediately imposes effective criminal duties on dumped products. Europe is able to protect European and Hungarian industry from emerging economies. We also owe thousands of Hungarian jobs to Europe, which does not allow cheap Chinese steel, for example. The EU is also preventing capital-intensive economies from acquiring important European companies. An investment due diligence proposal is being prepared to prevent Chinese and Russian companies from swallowing up important European companies. In other words, Europe is protecting us from having our electricity supplier in China or having the gas pipeline in Russian hands. Of course, there are countries where it is too late.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: in writing. - With the adoption of this new methodology, which is intended to be neutral and applicable to all types of country, our message is clear: we are refusing market economy status to China. The European Union must continue to fight against all unfair competition. We will therefore ensure the implementation of this new method so that no additional burden weighs on our companies and more particularly on our SMEs. I would like to welcome the consideration of environmental and social criteria, it is a first step in strengthening a trade that applies the same rules for all. But this new methodology is not an end in itself. It must be accompanied, and I hope very soon, by a real reform of our trade defense instruments, so that they become more effective, faster and more accessible. This is how we contribute to our goal of fair and equitable trade. Thank you.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Maurice Ponga, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the EU strategy for Africa: accelerating development (2017/2083 (INI)) (A8-0334 / 2017).

name: Maurice Ponga
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am happy that we are discussing today the relations between the European Union and Africa before the holding of the EU / AU summit which will take place in Abidjan in Côte d ' Ivoire on November 29 and 30. It will be an important summit and it is crucial that the voice of the European Parliament can be heard there in this context. I wanted to begin by warmly thanking the fellow shadow rapporteurs for their collaboration. We have arrived at a balanced text which presents a strong position of the European Parliament on the need to renew our partnership with Africa. One of the major recommendations of our report is the need to strengthen political dialogue with the African continent. Indeed, I am convinced that political dialogue must be increased between the two continents, in order to set up a win-win partnership which responds to common challenges in a spirit of reciprocal sharing and respect. It is necessary to change the paradigm to go beyond the donor-recipient approach and move to an approach between two equal partners. In this relationship which unites the European Union with Africa, it is nevertheless necessary to recognize the special links which unite us with the group of ACP States. This is why we reiterate in our report the need to maintain this acquis, while improving and strengthening the regional dimension within the framework of the post-Cotonou process. If the political dialogue must be strengthened in order to have a relationship that responds to shared challenges, this also involves making resilience a central axis of cooperation between the two continents. This resilience must be addressed in these five dimensions: political, security, economic, environmental and social. To promote political resilience, governance and respect for rights need to be of man of the founding elements of our partnership with Africa and to support more frequent political exchanges between the various mixed parliamentary assemblies in order to exchange without taboos. The security issue is also crucial in our relationship with Africa. Indeed, as we underline in the report there are close links between development and security. Without security there can be no development and vice versa. This is why it is necessary to strengthen cooperation between the two continents to fight against organized crime, human trafficking or terrorism. While the European Union is a major player in guaranteeing security on the African continent, all African countries and regional organizations must also be involved in matters of peace and security. It is indeed important that Africa builds its own capacities. Another major challenge is to ensure the economic resilience of the two continents by creating quality jobs. This must involve investments in key sectors such as the blue economy, research, digitization, but also energy, basic infrastructure and even agriculture. The decisive role of the private sector and SMEs is recalled in our report, because we all know it is necessary to create wealth on the African continent. And this created wealth must stay there. Each year, more than $ 50 billion illegally escapes Africa. It is more than official development assistance. We must strengthen the tools to fight tax evasion and corruption, this is a sine qua non for ensuring sustainable development. Environmental and social resilience are also important elements of our report. In addition to the demographic challenges that we must take into account, the issue of climate change is crucial for the African continent, in view of the increasing number of natural disasters over the past 10 years and their increased intensity. Finally, migration and mobility are issues in our relationship with Africa that we cannot avoid. Indeed, the migratory flow that we are experiencing must be able to be better controlled and not be suffered. In my opinion, it is important that the phenomena be approached in a coordinated and comprehensive manner between the two continents, involving the countries of origin, transit and destination in order to make it a tool for the development of both continents, which requires a long term approach. And finally, several European initiatives deserve to be mentioned, the FEDD, the various trust funds or the migration partnerships which should make it possible to fight against the root causes of irregular migration. For lasting solutions to be put in place, it is urgent that the Member States contribute financially to the various funds set up at European level, as President Juncker reminded us. There are many challenges to overcome for the 218 million people who are victims of extreme poverty on the African continent to emerge from it. This is a challenge that we must meet together and I sincerely hope that the next summit in Abidjan will provide answers.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Ponga, for an excellent and very useful report. We are very glad to see that the arguments and priority areas set out in your report concur with the thinking outlined in the Joint Communication for a renewed impetus of the Africa-EU Partnership from May 2017 and the June Council conclusions.  The key priorities under the heading ‘Resilience’, referring to improved political security as well as environmental, economic and social resilience, are duly reflected in our work with African partners. The resolution underlines the critical role of African youth in light of a significant population growth. More than half of global population growth between now and 2050 is expected to occur in Africa.  According to projections, sub-Saharan Africa needs to create around 18 million new jobs each year up to 2035 in order to absorb new labour market entrants, compared to the three million formal jobs created today. It should be a priority for both Africa and Europe to turn demographic developments into a dividend. We require inclusive development and sustainable growth for large-scale job creation. The leitmotiv of the fifth AU-EU Summit taking place on 29—30 November this year in Abidjan, Côte d’Ivoire, will be investing in youth. More broadly, this will provide a critical opportunity for the EU and Africa to build a stronger political partnership and increase our cooperation in the international arena, guided by: the UN’s 2030 agenda and its Sustainable Development Goals; the African Union’s Agenda 2063; the global strategy for the European Union’s foreign and security policy; as well as the new European consensus on development.  The finalisation of your report just a few weeks before this event is very timely, and it is appreciated to see key teams and priority areas reinforced by its content. The summit should strive to bring Africa and Europe closer together through the strengthening of economic cooperation and the promotion of sustainable development, with both continents living side by side in peace, security, democracy, prosperity, solidarity and human dignity.  The summit should confirm and strengthen our mutual engagement and joint action for the period 2018 to 2020 in the framework of the Joint Africa-EU Strategy. As you know well, the Africa-EU strategic partnership is based on shared values. It promotes common interests and shared strategic objectives, which are at the centre of the political and policy dialogue between the African Union and the European Union, as well as between the African Union member states and the EU. This also involves a fruitful dialogue and cooperation between the European Parliament and the Pan-African Parliament, which we strongly encourage.  I am glad to note that the meeting between the European Parliament and the Pan-African Parliament will take place on 27 and 28 November in Abidjan. This partnership must also go beyond political institutions and involve all stakeholders: non-state actors such as civil society organisations, youth organisations, the private sector, as well as economic and social actors. The summit agenda will be built around five key themes: peace and security; governance; investment and job creation; knowledge and skills; and mobility and migration. The overarching theme of youth will be prominently reflected throughout the summit’s agenda. We are exploring the possibility of strengthening the involvement of different stakeholders, in particular of youth, beyond the customary presentation of the recommendations in the opening session.  The European Union aims for concrete outcomes that make a difference, setting a collective agenda with ownership and contributions from all in the priority areas, with strong commitments from both sides coupled with concrete joint initiatives. For example, digital technologies and services are major drivers to boost development and a major source of growth and quality jobs for youth in various sectors, while also empowering women and girls. Sustainable energy and agriculture, the blue economy, building climate resilience, and research and innovation are equally important, and the list goes on. Significant work has been undertaken in preparation of the summit with the clear objective to go beyond declarations of intent and to establish concrete proposals for implementation. In the run-up to the summit, two successful summit side events have already taken place: the Civil Society Forum in Tunis in July and the Youth Summit in Abidjan on 9 and 11 October. A number of other events will follow and I would like to mention the EU-Africa Business Forum on 27 November. This sixth EU-Africa Business Forum will be entitled ‘Investing in job creation for youth’, with a specific focus on youth and women’s entrepreneurship. It will also deal with innovative financing and provide a platform to promote the EU’s new external investment plan, agri-business, renewable energy and digitalisation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are at a crucial moment for relations between Europe and Africa. On 28 and 29 November this fifth summit will finally be an African Union-European Union summit, in name and in fact, and it will be fundamental to redefine a future and necessary collaboration between our two blocs. The European Union and its Member States are the main partner for Africa, a continent that will double its population by 2050. Precisely for this reason, the main aspect on which we must focus is support for African youth, a theme that is at the heart of this conference, but which must be so in deeds and not just in words. If we really want to build resilient societies and fight against the causes that are at the root of radicalization, that's where we need to act, it's by creating jobs, creating participation, giving hope to those who don't have any today that we can change the face of a continent that is the main mirror of our geopolitical ambition. It depends on us which image this mirror can make us in the next few years. If we are brave or we are consistent with our values, then it will not be the image we have seen so far.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, relations between Europe and Africa are not only an interinstitutional issue, but also an economic and cultural one. In invoking a new partnership strategy, we allude to the sacrosanct right of African citizens to live in territories that guarantee well-being and dignity for all, economic development, food security, good governance, security tout court, migration and mobility, environment. These issues reported in the resolution are also fundamental elements of a political vision at the service of the people. Therefore we must make sure on our part that the posture from which we start is respectful of the emancipatory drive of the African people, which for some time has expressed the need to live under a real rule of law. The resolution's focus on young people can only achieve results by leaving aside any possible economic political greed. In other words, we must remove the specter of domination and superiority in order to behave in a more egalitarian way, that is, win-win, so that Europe and Africa will forever become mutually satisfied partners.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - I would like to congratulate the rapporteur. His document spells out very accurately the priorities of relations between the European Union and African countries in response to the joint communication between the Commission and the High Representative of May 2017. As the rapporteur and colleagues have already mentioned, the report was based on the need to strengthen the resilience of societies, especially through actions such as supporting development economic, strengthening good governance and security, and above all, respect for human rights, and emphasis on social and environmental aspects. Difficult topics such as migration and mobility, and highlighting the role of young people as well as addressing recommendations related to the Sustainable Development Goals and the 2030 Agenda, are also included in this report. I hope that the report will be adopted by a large majority on Thursday, which will allow the European Parliament's position to be clearly presented ahead of the 5th EU-Africa Summit in Abidjan. It is important that in this area, which is a priority from the perspective of development policy, the EU institutions should speak with one voice. Consistency in our position will also be crucial before and during the negotiations on the new Cotonou Agreement, which are scheduled to start in September 2018.

name: Norbert Neuser
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, dear Maurice Ponga! We'll adopt a good report on Thursday. Thank you for the constructive cooperation. As Social Democrats, we are happy to vote in favor of the report because it contains the essential points of our Africa policy. The report also makes it clear that we are ruling out demands that are repeatedly made - migration policy and the conditioning of development cooperation. Development cooperation remains a priority for poverty reduction, and conditioning to the recipient countries according to the motto “Keep the refugees off our necks, then there will be development funds” must not take place. We therefore also want - and this is what the report makes clear - legal migration opportunities in order to somewhat prevent the disasters that have been going on for years in the Mediterranean Sea and in desert areas. We have brought in some of our key positions. We want there to be fair access to land and water as a means of strengthening smallholder family businesses. In particular, we want self-determination to be guaranteed in family planning. And here I am addressing a point that is very important: if we want to curb overpopulation, we need clear messages, then we also need self-determination. Otherwise, many of our development cooperation efforts will be of relatively little use if, as a result of unbelievable population growth, the aid and whatever progress we have made is essentially undone. One last thing about dialogue: We have the possibilities for dialogue; we should make even greater use of it in the area of ​​the ACP, in the area of ​​the Pan-African Parliament and in cooperation with our Parliament. Overall, a very good report. I am very optimistic about Abidjan.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, 60% of Africans are young people under the age of 25, many leaving in extreme poverty or affected by violent conflicts and natural disasters. We go to Abidjan with a firm decision to assist them in providing resilience to their societies and states, to assist in building peace, to bring reconciliation if necessary, and to providing post—conflict reconstruction. We are going to accept strategies that are long term, and we consider it both challenging and a fantastic opportunity.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, first I would like to thank and congratulate Mr Ponga on this dossier and this excellent report. Africa and Europe are neighboring continents, I think this is too often forgotten. We are linked by a common history, sometimes painful, sometimes perspective, we share cultures and languages ​​in common and I think - I have already pleaded for this for a very long time - that Africa and Europe must forge a common strategy and an authentic and ambitious partnership which definitively abandons paternalism and turns its back on unacceptable forms of neocolonialism, which still too often trot in the heads of certain decision-makers. We need a real political and economic partnership. It would be profitable both for Europe and for Africa. The best path would be the economic development of Africa. This is the reason why I have always defended economic partnership agreements. Africa is in dire need of a vibrant market economy which could create prosperity by harnessing its immense resources and which could also lift millions of citizens out of poverty and in particular, as a colleague said, millions of young people. who are unemployed and without prospects. But if Africa needs market economies, it also needs strong states that guarantee a fair distribution of this wealth that is created. Too often it happens that, even where there is growth - sometimes even, there was a time, in double digits, I think of Latin America -, poverty does not reduce, because it is concentrated in those who create it selfishly, it must be said. The state must therefore play an important role. We must also become political partners in geopolitical space. I think it is finally time to meet our financial commitments to developing countries to support policies to support renewable and alternative energies.We need to transfer technology and knowledge, but I really believe that, in recent years, Europe has perhaps not been attentive enough to weld and truly forge an alliance with Africa.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, relations between the European Union and Africa must not respond to the exclusive interests of the Union. Neither geostrategic, such as the outsourcing of our borders to control migratory flows, nor commercial and investment, such as the search for the exclusive benefit for European companies and capital. These relationships should be based on mutual understanding and cooperation among equals, overcoming colonialism and paternalistic behaviors, and effectively address the common challenges we have - such as climate change, poverty and inequality - and achieve development goals. sustainability, which, together with the strengthening of human rights, should be the key objectives of the European Union-Africa strategy. All foreign action for Africa must be subsidiary to this objective, and for this we should promote fair trade; boost social and solidarity economies; contribute to the accountability of the private sector by including clauses of due diligence obligations in trade agreements, thus ensuring the sustainability of value chains; not to increase the unsustainability of debt, following the UNCTAD principles on responsible sovereign lending and borrowing; promote tax systems and fight tax evasion and avoidance, which drain your domestic resources. As long as human rights and the sustainable development goals are not at the center, we will also be complicit in the increase in poverty, inequality and, ultimately, in the root causes of forced migration.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Officially, the EU-AU summit is about youth. But it's actually about migration, of course, and the African leaders know that. I think they will receive our Prime Ministers with some skepticism when they arrive in Abidjan. Do we come as partners, do Macron, Merkel and Rutte come up with their domestic agenda or are they really willing to help the youth of Africa? You cannot fight poverty in a few years and fighting the root causes of migration takes a lot of time: certainly an entire generation. Africa faces a huge demographic challenge. Many young people are looking for work and a better life, and we must and can help with that. But then we must be prepared to make a long-term commitment to the developments in that continent, then we will have to act more fairly, invest more fairly and not spend our development money on closing borders but on poverty reduction. Then we are real partners and Abidjan also speaks of friend to friend who is future-oriented. If we don't, then we have a problem.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is well known that Africa is an important partner for Europe, that it is becoming more and more important every day. Migration, raw materials, terrorism, population growth, peace and security, environment and development are just some of the fields in which cooperation between the two continents can bear fruit and it is essential to keep this in mind in view of the summit between the European Union and the Africa of Abidjan. But if we want to tackle these issues effectively and if we really want to solve the big common problems, then we need to have the courage to call things by their own name and tackle the problems at their root. We must make it clear that it is not by funding multinationals that development is guaranteed, it is not by closing our eyes to human rights violations that we fight migration and it is not with arms that peace is achieved. I hope that in the next summit between heads of state, the serious problems on the table can be tackled with a different attitude, adopting a long-term perspective and keeping a straight back in the face of the inevitable pressures of large power groups that pursue particular interests often in conflict with the common good in Africa.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, economically, 33 of the 47 least developed countries in the world are in Africa. 218 million people live there in extreme poverty. These figures are all the more worrying given that, according to official forecasts, Africa, which currently has one billion inhabitants, will have two and a half billion in 2050. It is therefore urgent to help Africa, out of solidarity towards Africans, but also in our interest, because if we do nothing, we will experience an unprecedented migratory flood. To help Africa, the European Union must increase its grants under the European Development Fund. For their part, European states must respect their commitment to devote 0.7% of their GDP to development aid, in order to intensify their cooperation with Africa. The Ponga report is right to reiterate these objectives, notably by endorsing Jean-Louis Borloo's proposal to electrify Africa. But it disappoints in three ways. First, by wanting to deliver Africa to globalized free trade, which would amount to ruining its traditional agriculture when it should be encouraged instead. Second, by not supporting enough the G5 Sahel, an African counterterrorism intervention force, created by five African states, with the help of France. Finally, in wanting to promote legal immigration and singing praises, I quote, "positive effects of migration", because I believe that Europe needs children more than migrants. Its future depends on the development of a natalist policy and not on migratory submersion, legal or not.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: - Mister President! One of the key points of this very good report by Maurice Ponga is paragraph 39, where the European Parliament regrets that Africa is losing around 50 billion US dollars each year in illicit cash flows, which exceeds and thereby exceeds the annual funding from official development cooperation Efforts to mobilize domestic revenues are undermined. Not only since the Paradise Papers did we know that European companies, in cooperation with corrupt African regimes, are very good at bringing the profits out of the continent and not paying taxes. If this swamp is not drained, no matter how many tax money-financed development measures we can launch - we will chase after development. Second, if we put in place additional development cooperation instruments such as the Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, then we should also ensure that it brings additional added value. 90% of this fund is financed from the European budget. Only a small proportion of the Member States are involved. At the same time, however, a large number of programs from these funds are contractually bound with government development agencies from the member states. This is left pocket, right pocket, and it doesn't get us any further.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I think Mr Ponga’s report is an excellent report and it gives us the opportunity to see the summit in Abidjan as one which is framed by the sustainable development goals. That is extremely important, because by doing that we move away from the traditional view of Africa – about donor—recipient aid – and we move towards a partnership fit for the 21st century. Commissioner, you talked about the need for practical outcomes to the summit; I think that that is the most important thing that has been said tonight. We don’t want to come away with more general statements of intent; we need to come away with jobs and investment in Africa. It’s estimated that we need 15 to 20 million jobs created per year in Africa if we are to meet demand from the growing population. Between 2010 and 2015, only 21 million jobs were created. The focus has to be on investment and bringing growth and sharing the benefits of that growth with the wider population. I hear you say that there will be a very strong gender dimension, and I hope you will deliver on that as well: without the interests of young women being looked after, we will not get a just growth in Africa.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: - Mister President! A saying from Uganda about the EU-Africa Strategy: The best time to plant a tree was twenty years ago; the next best is now. As a development politician, I would have wished for this wisdom about the new Africa strategy a long time ago. Our neighbor Africa deserves a fair offer at eye level. We need a strong African Union as a twin of the EU - also in our own interest. We need cooperation that respects the diversity of African states and provides concrete on-site help. Let's strengthen families, municipalities and cooperatives instead of wasting the millions on regimes or corporations! Let's give away education for the young generation as a motor of development in exchange and in partnership! Let's learn from each other! Let's bring trainees, students and start-ups together, let them mature together! Let's create perspectives and positive development! Let's stop arms exports! We deliver well pumps and water purifiers! Let's lock the despots' accounts! Let's promote real democrats! Let's strengthen subsidiarity! Or, as they say in Senegal: the little stars always shine while the big sun goes down.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, I think Maurice Ponga agrees with me that the development of Africa is first and foremost the business of Africans. The aim of a good EU-Africa strategy is to respect this principle of standing alongside Africans, not to dominate them, but to support them. The aim of a good EU-Africa strategy is to oppose a common front to the plunder of resources and, to this end, to help African states to eradicate corruption, to levy taxes and to cut taxes. wings to predators. The goal of a good strategy is to have a common understanding of the great challenges we have in common: the climate, insecurity, terrorism and so on. The goal of a good EU-Africa strategy is to negotiate a real pact between Africa and the European Union and to bring our common views and positions to all international bodies, at the WTO, at the United Nations. and many more. The key to the success of such an enterprise depends on the credibility of all partners. From this point of view, the European Union, which is a solid partner, could do even better if it agreed to fulfill all of its commitments to its African partners and in particular as regards its level of aid. public development.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, there are those who try to hide behind successive European Union-Africa strategies the vision of the African continent as an immense board of imperialist dispute over raw materials, markets, areas of influence. The novelty may be that the hidden cat already has much more than the tail outside. Africa and the African peoples do not need to be modeled on the political and economic organization of their respective states. They do need to have their sovereignty and legitimate options respected in terms of their needs and desires. They do not need self-help that perpetuates relations of subordination and dependence and which is increasingly asserting itself as the bargaining chip for the acceptance of the European Union's policies and interests, be it in relation to migration or in relation to the liberalization and deregulation of trade . They do need genuine cooperation that privileges essential sectors such as education, health, agriculture, among others, and that is respectful of the sovereign will of the African people and their right to sovereign development.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE).
text: - Mr President! By 2050, Africa's population is estimated at 2.4 billion people, the majority of them young people. I am therefore pleased that the main theme of the fifth EU-Africa Summit is youth, as it is important to set up, support and fund initiatives that promote democracy, the rule of law and human rights, aimed at young people. The EU's relations with African countries are historically rooted. Our joint work now should focus in particular on creating long-term political, economic and social conditions in Africa that promote sustainable and stable growth and development in the areas of peace, democracy, human rights, the rule of law and good governance. Among other things, the root causes of poverty and migration should be combated. The free movement within Africa and between Africa and the EU, for both the highly educated and the low-skilled, should be facilitated through legal channels for migration. Last but not least, aid must not be conditional on migration agreements.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: - The cooperation of the European Union with Africa is based on asymmetrical agreements, and this is very good, because the purpose of this cooperation is to support the development of African countries.The goal of both sides is not only economic growth and development, but also peace and security, social development, democracy and human rights, as well as continental integration and, since the Valletta Summit, the fight against illegal immigration.The new priorities - we have heard it also in today's debate - include creating new jobs and acting to build democratic and transparent state institutions.In my opinion, however, education should be the top priority.First - education, second - education, and third - education.Because only an enlightened society is aware of its rights and ready to fight for them.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: - Mr President, it is more than likely that Africa is the cradle of humanity, but it is absolutely certain that it is the premature grave of tens of millions of people who are victims of poverty, victims of exclusion, of armed conflict, people forced intoemigrate in conditions of maximum risk.But Africa is also a country of resources, it is a continent of opportunities, full of talent and full of ambition for the future.We cannot solve their problems, but we can help them to do so and, to help them, we have to give them unconditional help.We have to invest in productive matters.We have to reach fair partnership agreements with them and we have to have a relationship of equality, of mutual respect, of aid to governance, of cooperation, to ensure that this continent, today a martyr, is in the future a continent of hope.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: - I am actually very happy that we are here this evening talking about the EU-Africa strategy. And as many colleagues have said, I think Africa should take matters into its own hands above all. Africa is a fantastic continent: beautiful people, beautiful nature, but unfortunately also full of challenges. A poor continent, a continent affected by many wars, a continent facing many challenges and experiencing a fantastic explosion, enormous growth. The young people there will increase enormously, population growth will increase. I think it is good that Europe is finally paying more attention to a good strategy. I would argue for Europe to commit to ending the conflicts. For me that is really priority number one. Two: ensuring that young people in Africa get opportunities, education, healthcare, infrastructure, ensuring that they can participate in politics there, and finally, very important: focusing on the fight against people smugglers. We know from Europol that 90% of asylum seekers reach Europe through people smugglers. Let's bet on that.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, it seems to me more urgent than ever to think about decoloniality, because relations between Europe and Africa are always lived in a relationship of domination, by means of free trade agreements which empty theAfrica of its own possibilities, which organize the plundering of its resources and which deliver it to the macabre game of multinationals.Allow me to hear here the great voice of Aimé Césaire: Africa, "Your sun tiara with the butt of the butt pushed up to the neck they have transformed into a straitjacket;your clairvoyance they put out in the eyes;prostitute your modest face;muzzled, howling it was guttural, your voice, which spoke in the silence of the shadows.Africa, do not tremble the fight is new ”, I close the quotation marks and I say: in the EU-Africa relationship, let us not perpetuate the mistakes of the past and do not do with Africa what Europe wants it to do.is.

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: - Mister President! With this Ponga report, but also with the document that we are going to adopt together with the Pan-African Parliament, we as parliamentarians will probably be addressing the right points before the Abidjan summit. And I also think that this will be the case at the actual summit. But for us it must be politically decisive that the commitment that we are expressing at the summit continues and that we do not get back into the situation we have had since the last summit, that there are no regular political troika at all within the framework of the ministerial troika meetings Has given meeting. That didn't happen. It is right for the Commission to meet - the African and the European - but this commitment must also remain on the part of the Member States. We also have to give an important push on the part of Parliament. The challenges are so great that we cannot afford to simply operate this relationship below the political level. We need a commitment on the part of the member states to bring the relations into a form so that the challenges can be tackled together.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Africa is an important and strategic partner for the EU. Yet, for some time now, relations with African countries have been heavily conditioned by the policies of externalization of our borders and responsibilities. But we will pay dearly for the security obsession of European governments that are entering into agreements, such as the Migration Compact, which want to make development aid conditional on border control. These policies do not eradicate poverty, but increase it, and certainly do not create opportunities for African youth. In this way we risk pushing African partners towards other interlocutors, concentrating aid on the countries that are on the routes that affect Europe, forgetting others, and we risk dramatically impacting African economies for which intra-regional mobility is essential. Here, what are the European governments doing? They are focusing on supporting the Libyan Coast Guard, which the other day obstructed search and rescue operations, causing the death of five people including a child. What are they doing? They are sending back to Libya, to the prisons where people are tortured, the people who try to escape. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights also spoke today of an outrage to human conscience. Please reflect on this and change these policies which are nefarious.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, with the fifth Africa-European Union Summit just around the corner, we need a more equal partnership between the European Union and Africa, based on development and mutual respect, in order to tackle global issues such as the fight against poverty or peace, and to promote a relationship based on the inalienable right of peoples to choose their own economic, political and social system, without external interference. The Africa-EU strategic partnership over the past ten years has further favored the neocolonial interests of certain states, and even multinational corporations, at the expense of the peoples. The trap of development aid in the form of loans increases the unsustainable debt of African countries. The aid must be without usurious conditions. The EU strategy with Africa must not be linked to the priorities chosen by donors and must not be linked to the control of migration and refugee flows. It is regrettable, in this sense, the pressure from the EU to conclude pacts on migration and attempts to externalize borders.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Africa is and must be a priority area for our foreign action, by history, by geography, by human and economic ties. I am pleased that youth and employment are the main themes of the forthcoming European Union-African Union Summit in Abidjan. These are decisive fields for the prosperity of the continent. One of our main challenges is to help create physical, legal and institutional security, the three necessary for development in Africa to be consolidated to generate greater stability and better opportunities; in other words, and following Mr. Ponga's report, in deepening political, economic, social, environmental and security resilience. Obviously, a central area of ​​mutual interest in our relationship is also related to migratory flows. This is a complex matter that requires a policy of comprehensive collaboration with the countries of origin and transit, in such a way that it benefits all, as agreed at the Valletta Summit. And I conclude, Mr. President: I hope, I trust that the Abidjan Summit will serve to continue deepening and updating that important relationship of the European Union with that neighboring continent, with Africa.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate the outcome of this very important report, which comes at a time when some political and economic partnership between Europe and Africa is gaining momentum, and when the need to provide the latter with a new vision is becoming increasingly more pronounced. Resilience should be one of the concepts lying at the core of the new EU—Africa Strategy. I share the opinion that future cooperation, for which an intensified political dialogue acts as a precondition, should focus on key areas such as economic development, good governance, human development, migration, the environment, and security and the fight against terrorism. Moreover, I emphasise the importance of adapting a holistic approach to migration, and I particularly welcome the line drawn between development aid and cooperation in migration matters. Finally, having in mind the very strong ties between the European Union and the African countries, I would like to reiterate the need for a boosted commitment from the EU’s side in helping the African continent to be stabilised and attract major investment through, for example, the European fund for sustainable development – a very important EU instrument to boost development.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: - I have spent some time in Africa and I know that we are not working on this strategy just because of the summit in Abidjan.This strategy does not only concern the future of Africa, but is essential for the future of the European Union.I welcome the comprehensive strategic approach to Africa and congratulate my colleague Pongi on his engagement.I want all our political and financial resources to be used in a more coordinated and effective way.I am in favor of giving more support to the non-governmental sector, which works for the good of Africa, and in some places only this sector is effective because government services do not work.And I would also say, let’s not be too bureaucratic in this.Let us join the Saharan greening projects and pay more attention to the consequences of climate change in Africa.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: - Mr President, cooperation strategies must contribute so that the values ​​of globalization are fair and capable of responding to the issues of our time, inequalities, climate change, forced migration and security challenges. Association partnerships are needed, inspired by a shared vision about the future that will allow the emergence of strong institutions. At the same time, we have to empower individuals, give them qualifications and skills. The EU-Africa Summit is an excellent opportunity to set clear post-Cotonou stakes, enabling the Sustainable Development Goals to be achieved and the Paris Agreement to be fulfilled. Investing in cooperation for the qualification of populations, in particular the youngest, investing in new digital networks as vehicles for participation and access to services of common interest and investing in the energy transition and in the dissemination of population access to clean energy sources: clear options. We have to consolidate a partnership for the future that starts to bear fruit now.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Africa is our closest neighbor, a key strategic partner of the European Union. And that is why it is extremely important to intensify our relations with this continent. Mr Ponga's excellent report highlights two major challenges, which are sustainable development and job creation, especially among women and young people. While the European population ages day by day, Africa has the highest percentage of young people in the world. We must take advantage of this situation to create synergies that benefit both regions, while controlling flows. And the best way to control these flows is to invest in Africa. We are the main trading partner of the African continent, the largest partner in development cooperation, and this cooperation should translate into an increase in European investment in large public works in African countries. The Abidjan Summit is a magnificent occasion for the European Union to make clear its true commitment to Africa.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – As an active member of the EU—ACP Joint Parliamentary Assembly, I view our relationship with Africa as one of our foreign affairs priorities. My colleague’s useful report has highlighted some of the most important elements that our relationship with Africa should be based on, such as the inclusion of women and young people and the importance of the cultural and artistic sector. Most importantly, it is crucial that EU development funds should not be tied to cooperation with Europe in the field of migration: this report is very clear on that.  The report also grants significant importance to the fight against terrorism. Although this should be on the agenda, both Africans and Europeans must be extremely careful, as the use of terrorism laws to fight against human rights defenders and political opponents is more and more widespread on both our continents. In all sectors, our priority should be to always hold ourselves and our partners to achieving the highest human rights standards.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: - Mr Vice-President, Mr Pong's report is very stimulating material.He mentions, in fact and with knowledge of the situation, many of the challenges for the future of the partnership between the European Union and Africa.I am very sorry that I will not be able to support her in the vote.The emphasis on sexual and reproductive rights and the promotion of abortion in Africa by European Union funds is contrary to my conscience, as well as that of my constituents.I find it very harmful that the promotion of the so-called 'right to abortion' has become part of the European consensus on development policy.As a result, unlike abortion clinics in the European Union, those who often provide real health care to people in difficult conditions while adhering to the Hippocratic oath will not receive a penny from the European Union.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the future European Union-Africa Partnership must focus on specific areas, such as the protection of human rights, the rule of law and pluralism, good governance, security and the fight against Islamic terrorism, and the protection of environmental measures and the implementation of measures to tackle climate change, the debt settlement of African countries, the immediate cessation of the plunder of their wealth-producing resources and, of course, the tackling of migration. This can be done mainly through investments aimed at reducing poverty and unemployment. Only in this way will the total migratory flows that have flooded Greece and Italy be reduced. Investing in Africa, therefore, rather than providing generalized trade preferences for African agricultural and livestock products, such as duty-free Tunisian oil or South African feta, are unfavorable regulations for the primary sector in the European Union and Greece.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Pong on an excellent report and, at the same time, like many of my predecessors, I would like to emphasize that cooperation between the European Union and Africa is indeed very strategic. The contribution of the Africa-EU Partnership Strategy aims to strengthen, deepen and focus on the prosperity and stability of both continents in line with the commitments made under the Sustainable Development Goals, and in particular to take into account the environmental factor. Africa is particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change, and it is therefore crucial for the EU to develop a strategic approach to building resilience to climate change and to support African countries, especially those least developed, in their efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to climate change. At the same time, it is important that our alliance really focuses on young people, on the future, on supporting education, on the effective creation of new jobs.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Ponga for a very good report. This EU-Africa summit is coming to an important stage, and investment in young people has rightly been chosen as a priority. We know that Africa has a very young and rapidly growing population. All over the world, quality education and good skills are the key to a better future - and so is Africa. That is why it is now important to find concrete solutions on how to improve the quality of education at all levels in Africa and, above all, to ensure that girls also have access to education. It is good that we also want to focus more broadly on the rights of girls and women and the right of women to family planning. It is important for Africa's sustainable future - as is the promotion of entrepreneurship and sustainable investment in energy and transport projects. In all of these, concrete decisions are now expected from the summit. It is very important for the future of both Africa and Europe.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Members for their comments.  The Commission appreciates today’s rich debate showing the Parliament’s strong commitment and expertise regarding the improved Africa-EU relations. There is a general consensus on the work that remains to be done and on the key areas to be addressed. I must assure the House that the Commission is committed to fostering sustainable development and inclusive growth in Africa, in line with the priorities identified in the report. In this respect, the upcoming AU—EU Summit on 29—30 November 2017 is a key milestone for strengthening our partnership with the African partners. It is good to know that the key priorities covered by the report include economic development and job creation, natural resources, good governance, security, migration, the environment, education and youth – largely in line with the Commission’s priorities as well. As Commissioner for the Environment, I was also pleased to note the emphasis of the report – as well as the comments during this debate – on sustainable development, including the sustainable use of natural resources such as minerals, timber and wildlife, sustainable agriculture and industry, and the development of the blue economy and maritime industry. I was also pleased to see reference to the Action Plan against Wildlife Trafficking. The Commission is committed to working closely with Parliament and the EU Member States to ensure that we jointly advance our positive partnership with Africa. As I said earlier, the upcoming AU—EU Summit will be a testimony to our collective engagement, and a great opportunity to promote sustainable development for the benefit of all. I would like to thank Mr Ponga once again for his excellent work, and all the Members of this House for their contribution.

name: Maurice Ponga
text: protractor.- Mr President, I will be very brief to express my thanks to the colleagues who spoke this evening during the debate on this report that we are discussing.I also inform you that it will be put to a vote on Thursday.I hope it gets passed.Thus, he will be our roadmap and our word at this Abidjan summit.I end by saying that our wish is that this summit can provide solutions to the challenges that we have mentioned this evening.

name: Πρόεδρος.
text: - The discussion is over.The vote will take place tomorrow.Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: written. - This report is devoted to enhanced cooperation between the EU and Africa, in particular enhanced dialogue on good governance, human rights and the environment, and the condition that development aid is linked to respect for these issues. The report is also concerned about security and terrorism threats, and calls for the EU-Africa Strategy to help prevent such violations. In economic terms, the report calls for stronger public-private partnerships, it supports the establishment of a continental free trade area in Africa and the increase in intra-African trade. On the subject of refugees, the report reiterates the call for legal migration to be promoted and for a European framework for resettlement to be created. The report also calls on Member States to increase their financial contribution to trust funds and other instruments, thereby helping to reduce the root causes of migration. I welcome coordinated and transparent investments on the African continent in order to help the local people and thereby open up a secure future for them. However, I do not agree that Member States should provide mandatory resettlement quotas for refugees. Asylum law should remain the sole competence of the member states. It can be noted that there have recently been increasing discrepancies between report names and the texts actually contained. I would like to see more objectivity here.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing. - More than 218 million people live in extreme poverty in Africa, making the EU-Africa partnership an essential tool for implementing the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development. Although poverty is declining, the goals of sustainable development, in particular the eradication of poverty, must have priority. Migration is a key theme of the EU's global foreign and security policy strategy and a priority. If we want to stop migration, we need to give people jobs in our countries. I welcome the intensive political dialogue between the EU and Africa entitled On a new impetus for mutual partnership, with a view to giving new impetus to how to expand and strengthen prosperity and stability on both continents. As terrorism is a global threat to regional peace and stability, sustainable development and internal security, it must be addressed through coordinated efforts by national governments, regional and international organizations and European agencies. It is therefore essential to strengthen cooperation in the framework of this strategy, the main aim of which will be to prevent impunity, to uphold the rule of law, to expand police and judicial capacity, using best practices, to prevent and combat terrorism.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the oral question to the Commission on "Action Plan for Nature, Man and the Economy" on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000067/2017 - 2017/2819).(RSP) - Β8-0608 / 2017)

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: Author. - Investing in nature and biodiversity must be central to a smart, sustainable and inclusive Europe. Protecting biodiversity is not only necessary for nature itself, but is essential for our well-being and prosperity. For example, one in six jobs in the European Union is dependent on nature and the added value of Natura 2000 is many times greater than the management costs. Erasing the biodiversity strategy will cost us 50 billion euros per year. Stopping biodiversity loss must be a political priority. The Bird and Habitat Directives are a vital link in this story and must be fully implemented. This is the core message of the biodiversity report adopted by the European Parliament in February 2016 and for which I was rapporteur. At the end of 2016, the Commission finally cleared the uncertainty about the Nature Directives. The Commission also decided that the guidelines are fit for purpose and that the focus should be on their better and accelerated implementation. The Action Plan for Nature, People and the Economy proposed by the Commission earlier this year is without a doubt a step forward. But at the same time, the plan is inadequate and insufficient to achieve the biodiversity goals. Without additional efforts, we will miss the appointment again in 2020. The Environment Committee has a number of clear and concrete questions and wants to use them to send a strong signal about what can and must be improved. The action plan contains only one reference to the biodiversity strategy. How will the Commission respond to Parliament's more general requests for effective achievement of the 2020 targets? Moreover, the action plan only extends to 2020. It will remain silent for the period after 2020. What strategy does the Commission consider necessary for that post-2020 period? Financing is also essential. How will the Commission ensure that adequate funding is available, including in the next Multiannual Financial Framework? Is the Does the Commission intend to introduce a tracking mechanism for Natura 2000 expenditure to improve transparency, accountability and efficiency of EU funds, as recommended by the European Court of Auditors? Furthermore, the action plan does not respond to important initiatives for which Parliament has long been a requesting party. I am thinking of the creation of a trans-European network for green infrastructure, an EU initiative for pollinators and measures against illegal killing of birds, to name a few. When will the Commission publish its proposals on this matter? Finally, the coherence between biodiversity policy and other areas such as the common agricultural policy, including cohesion policy, remains a huge challenge. How does the Commission intend to increase this coherence? How does the Commission intend to integrate Natura 2000 and wider biodiversity measures in those areas? How does the Commission intend to monitor the impact of the common agricultural policy on biodiversity? We expect not only concrete answers from the Commission, but also a clear commitment. A lot of precious time has been lost and the clock is ticking. For the health, well-being and prosperity of future generations, we must do everything we can to safeguard nature and biodiversity. It goes without saying that the commitment of all actors is required for this. Biodiversity is everyone's business. If you leave the green theme blue-blue, you catapult Europe to the steel age.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Demesmaeker and the House for this opportunity to discuss with you the Commission Action Plan for nature, people and the economy. As you know, the plan is the result of a comprehensive and participatory evaluation process and a fitness check on the Habitats and Birds Directives. The findings of the fitness check were fully endorsed by the College of Commissioners during an orientation debate in December last year. The conclusion was clear: there is no essential problem with the legal framework of the Habitats and Birds Directives. It remains fundamentally sound, but there are problems with the application of the framework, and that is why we do not get the results that we want. There are funding shortages and we need more knowledge and more commitment. These are the key issues and that is why we prepared a strategic plan to address those gaps. Let me turn to the specific questions you have tabled for today’s debate. Your first question is about the links between the Action Plan and the 2020 Biodiversity Strategy. The Action Plan includes 15 concrete actions. These reflect the findings of the fitness check on the Habitats and Birds Directives and address the main shortcomings revealed by this evidence-based evaluation. The aim of the plan is rapidly to improve the practical implementation of the directives, to accelerate progress towards the EU 2020 goal of halting and reversing the loss of biodiversity and ecosystem services, and to improve consistency between the Habitats and Birds Directives and broader socio-economic objectives. Implementation of the Action Plan is essential in order to make progress on Target 1 of the EU Biodiversity Strategy, to – and I quote – ‘fully implement the Birds and Habitats Directives’. It will also contribute to achieving other targets in this strategy, namely Targets 2, 3 and 4, on restoration, agriculture, forestry and fisheries. Most of the actions are being launched in 2017 so that the Commission can report on their delivery before the end of its current term of office in 2019. We are aware that further efforts are needed to reach the 2020 biodiversity targets. The upcoming initiative to address the decline of pollinators is just one example of the Commission’s response to the calls made by Parliament to achieve the 2020 targets. Since you also asked about the Commission’s intentions from 2020 onwards, I can tell you that the nature Directives provide a solid and long-term legal foundation for EU biodiversity policy. The Commission plans to evaluate the EU Biodiversity Strategy and to report on its finding by 2020. The outcome of this evaluation will feed into thinking on the follow-up to the current EU Biodiversity Strategy, along with a global biodiversity framework for post-2020. Let me now address question two, which concerns specific initiatives on the Trans-European Network for Green Infrastructure (TEN-G), and also pollinators, access to justice and the illegal killing of birds. On TEN-G, I referred to Action 12 of the Action Plan which consists of providing guidance to support the deployment of EU-level green infrastructure, including through improving connectivity of Natura 2000 areas by mid-2018. A strategy framework to facilitate a more integrated approach to green infrastructure will be proposed under the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), providing some lessons for future inspiration. In addition, Action 1(b) of the Action Plan will motivate decision-makers to invest in green infrastructure through the provision of deeper guidance and appreciation of the value of ecosystem services.  On pollinators, the Commission intends to launch a dedicated initiative to complement the Action Plan. On access to justice, as a previous legislative proposal did not prove successful in Council, the Commission adopted in April 2017 an interpretative notice, presenting and explaining the substantial body of case law of the Court of Justice on the subject, including on the nature Directives. The Commission also undertakes many measures to eliminate illegal bird trapping, killing and trade, in cooperation with international conventions, and enforces the provision of the Birds Directive prohibiting trapping, killing and trade. Financial support is provided through the EU LIFE Programme funding.  The Commission assists Member States in fulfilling their obligations under the Birds Directive, for example through the ongoing LIFE European Social Enterprise Training (EuroSET) project, which is developing action plans and management plans for 16 threatened bird species. The third question is about mainstreaming Natura 2000 and wider biodiversity measures with other policies, especially with the common agricultural policy (CAP). As regards the current funding framework, Natura 2000 and wider biodiversity measures can be co-financed under several EU policies. As decisions on the allocation of EU funds under shared management rest primarily with the Member States, they are not obliged to take up the opportunities for financing Natura 2000 from the EU budget. Actions 9 to 12 of the Action Plan aim to facilitate full and effective use of the financial resources allocated for biodiversity protection and Natura 2000 sites in the period 2014-2020 under the various programmes and, where feasible, to promote increased allocations and uptake. In the context of Action 9 under the Action Plan, the impact of the CAP on biodiversity will be addressed in a specific evaluation scheduled for the second half of 2018. In accordance with the Commission guidelines, such an evaluation includes an assessment of consistency between the various policy areas concerned.  Let me now turn to a specific issue which is also the subject of the third question: large carnivores. The return of large carnivores, especially the wolf, to areas where they have been absent for a long time represents a significant challenge, especially at local level. The Action Plan envisages a series of measures to help address these challenges. For example, the Commission will update and actively promote, in all EU languages, its guidance document on species protection rules, which will include clarifications on flexibility within the existing legal framework. The Commission will also bring together experts from different Member States at bio-geographical level to address common challenges. This may also cover large carnivores whose populations are often transboundary. Action 13 of the Action Plan specifically proposes providing further support through the involvement of local and regional authorities, in order to inspire dialogue and help find solutions at a local level. The Commission will encourage the full and effective use of the financial resources under the European Agricultural Rural Development Fund (EARDF) to support coexistence through rural development measures and, in this context, support can be provided to farmers for preventive measures aimed at mitigating the risk of damage by large carnivores to livestock farming. Lastly, in question four, you ask about the next MFF. Here, I will be very brief as the Commission is now preparing its proposals for the post-2020 MFF. The indicators and the results from the ongoing financing period and the measures taken under the Action Plan will inform the debate and the reflections on the next MFF. It is too early to give indications of how Natura 2000 and wider biodiversity measures will be taken into account.  I thank the Members for their attention and I look forward to any further thoughts they may have on this broad, but important, topic.

name: Herbert Dorfmann
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! The Natura 2000 guidelines are now almost exactly 25 years old. And if you look back over these 25 years, you can say: on the one hand, a lot has been achieved, but on the other hand, there are perhaps hardly any guidelines in our legal texts that also cause such friction on the ground. This has to do with the fact that the Natura 2000 directives very often follow a top-down concept, that is to say that the Member States have the feeling that something is being imposed on them and, on the other hand, that the management of the Natura 2000 areas is not as before there are big gaps. That is why, Commissioner, my group is in favor of the action plan that has been submitted because, in our opinion, it is a step in the right direction and because we believe that the Natura 2000 directives must, on the one hand, be implemented in a subsidiary and cooperative manner. Subsidiary with those who are affected locally - with the administrations in the Member States and the regions - and, above all, cooperatively with those who are really affected, and these are mostly the landowners. But let me come back in a couple of sentences to a question that you just raised, Commissioner, and that is the question of large carnivores, particularly the wolf. Wherever the wolf returns today, it usually creates problems, because it does not return to a natural landscape, but to a cultural landscape - a cultural landscape where there are farmers, where there is breeding of small animals, where there is tourism where there are people and where there are usually massive problems. I fear, Commissioner, that a multilingual information sheet is not necessarily enough and that you cannot necessarily satisfy the farmers if you say: OK, we will pay for that from the Agricultural Fund. That means de facto that the Farmers can pay themselves.That is not the purpose of providing compensation for damage that undoubtedly occurs.I think we have to realize that the wolf is no longer an endangered animal, that there are populations that are in good conservation status, and that maybe it is our job to think about taboos tooQuestion to ponder: How can wolves also be managed where the good conservation status has been achieved, and do wolves really have to return all over Europe?I think that's our job.Only then will we give a sensible answer to those affected on site.

name: Karin Kadenbach
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would also like to express my joy that these nature conservation guidelines passed this REFIT test so positively. But in the end it came out: the legal basis is in order; there is a lack of implementation and, in part, also of financing.
