In your answer to the question today, you already touched on many of the problem areas that we have dealt with. I would just like to go back to two which we believe are not sufficiently detailed in your action plan. That is the close connection between biodiversity, species diversity and our agricultural policy. We would like the action plan, for example - as you mentioned - to include a concrete action plan for the conservation of pollinator insects. That's something we need. In the future, however, we also need very clear statements that the funds from the common agricultural policy will be used to preserve and improve biodiversity and not for measures that may have the opposite effect in everyday life. These are measures that we expect from you. We hope that you will be our loud voice in the Commission. We need biodiversity as a cross-cutting issue in all areas. It is not a silo, but a livelihood for animals, humans and in reality also for the economy.

name: Catherine Bearder
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, nature is in trouble. It is becoming clearer and clearer we are living beyond the sustainable carrying capacity of the planet. Over the last 40 years a quarter of wildlife species have become threatened with extinction. Internationally important peat bogs have been lost, wetlands drained for economic generation, and forests and their wildlife cut down, farmed or burned as humans encroach. Yet this is where the life-sustaining forces are located. Life-sustaining means that without them food, water and air will not and cannot be guaranteed to sustain us all.  The 1992 Rio summit saw the Convention on Biological Diversity, the first time the world came together and demanded action; and we’ve tried. We really have. In the EU we have had planned targets and funding for years, but the news is not good. A 75% decline in insect pollinator populations; just under 10% of our freshwater fishes are now threatened; one in ten of our bee species is facing extinction; a 72% decrease in butterflies. Animals and plants are disappearing across Europe. It is a silent crisis.  The Birds and Habitats Directives are conservation’s gold standards. Yet even they still miss their targets. Why? Is it the fact that the funding is going astray, or the political will to deliver is missing? Or because the public can’t see what is happening? And they really do care about nature. Well-financed Natura 2000 sites help create jobs, building green infrastructure with businesses, but again we are not going to meet the 2020 biodiversity targets and we’ll see further deterioration of nature.  So where’s the transparency? Where is the money going? Is the money being used effectively? We need to know. This House wants to work with the Commission and Member States to tackle this silent crisis. This time, Commissioner, let’s make it happen. Let’s deliver for nature.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, it is clear from the fitness check that we need real improvement for the implementation of the EU nature directives. Biodiversity is under threat across the continent, and this action plan points to where we are currently failing and aims to get us back on track for our 2020 goals. There are real concerns on the island of Ireland about the impact of Brexit on the over 135 000 hectares of Natura 2000 sites that traverse along the border. We also welcome in the action the financial commitments to increasing biodiversity funding. However, as an ecologist, I reject the paragraphs that focus solely on the negative aspects of the reintroduction of predators. While certain preventive measures may be necessary, we cannot rule out the introduction of predators as they constitute an important part of the ecological balance of some habitats.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, according to key NGOs, half of the EU’s natural areas are only protected on paper due to widespread implementation deficiencies. This action plan is an important step forward, as it aims to improve the practical implementation of the nature directives. But is it sufficient? Is it comprehensive enough? Despite the strong positive commitment to addressing the root problems, I think that the European Commission has failed to propose actions to tackle the drivers of biodiversity loss, including agriculture, transport and energy.  Firstly, the Commission must improve coherence with common agricultural policy and make sure that all infrastructure developments are fitted with proper environmental safeguards. Financing is also a very important issue. According to an IEP report, the current EU budget covers only up to 19% of the funding needed to properly manage Natura 2000 sites. Why does the action plan not better highlight the urgency of the need to scale up financial resources? Biodiversity has to be mainstreamed in the EU budgets beyond 2020, with nature protection earmarked in each individual instrument in addition to the dedicated biodiversity scheme. My last remark: the ECA found that the coordination between responsible authorities and other stakeholders in the Member States was not sufficient; therefore, the Commission should provide effective support to national and regional actors in the implementation of nature legislation and the improvement of environmental inspections.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: - Nature, people and the economy. This important combination is what the Action Plan of the European Commission and reality revolve around. A flexible implementation approach contributes to eliminating unnecessary conflicts and problems that have arisen between conservationists, governments, farmers, estate owners and fishermen. By developing improved guidelines with regulations and best practices, the Commission should provide effective support for implementation by provinces and governments. That also means financial compensation. Landowners should also be able to receive market-based compensation for green and blue ecosystem services for nature, landscape and water. When it comes to the explosive growth of geese and cormorants that threaten other waterfowl and rare fish species, game management is required. The same also applies to the wolf. The real danger posed by wolf-dog hybrids must be combated by consistent hunters: grazing livestock and the safety of our citizens are paramount. Finally, Chairman: a new green infrastructure TEN-G for all of Europe is a very bad idea if it is introduced too quickly. First, let's work on improved implementation within and coherence between Natura 2000 sites, including across borders, as the Council and Commission also wish, and let's get to work on that first.

name: Susanne Melior (S&D).
text: - Mister President! I would like to join my colleagues in thanking the Commissioner. I think it is a good thing that both environmental guidelines / nature conservation guidelines are in place for the time being and that we are primarily concerned with their implementation. Because in fact it is dramatic. What has not yet been mentioned: The death of insects is also taking place dramatically. We have a great loss of biodiversity here and we all have to work together. Dear Commissioner, you also had the opportunity to speak to anglers, pond farmers and fishermen in my home state of Brandenburg. Of course there are problems that still need to be addressed. With us it is the cormorant; the population has recovered very well and there is great competition for the fishermen when it comes to catching. I think that one really has to think about regulation. Because in order to be able to preserve biodiversity, we need everyone involved in the system, especially those who use it. But people, nature and business belong together.

name: Stefan Eck (GUE/NGL).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! The mid-term review of the biodiversity strategy clearly shows that we will not achieve our goals by 2020. On the contrary: biodiversity continues to decline at a rapid pace. In addition to the destruction of habitats by humans, climate change, environmental pollution and the spread of exotic animal and plant species, intensive agriculture is largely responsible for this sad development. We therefore need a new European agricultural policy that no longer focuses on mass production and growth at any price, but rather on the production of healthy food and the preservation of nature - which of course has to be rewarded financially. The previous agricultural policy is, with regard to the extinction of so many animal and plant species, but also in many other respects - a single catastrophe. It is time we took action. We also need a massive increase in funding for ensuring the Birds and Habitats Directive, for Natura 2000 and for many other measures. That would be a sensible investment, because with no money in the world we can buy back an extinct species.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the action plan that you are proposing to us combines in its title the natural environment, the population and the economy. This is a good balance. The preservation of biodiversity is an objective that we must share with the population, with the entire population, those directly concerned by the measures taken as well as populations further afield. Natura 2000 is thus a constructive approach if it is accompanied by sufficient means for its implementation, allowing the adoption of new practices by the population and the development of an active and dynamic economy. But this is not the case with our current management of large predators, large carnivores in particular. The Commission is determined to maintain strict protection of the wolf, without taking into account the impacts on breeding and life in rural areas, including tourism. Today the breeders have tried everything. They have no effective means of protection against predation from the wolf, a determined, intelligent and cunning animal. The idyllic vision of the wolf is part of an urban approach far removed from the real life of the territories it frequents. I come from there. Commissioner, let me ask you two questions: Have you ever had to deal with a desperate shepherd who collapses in front of you in tears? Are you ready to ask for a revision of the Berne Convention?

name: Norbert Lins (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! “He doesn't do anything, he just wants to play.” Dog owners often try to belittle the curiosity of their favorite pets with this sentence. That this does not apply to the wolf could be observed a few days ago in my southern German homeland. For the first time in a hundred years, a wolf killed farm animals in Baden-Württemberg, there were three sheep. Today's debate on the nature conservation action plan is about the question of coexistence between humans and animals, but also between farm animals and wild animals. During the aptitude test, we agreed not to open up the EU nature conservation directives, but rather that their implementation must be better. I therefore welcome the action plan. The guidelines allow the necessary flexibility between humans and nature. However, the Commission must further clarify the application of this discretion by the Member States by developing further guidelines. Based on the beaver management of my neighbors in Bavaria, it can be shown that regional management is quite feasible. Addressing the Member States and the regions: Of course, there must also be a clear political will for real management of wild animals. Addressed to the European Commission: If there are clear impulses from the regions and member states and the favorable conservation status is also proven, then the Commission must act. I think that also applies, for example, to the conflicts between the cormorant and fishermen. For an improved biodiversity the broad acceptance and participation of all concerned is essential. Nature conservation must be done in close coordination with all actors.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Vella, ladies and gentlemen. It's almost like a fairy tale: After an absence of over a hundred years, the wolf is back in Europe. It is spreading rapidly, that sounds spectacular. But when the returnees have reached their own terrace, it is more difficult to be happy. Because the wolf is definitely not a cuddly kitten. From Lower Saxony I keep getting pictures of cracked sheep, cattle and even dogs. It seems only a matter of time before a human falls victim to the predators. We understand these concerns. When strictly protected species have achieved a good conservation status and at the same time endanger sustainable development in rural areas, the Commission must act. Incidentally, this also applies to the cormorant. Its massive expansion in recent years has had a devastating impact on fish stocks. For example, on the Dümmer in Lower Saxony, the important predatory fish population has collapsed dramatically due to the cormorant. No wonder that a cormorant eats up to half a kilo of fish per day on average. The local people urgently need more room for maneuver. It cannot be that flexible solutions on site fail due to rigid European guidelines. Tomorrow we have the chance to bring Europe closer to its citizens again. We should seize this opportunity and adopt the action plan with a large majority.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the action plan must have real goals and need to be monitored. However, it is equally important to carry out checks on the directives already in place. In December 2016, based on an evaluation of the review of the effectiveness of the nature protection directives, it was found that these directives are fit for purpose, but that their implementation needs to be significantly improved in order to meet the set objectives. The aim of the Nature, People and Economy Action Plan is therefore to rapidly improve the practical application of the nature protection directives. I welcome the Commission's efforts to involve the local and regional authorities of the Member States, which play a key role in protecting nature and biodiversity. If successful cooperation is achieved at all levels, we can achieve very good results not only in the field of nature protection. After all, my colleague Lins raised the issue of regional management a while ago. I would also like to appreciate that this resolution calls on the Commission to present a strategy on the problem of endangered pollinators, particularly bees. Their contribution to the environment and the economy is incalculable and disappears from the environment. I would also like to support traditional agricultural practices in the field of pastoralism or an increase in subsidy support under the Life program by 10%, at least 10%. These are the basic requirements that I think should be reflected in the action plan.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Mr President, the aim of the Action Plan for Nature, People and the Economy is to rapidly improve the practical implementation of the nature directives. It is stated very ambitiously that this Plan will lay a solid foundation for harmonizing the needs of nature, people and economies and connecting them. The content of the Action Plan lists four priorities which clearly show the need to increase the budget money for the Natura 2000 network. In the table of measures, the proposed measures should be more specific, it is not specified what will be taken or how much each of these measures costs, as nor who, when and where should take these measures. Such serious documents should not use seemingly insufficiently substantiated claims, such as that the estimated annual benefit of the network is 200 to 300 billion euros, nor should they use the same method in the debate as, for example, highlighting the problem of illegal killing. birds, without stating in the first case who and on what basis made the assessment and how it varies on an annual basis by 100 billion euros, and in the second case, where the illegal killing of birds took place and what measures have already been taken. Since God created the world, people, nature and animal species have been in constant interaction for the benefit of man and should remain so in the future, of course with a much more responsible and measured attitude of man towards animal species and nature in general. Therefore, documents like this Action Plan need to be more concrete and realistic, with clear measures and a financial plan for each of the measures. In the area I come from, a lot of money has been spent on protecting the wolf, and people are not able to collect the damage the wolf is doing to them. That is simply unacceptable.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! We have often talked bilaterally about the situation as to how far the nature conservation directives - Natura 2000, the bird protection directive - can actually be implemented in practicable methods. There are also excesses. With all the highly interesting situation, that we absolutely want to restore biodiversity, want to protect it, that we have brought very specific species that were close to extinction back to a population, to a level where we can be happy that it is so. But if, for example, we have a cormorant population in the last 20 years that has increased tenfold and fifteenfold - at my home in Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania there are over 20,000 breeding pairs including young birds and a cormorant population of 40,000, 50,000 animals, who not only stay on the Baltic Sea coast and in the waters close to the coast and naturally exert enormous pressure on the fish stocks there, but also go further inland, then there are also the so-called tourists, those from the Baltic States and Finland, where they have theirs Have breeding areas, then come to us afterwards - we absolutely need a European cormorant management plan with shooting quotas, and we also have to go into the brood ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: - Mr President, the debate on the action plan for nature, man and the economy is an important initiative. The action plan, although an important step forward, is nevertheless considered insufficient to meet the biodiversity targets set for 2020. I have heard, Mr Vella, the Commission 's answers, but words must be combined with deeds. I am referring to the protection of Natura 2000 sites in Greece. A recent example is the brutal violation of the legislation for the protection of the Natura 2000 area in the area of ​​South Karystia, on Mount Ochi in Evia, where the installation of wind farms that will produce 50% of the total wind energy in Greece, destroying the environment , flora, fauna and especially wild birds. On Sunday, November 12, I participated in a relevant protest rally in Karystos. I convey to you, as I promised, the cry of agony of the residents who ask for protection of the Natura 2000 network on Mount Ochi. I am also waiting for an answer to the relevant question I asked on 29/9 on this issue.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I should like to thank honourable Members for their reflections and I will try to answer some of the points that were raised. Mr Dorfmann talked about the Natura 2000 sites and said that a lot has been achieved. A lot has been achieved in identifying the Natura 2000 sites, but I am not satisfied that a lot has been achieved in terms of managing them. In fact, only about 50% of the identified sites are being managed – and that is on land. When it comes to marine protected areas (MPAs), in the seas, we have only reached 6% of the area that we are targeting, whereas on land we have reached 20% which has been identified, but only 10% which is being managed. On the large carnivores issue, many mentioned large carnivores and that they could be problematic, but there are solutions and some Member States have found a number of solutions to a number of their problems. In our Environmental Implementation Review (EIR) we will be presenting a peer—to—peer. If Member States are lacking solutions whilst others have the solutions, we will hopefully be able to bring the best practices from one Member State to another. The important thing is not to move away from the problem but to find a solution. To Ms Kadenbach, yes, the issue of whether the legislation is in place, and whether we have the necessary funding to manage the sites, was one of the problems identified in the REFIT Fitness Check. One way of dealing with this, first of all, is that for funding which is being allocated to other sectors, especially agriculture under the CAP, we have to make certain that output is compatible with the nature directives as well. She mentioned pollinators and, as I said, we will be presenting a dedicated initiative on this. I agree with Ms Catherine Bearder that we are almost testing our biodiversity to its limits and that the news is not good, but I have to say that improvements – hopefully – will be made. That is the idea of this action plan, because if we were to continue with a ‘business as usual’ approach, things would have continued to deteriorate even further. Obviously there are many reasons; most of the reasons we can handle, some of the reasons will be a little bit more problematic but we still have to handle them. I am referring for example to agriculture. I am not talking about all agriculture, because agriculture has some good practices and it has some bad practices. We are not after taking away a single euro from the CAP, what we are after is making certain that every single euro which is spent in the CAP is spent sustainably and in protecting and strengthening nature as well. Ms Boylan expressed her interests and her concerns about Ireland, and again she mentioned the Natura 2000 sites. As I have already said, these have been a success story, but a lot more could be achieved. We are always talking about the Natura 2000 sites, which cover only 20% of our land, but we have to keep in mind that we still have to manage and protect our biodiversity in the other 80% which is outside the Natura 2000 areas. Mr Jávor asked whether this action plan is enough. I say, no, it is not enough. Why? Because it is an action plan and unless it is implemented, then the whole purpose of coming up with this action plan would be totally meaningless. He also mentioned the three sectors: transport, energy and agriculture, and their financing. As I said before, we have to make certain that every single euro spent in the multiannual financial framework (MFF) is spent with greening and sustainability in mind. Ms Schreijer-Pierik mentioned the unnecessary conflict between farmers, NGOs, authorities and I do agree with at least one word: ‘unnecessary’. Why? Because there have been some good examples of local solutions with the participation of all the stakeholders, including farmers. When we talk about the farmers and biodiversity, we have to look at the farmers as part of the solution and not always as part of the problem. I have spoken with a number of agriculture ministers, with a number of agricultural organisations, and I have to say they do understand the problem and most of them are very willing to be part of the solution and not of the problem. It is also in their interest, because when we come up with directives, with legislation to protect water, air, and soil, it is in the interest not just of nature but it is in the interest of farmers themselves. With regard to what Ms Melior said, that we have the directives and we have to implement: Yes we have the directives, some of the directives we have had for 38 years and one of my reactions when we said, ‘Ah, we have to implement them’ was: But should it take us 38 years to realise that we have to start implementing directives which we came up with 30 years ago? Ms Melior mentioned Brandenburg, I was there, I was present, I talked to the fishermen and this week I had a team from my services there and the report that I have back is that they have agreed on a list of actions, on a programme that they will take together and hopefully if this sort of programme works, we will be able to introduce this to other regions as well. Mr Eck said that by 2020 that we will not achieve our targets, even with the action plan. My reaction to that is: imagine how we could achieve them then without the action plan, how we could achieve them with the ‘business as usual’ approach. I agree that we will not reach it unless we are prepared to act. Mr Dantin spoke about ‘nature, people and economy’ in the title. I agree with him, that is the sustainability concept. We are not talking environment, we are not talking only nature but we are talking about sustainability. Sustainability does not start and end with nature, it does not start and end with people, it does not even start and end with the economy. The idea of sustainability is that one of these sectors does not move forward at the expense of the others. The issue of wolves came out several times. I have spoken about wolves in several of our Member States. The last time I spoke about wolves was about two weeks ago in Sweden, where they have a different problem because the problem in Sweden is, from an environmental perspective, their genetic status, not a question of numbers. It is time that we took the issue of wolves – not wolves in Spain, or wolves in Italy, or wolves in Sweden – but the whole issue of wolves across Europe so that we can come up with some good ideas how to manage this species. When we talk about problematic species – we are dealing with about 1 500 species – we are always mentioning the same five. We should not disregard the whole action plan and the whole directives which are dealing with 1 500 species simply because we have a problem with two, three or four of these species. On what Mr Lins said, there is no better solution than a local solution, very often it happens positively that solutions are found locally between all the stakeholders, where we have farmers, NGOs, fishermen, authorities and whatever. When these solutions are solved at a local level, we never hear anything about them in practice. Unfortunately, when local solutions are not found, then the authorities and everyone throws those problems back to Brussels.  Mr Gieseke spoke about the wolves again and Mr Stanislav Polčák spoke about the gaps between the directives and their implementation. A very good, important point that was mentioned was the need for the local and regional level. When we talk about implementation, very often we discuss implementation with central government but the implementation is taking place on the ground at local and regional level. I believe that that is where the focus should be. I agree with Mr Tolić that we have not only to implement but to speed up implementation because there is a lot of urgency. Unfortunately, I talk about this urgency because I fear that things are happening quicker than we were expecting, and I always give the example of the Great Barrier Reef which I mentioned this week in Bonn. When scientists started talking about the Great Barrier Reef and the problems it will have with climate change, this was 20 years ago and they predicted that by 2050 the Great Barrier Reef and other reefs will have problems. Today, 30 years before 2050, we have a big percentage of our reefs which are already gone. I fear that things are moving fast even than our scientists are telling us. It is not just a question of acting but acting with urgency as well. We often discuss, as Mr Kuhn said, even on a bilateral basis, the issues of cormorants which could be not always problematic, but they can be problematic in some areas for some economic activities. As is the case with Brandenburg, we are trying to solve and we are trying to be part of the solution as well. With regard to Mr Marias, I will look whether the specific issue has been handled or not and I will get back to you.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: I have received a motion for a resolution to end this debate.The discussion is over.The vote will take place tomorrow.
